TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian History: Religion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned requests:
(i) that those of religious conviction who have contributed to the development of Australia should be recognised in the study of Australian history to ensure that a balanced history is taught;
(ii) that any syllabus prepared on the teaching of Civics and Citizenship should include the contribution of people of religious conviction highlighting their religious motivation;
(iii) that funds be allocated to ensure that teachers are given in‐service training on the role of religious influences in the development of Australian democracy; and
(iv) that materials are produced to support the above for use in the classroom.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petitioners respectfully draw the attention of the Senate to the Fact that the quality of life of the citizens of the Sutherland Shire will be severely and adversely affected by the construction of an airport at Holsworthy. The petitioners therefore call on the Senate to urge the Prime Minister and Government to prevent the construction of any airport at Holsworthy.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the petitioners respectfully draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the residents, visitors and friends of the Illawarra wish to voice their strong and united opposition to Holsworthy being considered the site for Sydney's second airport. An airport would destroy pristine bushland, and pollute our air and water. The Illawarra's tourism industry, largely based on the region's beauty and tranquillity, would be crushed. An airport would fracture the existing society by dividing and tormenting residents with inescapable flight paths.
We call on the Senate to urge the Government to prevent the building of an airport at Holsworthy.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: The Petitioners respectfully draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the quality of life of the citizens of the Illawarra will be severely and adversely affected by the construction of an airport at Holsworthy. PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced.

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya;

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service was `operational' and accepted responsibility for disabilities resulting from that service. Those affected appreciate the belated, partical recognition. However, government departments are still resorting to old, and inventing new excuses, to deny the above 3 points.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate acts to help remove the injustice of 40 years and fully recognise R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age` as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned recognises the importance to Australia's retirement income policy of a stable and secure superannuation system in which people are encouraged, not penalised, for taking steps to provide for their retirement and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that `The Coalition is fully committed to engendering stability, security, simplicity and flexibility into the superannuation system'.

2. The Liberal/National Government acknowledge that the inclusion of superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test is inequitable, erodes public confidence in the superannuation system and penalises those who have attempted to provide for their own retirement.
3. The Government repeal legislation including superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation of Postgraduate Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government recognise that taxing scholarships will:
(a) jeopardise links between universities and industry;
(b) increase the costs of scholarships resulting in few scholarships or scholarships of less value;
(c) represents another attack on the education sector; and
(d) compromise Australia's future research capacity and productivity;
and

Calls on the Government to ensure that any changes to the regulations or legislation governing the taxation of postgraduate scholarships maintain the tax exempt status of all postgraduate scholarships.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation of Postgraduate Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned students and staff at the University of Tasmania, do hereby declare our opposition to the taxation of postgraduate scholarships. We respectfully submit that:
(a) the majority of research undertaken in Australian universities is performed by postgraduate research students;
(b) postgraduate scholarship stipend levels place research students amongst the lowest paid professionals in the country;
(c) taxation of scholarships would act as a significant disincentive to pursue postgraduate study by some of Australia's most talented young researchers;
(d) taxation of industry‐linked scholarships would jeopardise many of the sponsored research arrangements being otherwise encouraged between universities and industry; and
(e) loss of welfare benefits due to the increase in assessable income associated with scholarship taxation would affect sole parents and young families in a particularly regressive manner.
We therefore call upon the Parliament to assert the tax‐free status of merit‐based postgraduate scholarships through legislative changes to the taxation law.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promoted Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate notes, with concern, the observation expressed in the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration, entitled Cultivating competition: Inquiry into aspects of the National Competition Policy reform package , that there has been no major analysis of the broader socio-economic costs of the National Competition Policy.

(2) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Socio-Economic Consequences of the National Competition Policy, be appointed to inquire into and report, by the first sitting day in 1998, on the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (a) the broader socio-economic consequences, including costs, of the National Competition Policy, as implemented by the Competition Policy Reform Act 1995 , including, but not limited to, the impact of the policy on:

TAB.TAB: (i) unemployment,
(ii) changed working conditions,
(iii) social welfare,
(iv) equity,
(v) social dislocation, and
(vi) environmental impacts; and

PARA.TAB: (b) the relative effect and variation in impact of the National Competition Policy on urban and rural and regional communities.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the committee consist of seven senators as follows:

TAB.TAB: (i) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(ii) two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(iii) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and
(iv) one nominated by the Greens Western Australia or Independent senators;

SPEECH.PARA: (4) That the quorum of the committee be three members with one representing the Government, one representing the Opposition and one representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens Western Australia or independent senators.
(5) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.
(7) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(8) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(9) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

(10) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(11) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(12) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate adopt the following resolution, agreed to by the European Parliament:
The European Parliament,
having regard to its previous resolutions on the case of Mordechai Vanunu, in particular those of 14 June 1990, 22 November 1990 and 10 October 1991,
A. recalling that Mordechai Vanunu has been held in solitary confinement in Israel since he was kidnapped in Rome on 30 September 1986 and sentenced to 18 years imprisonment,
B. deeply concerned that such incarceration for over ten years in a small cell will cause permanent psychological damage,
C. aware that Mr Vanunu told the press everything he knew about Israel's nuclear weapons capacity more than ten years ago, and that he does not now constitute a security risk,

D. noting that Amnesty International described this prolonged solitary confinement as `cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment' and called for his immediate release `to redress the human rights violations he has suffered',

PARA.TAB: 1. Deeply regrets no mercy has been shown to Mordechai Vanunu since it adopted the previous resolutions referred to above;
2. Calls upon the competent Israeli authorities to show clemency to Mordechai Vanunu by removing him from solitary confinement and considering his early release.

(b) notes that the Howard Government's policy on greenhouse gas emissions contains a proposal to set meaningful differential targets for Australia as a `special case' so as not to destroy Australian industries and the nation's economy, which are so dependent on fossil fuels;

TAB.TAB: (i) the ALP for preying on the concerns of steelworkers at Newcastle with much rhetoric about protecting jobs, when at the same time the ALP understands that the implementation of binding targets would devastate Australia's steelmaking, coal, aluminium and non-ferrous metal industries, cut our gross domestic product by 2 per cent by the year 2010 and cut wages by 20 per cent, and

(ii) the ALP for not standing up for coal mining and aluminium smelter jobs in the Hunter region where, over the coming 2 years alone, a $1.2 billion coal boom producing 665 direct jobs would be threatened by an impractical greenhouse policy.

TITLE.XREF: PLEBISCITE FOR AN AUSTRALIAN REPUBLIC BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus and Senator Kernot) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to require a plebiscite on whether Australia should be a republic.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats greatly regret the decision of the government not to accept the Senate's amendments to the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1996. We also regret the government's decision not to proceed with the People's Convention in December this year.

Our parties remain committed to ensuring that all Australians are given an opportunity to have their say on whether Australia should become a Republic, with an Australian as our Head of State. Accordingly, we urge the government to join with us in adopting a constructive approach to the Republic debate.

To this end, we are jointly sponsoring this bill, announced yesterday by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and the Leader of the Opposition, in the Senate. The Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Kim Beazley MP, is introducing a similar bill into the House of Representatives today.

The bill provides for the holding of a plebiscite, a national vote, on whether Australia should become a Republic. The plebiscite will be conducted in accordance with the usual forms and precedents as provided in the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. This includes provision for a compulsory attendance ballot as has been the case at every significant national vote since 1924.

The bill would allow the plebiscite to be held at any time between now and the next Federal election. This will provide the Parliament with the maximum flexibility to determine the appropriate timetable for the plebiscite. It would allow the election to be held in conjunction with the next federal election, if that was considered desirable for cost saving reasons.

The form of the question to be put at the plebiscite would be determined by a Joint Parliamentary Committee. We believe that the committee should consist of 6 members of the government, 4 from the Opposition, 1 from the Australian Democrats and 1 chosen from amongst the other minor parties and independents represented in the parliament. However, we are, of course, open to discussion on this issue.

The Joint Parliamentary Committee will be required to make its decisions by a two‐thirds majority. This will ensure that decisions of the committee are not dominated by the wishes of any one political party. It will ensure that, if decisions are made that they will be made on the basis of a broad consensus across the Parliament.

While a plebiscite, preceding a Constitutional Referendum, is the preferred course of action of both our parties, we remain open to any reasonable suggestions from the government, the minor parties or the independents that would enable debate on the Republic to proceed on a constructive basis.

It may well be that some useful ideas and suggestions for alternative processes will emerge from the deliberations of our proposed Joint Parliamentary Committee. That is why we have vested the committee with all the necessary powers to inquire into this matter and to make recommendations to the Parliament as to any alternate courses of action that should be adopted.
But these provisions are merely designed to ensure that Australians get a fair vote on this issue.

Should the Australian people vote at the plebiscite in favour of a Republic and in favour of making our Head of State an Australian, we would support a process to enable a detailed Republican model to be determined. Again, we believe this process should proceed on a consensus basis.

It may well be determined that the Joint Parliamentary Committee is the best body to undertake this process. If it is determined that it should undertake that role, then the committee should engage in wide‐ranging and representative consultations with the Australian people before reaching its conclusions.
Alternately, it would also be appropriate for a properly constituted People's Convention to consider this issue.

Ultimately, however, the issue of whether Australia becomes a Republic, with an Australian as our Head of State, can only be determined by the Australian people themselves in accordance with section 128 of the Constitution. This will require a referendum to be held on the preferred model for the Republic as determined by the Parliament as a whole.

The model proposed today is specifically designed to ensure the maximum degree of consultation with the Australian people at the beginning the middle and the end of the process. The model is also capable of delivering Australia a Republic, if that is the people's wish in time for either the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000 or by the centenary of Federation on 1 January 2001.
In comparison to this we have the attitude to date of the government on this issue.

While the government has said it remains committed to its election promise to hold a Constitutional Convention, it is clear from its insistence on an undemocratic and un‐Australian voting system that it is content to see the Convention delayed or scrapped, and the Republic debate put on the back‐burner.
But it is never too late for the government to take a constructive approach.

That is why the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have put forward this constructive proposal so that all Australians will be able to express their views, at every stage of the process, on this important issue.
We are committed to giving the Australian people a say. We call upon the government and all other members of the Parliament to match that commitment.

Whether or not the Republic is inevitable is a matter for genuine political debate. But no‐one in this Parliament can deny that the vast majority of Australians are ready and willing to decide whether they want Australia to become a Republic, whether they want an Australian as our Head of State.

We can, and should, take the politics out of this decision and hand it over to the Australian people. But unless we, as politicians, are genuinely willing to do so, we doom discussion of the Republic, or any other issue of constitutional reform, to failure.
We should get out of the way and design a process, that we can all agree on, that will allow the Australian people to decide. We urge the government to join us in this opportunity.
We commend this bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 10th report of the Joint Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the current inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Publications on the proposed discontinuation of the parliamentary papers series.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Standing Committee on Publications is conducting an inquiry into the possible discontinuation of the parliamentary papers series. The inquiry has been initiated in response to a request by the Presiding Officers, who wrote to the committee on 27 June 1996 seeking its advice on a proposal to discontinue the series. In order properly to consider the proposal, the committee sought information and views from interested parties. It has received 58 submissions and has conducted two public hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee received a useful submission from the Australian Government Publishing Service and took oral evidence from that organisation on 10 February 1997. Before the committee finalises its report, however, it will need to take additional evidence from the AGPS at a further public hearing. This evidence could cover matters such as the restructuring of the AGPS, its future role, its community service obligations and the revised Charter of printing and publishing responsibilities.

The committee had arranged to take this evidence on Thursday, 19 June, but an injunction was granted by the Federal Court in relation to the tender process for the sale of the AGPS. Given the resulting uncertainty about the future of the AGPS, the committee decided not to proceed with that hearing. It is understood that the court hearings on the matter are to commence on 30 June 1997. The outcome of the case will therefore not be known before the parliament has adjourned for the winter.

A significant issue to be considered by the committee is the administrative arrangements that will be established, after the sale of the AGPS, to ensure the distribution of parliamentary and executive government documents. Without the additional evidence from the AGPS, the committee is not now able to conclude its inquiry into the proposed discontinuation of the parliamentary papers series but will do so early in the spring session.

TITLE.XREF: TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT (PROHIBITION OF B‐PARTY CHARGING OF INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDERS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Telecommunications Act 1997 to prohibit B‐party charging of Internet service providers, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I table an explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Access to the Internet is of fundamental importance for consumers in the new communications environment. For this reason, the Australian Democrats believe the Internet should remain affordable to all.

As the scope of on‐line services grows, access to them will become an ever more pressing imperative. The Internet already offers a means for accessing information which is vital for enabling active participation in our society. For example, information on government services, policies and activities is readily available on‐line. In fact, the Internet is already proving one of the most effective and efficient means of obtaining such information. The projected growth of health and educational services will also contribute to the growth of the Internet as a critical tool for students and families.

The cost of accessing the Internet is therefore rapidly becoming a factor for an ever increasing number of families. In time, it is likely to become a cost that is virtually unavoidable—much like the telephone in our society.

The parliament, therefore, has a duty to ensure that access to the Internet remains affordable. Putting safeguards in place now is a way of ensuring that we do not create an information under‐class in the near future. That we do not wind up with a society divided into the information‐rich and the information‐poor.
Moreover, preserving low‐cost access to the Internet is also an important means of entrenching the dynamic growth in the industry.

Despite the efforts of the Democrats, under the Telecommunications Act 1997 (which comes into effect on 1 July 1997), business customers will not be guaranteed ongoing provision of untimed local calls for data. This means business users may be forced to accept timed charges for Internet and other data calls in the not too distant future. This decision, which rests with telecommunications carriers, would add significantly to the costs faced by small businesses and their consumers.

Fortunately, residential customers and charitable bodies and welfare organisations are guaranteed ongoing provision of untimed local voice and data calls. This means that these customers are able to connect to an Internet Service Provider in their local call zone, for the purpose of accessing the Internet, at the cost of an untimed call.

Telecommunications carriers, however, are not prohibited from charging Internet Service Providers a separate—timed—levy for receiving calls (known as B‐Party charging). This opens the way for all customers (including residential customers and charitable bodies or welfare organisations), to be indirectly charged on a timed basis for accessing the Internet.
The Democrats do not believe the imposition of such charges is warranted.

If Internet Service Providers are charged a timed levy for receiving a calls for the purposes of connecting to the Internet, they will be forced to pass these additional costs on to their customers, through increased fees. It could also be used by larger telecommunications companies to crush their competitors.

The Minister for Communications has said the government will not allow such B‐Party charging. This is a decision we welcome. Unfortunately, the government has not acted to rule out such charges in legislation.

The purpose of this bill, therefore, is to preserve the status quo by preventing carriers from charging the receiver of a telephone call where the receiver is the provider of an Internet service and where the call is for the purpose of connecting to the Internet. This practice, known as B‐party charging, is prohibited by this bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, I have the pleasure and honour of tabling the second report of the committee on its inquiry into the Australian legal aid system.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I recognise the assistance of the committee secretariat in the preparation of this report. In particular, I thank Mr Stephen Bull and Ms Helen Eastburn. Ms Eastburn was seconded to the committee from the Attorney-General's Department.

The legal aid inquiry was referred to the committee on 17 September 1996. Since that time, the committee has received 171 written submissions, has held public hearings in each capital city and tabled the first report on 26 March 1997. The committee noted in its first report that evidence to the inquiry focused on the government's decision to change the funding arrangements for legal aid.

This second report of the committee does three things. First, the report documents the further progress in the Commonwealth and state and territory negotiations. The committee understands that all state and territory governments, with the exception of Western Australian, have reached in principle agreements with the Commonwealth government. Two of these agreements—those with the Queensland and New South Wales governments—are reported to provide agency type arrangements rather than cooperative agreements. The committee intends to assess closely the terms of the final agreements when they are made public in order to satisfy itself that the arrangements are fair and equitable.

The second aspect of this report is to review further evidence given to the committee at public hearings in Sydney and Perth. At these hearings the committee heard from a broad spectrum of witnesses, including the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Western Australia, the Western Australian Attorney-General, the Public Defender of New South Wales, ATSIC, bar associations and law societies, ACOSS, legal aid commissions and public interest groups. The clear message to the government from these hearings is that its decision to change the legal aid system is a serious attack on the justice system and that the small initial savings could lead to far greater economic and social costs.

Thirdly, the committee addresses four specific terms of reference for the inquiry. In the first instance the report looks at the terms of reference No. 2—that is, the role and responsibility of governments and the profession in the provision of legal aid. A significant aspect of legal aid in Australia which is often overlooked or not known is that the Commonwealth government has taken a leading policy and funding role over the last 25 years or so. The legal profession provides a significant amount of free or reduced cost assistance to those in need of legal services. This contribution has been valued at $62 million per annum. The committee considers that this contribution by the profession should be recognised, and to this end the committee recommends the establishment of an annual award program for individuals and firms that undertake pro bono work.

The committee also heard evidence regarding the considerable scope for improving the provision of legal aid through systematic, innovative cooperative research and development work. The report records the committee's support for the establishment of a fund to coordinate and promulgate new initiatives for the provision of legal information, advice and education. In the committee's view, this fund could have considerable positive flow‐on effects.

Secondly, the report considers term of reference (3)(a): the impact of Australia's international obligations on legal aid assistance. Importantly, compliance with international obligations depends on results not procedures. The committee notes the Commonwealth government's clear intention to comply with the principles contained in its international obligations in relation to Com monwealth matters, including matters arising under Commonwealth laws giving effect to international obligations. This is a step in the right direction. However, it begs the question of whether the state and territory governments can attain the same level of compliance under the new proposed funding arrangements. The detail of and practice under the post 1 July 1997 agreements will be critical in determining the answer to this question.

The third issue considered in this report is term of reference (8): the implication for the legal aid system arising from the High Court Dietrich decision. As senators will know, the Dietrich decision established a principle that an indigent accused charged with a serious offence must be represented if he or she is to have a fair trial. If such an accused is not represented a stay of proceedings will be granted. This means that, in order for the trial of such an accused to proceed, representation must be provided at public expense. This in turn may lead to reduced funding being available for other legal services. The committee considers that it is essential for the Commonwealth government to monitor the implications of the Dietrich decision for legal aid funding.

BREAK.PARA: The fourth issue considered in the report was in term of reference (9): the capacity of the legal aid to provide for separate representation of children where such assistance is essential to the pursuit of justice. It was obvious to the committee from evidence provided to it that separate representation of children had been a source of increased cost to the Australian legal aid system, although it is suggested that these costs may have begun to plateau. The committee recommends that national guidelines be established by the government to ensure appropriate representation in the best interests of the child. It also recommends adequate funding to be made available to legal aid commissions for the provision of legal representation to children, having regard to the guidelines set down by the full court of the Family Court in Re K.

The evidence received in the committee's two reports on legal aid gives me great concern. I am concerned about the uncertain future of Australia's current cooperative legal aid system and that savings may well be illusory as cuts in Commonwealth funding may be offset by increased costs, delays and inefficiencies in the courts. I am also concerned that alternative, innovative efficiency measures are being ignored in the government's zeal to quarantine funding to Commonwealth matters only—a decision made more difficult in the light of all Australia's interests in the proper administration of justice. Events over the next month or two may demonstrate my concerns to be unfounded. I hope so.

The committee has agreed to continue the inquiry and to extend the terms of reference of the inquiry. This will enable the committee to monitor the legal aid system after the new funding arrangements become operational and to report on its outstanding terms of reference. I commend the report to the Senate and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Community Affairs References Committee relating to access to medical records in Australia, together with submissions and transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

The inquiry into access to medical records was referred to the Committee on 14 December 1996 after Senator Belinda Neal's proposal to amend the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, to incorporate access to medical records provisions, was unsuccessful.

The reference to the Committee was, among related issues, to inquire into a legislative access to medical records scheme to provide patients in the private health sector with a right of access to their medical records.

The background to the amendment concerned a patient's right of access to her doctor's notes. A test case, Breen v Williams in 1994, went to the NSW Court of Appeal. In 1996, the High Court of Australia confirmed that in the private health sector, the common law confirms ownership of records with the originator of the record.

While patients in the public health sector have access to their medical and other health records under the provisions of Freedom of Information legislation, patients in the private sector must rely upon the cooperation of medical practitioners and other health care providers to provide access to their records.

The High Court advised that if there was to be any change, it was for the Parliament to decide upon legislation which would ensure individuals' access to their medical records in the private health sector.
The aim of Senator Neal's proposal was to remove this anomaly, to provide access to medical records, and to ensure the privacy of medical and other health records.

During the course of the inquiry, the Committee received 60 submissions from parties with an interest in, or associated with, the provision of medical services and held two days of public hearings, receiving evidence from 20 organisations and 36 witnesses.

The major issues confronting the inquiry concerned access and privacy matters, including the scope of possible Commonwealth legislation, mechanisms to protect the interests of patients and third parties against potentially harmful disclosures, appropriate sanctions, exemptions to access, mechanisms for decision making and review of decisions with regard to exemptions, and provision for parliamentary scrutiny and oversight of arrangements.

The Committee recognised the extent and depth of community concern that patients and consumers in the private health care sector do not enjoy the same right of access to their medical and health records as do those in the public health sector.

The Committee notes that there is strong community and consumer support for a national legislative regime which would permit individuals' access to their medical and other health records in the public and private health sectors.

The Committee has focused in great measure upon privacy issues and considers that the extension of privacy legislation into the private health sector is essential to protect the confidentiality and accessibility of individuals' medical and other health records.
The Committee has also found that there is a need for a national legislative schedule to cover the storage, transfer and destruction of records.

The Committee recognises that there are constitutional limitations in the area of health and the need for consultation to reach agreement with the States and Territories for a national access to medical and other health records scheme.
The Committee's major recommendations are:

that the Commonwealth should initiate immediate discussions between all stakeholders in the States and Territories to enable the drafting and passage of legislation to ensure access to medical records for all individuals across the public and private health sectors;

that the Commonwealth should move expeditiously to draft legislation for national access to medical and other health records, and extended privacy legislation, to avoid the possibility of conflicting with State and Territory access to medical and other health records legislation being developed;
that national legislation will be prospective in its operation, except where matters of fact are concerned;
that for a national legislative scheme, a broad definition should be adopted to describe information and materials constituting an individual's medical or health record.

Health consumers have been calling for law reform and equity in access to medical records for over a decade. This inquiry has opened up the whole issue to public and parliamentary scrutiny and has provided a forum for a discussion of other closely related issues, including the need to protect the confidentiality and privacy of medical and other health records in the health sector.

This inquiry has presented a challenge to those who contend that the ownership of medical and other health records must continue; it has reviewed legislative access regimes in other countries, and it has produced constructive options for creating an Australian legislative regime.
The Committee supports the view that national legislation is essential to provide all Australians with a right, subject to specific exemptions, to access to their medical and other health records.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The access to medical records report, as the Senate may recall, was brought about by an amendment I moved to the health insurance amendment bill late last year. In fact I think it was in the last 24 hours before the Senate got up. I must confess that probably that amendment was not ideal in its terms, but it certainly did what I hoped it would do and that was to put the whole issue of access to medical records firmly on the agenda. It has done so through the Senate inquiry and the report that has been tabled today.

The report—and I would commend a quick read, or at least a flick through it—does a very good summary of the materials, discussion and issues that have been dealt with in the community in relation to this issue over the last few years. It clearly indicates that there is extraordinarily strong community support for continuing the process and providing a more open and accessible process whereby patients of doctors, and also of other health professionals, can obtain access to their medical records.

You may well recall that earlier this year, quite contrary to the views put during the election campaign, the coalition government and the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, indicated that, in fact, they did not intend to extend the privacy legislation. This extension would have included access to medical records, not only for the public sector as it is now, but also for the private sector. This announcement was greeted with a great deal of concern by those people in the community who had relied on the views put by the Prime Minister and other members of his government during the election campaign that certainly one of things they did intend to do was to make sure that access to medical records was available in the private sector.

It was also put by people during the debate that there was not a strong view in the community that access to medical records was required. You might note that the 60 submissions received by that committee were not only from a range of organisations involved in the health industry but also from individuals who had had difficulty with obtaining access to their records and, further, who had suffered adverse consequences as a result of that.

I also had contact with a number of people over the period—and I suppose I will continue to have contact with those people and with new people—who had had great difficulties with treatment that they had received and, firstly, had been unable to sort out what had occurred and, secondly, had been unable to resolve the health problems that they had because of the lack of information that had been provided about what had taken place.

I hope that the government will see fit as a result of this report to legislate to provide access to medical records and really create a true relationship of openness and trust between patients and doctors, and not allow the situation to continue as it is at the moment where doctors really are the guardians of knowledge and hand it out as they think fit. I do not mean to imply by that that all doctors are reluctant to give access to their records, but certainly there is a large proportion of medical practitioners who really feel that it is not in the best interests of patients in almost all cases to provide them with access.

It was argued earlier in the debate that the AMA guidelines that recommended that medical practitioners give access to their medical records was sufficient and it was not necessary to legislate to provide that access. But there are two points that I wish to make very strongly about that proposition. The first is that the AMA has only 50 per cent of the medical profession as members. Further, that the code, which is entirely voluntary, does not really suggest that access should be given directly. It says:
Where a doctor agrees to provide information to a patient from the contents of records concerning the patient's medical treatment:
(a) The patient should be informed of all relevant factual information contained in the record.
(b) However, the doctor's opinions and conclusions recorded in the medical record will be released only at the discretion of the doctor concerned.

So this voluntary code put forward by the AMA as a solution to the problem very clearly says that the relationship is such that the doctor himself or herself should control the release of those records and that it is not a right of the patient to see what is written about them.

My view is that there really cannot be proper health care unless patients are equal partners with their doctors in their treatment, are aware of all facts and are involved in all decisions about their health care. I believe this can only be achieved when they are entitled to see the information that is recorded about them.

In conclusion, I would like to thank very much the committee involved with this inquiry for their diligence and hard work. I would also particularly like to thank Sue Rickard in the committee secretariat who worked very hard on the report and has really produced a quality document. I understand she is leaving us now, going overseas and then returning to an academic lifestyle. Thank you, Sue Rickard.
I strongly commend the report to the Senate and ask that the government respond to the recommendations contained in there as a matter of priority and as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on the Regulation of computer on-line services—Part 3 , together with submissions.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on the Regulation of Computer On‐Line Services, Part 3.

The Committee conducted Part 3 of this inquiry in response to the rapid pace of change in computer on‐line services since it last looked at this issue in 1995. The inquiry revealed numerous important developments in the industry. These included not only daily increases in the number of Australian users of on‐line services but also an increase in the number and the degree of responsiveness of blocking and filtering software, the development of labelling protocols such as the Platform for Internet Content Selection (PICS) and rapid progress towards convergence of the technologies used by various media.

The Committee is recommending that governments introduce legislation to regulate the on‐line industry to ensure that material that cannot legally be distributed through other media should also not be distributed through on‐line services. In the Committee's view, the legislation should require participants in the on‐line services industry to develop codes of practice in consultation with government, other industry and users and to register those codes of practice with an appropriate body to be determined in the legislation. The Committee is also recommending that appropriate complaints handling procedures be put in place for the benefit of consumers. The Committee believes that failure to abide by the codes of practice should carry financial penalties.

The protection of minors from material that is not suitable for them is an important consideration and the Committee is greatly encouraged by the progress made in the area of blocking and filtering software in less than 2 years since Part 2 of its inquiry. However, parents need to be reminded that the software currently available will often block suitable as well as unsuitable material and that they cannot be relied upon to block out everything that a parent may wish to see blocked.

The Committee is therefore recommending that a public education campaign be conducted on the potential impact of computer on‐line technologies and the rights and responsibilities that they bring with them. The Committee has stressed the need for adequate age verification procedures to be put in place for the protection of minors from certain material now available on‐line.

The volume of material that is accessible through the use of computer on‐line services makes the detection of illegal material such as child pornography and paedophilic information, extremely difficult. The Committee believes it would assist both Internet Service Providers and law enforcement agencies if they could be informed, by users who find illegal material, of its location. To this end, the Committee is recommending the establishment of a phone, fax and e‐mail hotline where information about such material can be conveyed so that any follow‐up action can be taken if it proves to be needed.

In view of the global nature of the Internet , the Committee has reviewed the measures taken by various overseas countries to prevent the transmission of illegal material through the use of various computer on‐line services. Measures taken by national governments alone cannot be fully effective in addressing the problem. The Committee is therefore recommending that the federal government continue its efforts internationally to develop appropriate protocols to deal with those who use on‐line services to conduct criminal activities across national borders.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

Among its statutory duties, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities is required to inquire into the operation of the Corporations Law, or of other Australian or foreign laws that appear to significantly affect the operation of the Corporations Law.
In seeking to fulfil these responsibilities, the Committee has decided to undertake an inquiry into various aspects of the growth in electronic commerce.

Specifically, the Committee has decided to examine the implications for the Corporations Law, the Australian Securities Commission and securities exchanges of global electronic capital raising and share‐trading, with particular reference to:
a) the availability of prescribed information in electronic form;
b) the publication in electronic form of advice or rumours about shares;
c) electronic share hawking;
d) the need to recognise the changing roles and activities of participants in securities markets;
e) determining the legal, accounting and other rules that should govern electronic capital raising and share‐trading, including the international legal ramifications;
f) determining how rules might be enforced; and
g) ensuring the security of information provided electronically and transactions conducted electronically.

The Committee has undertaken some preliminary work to lay the foundations for this inquiry, and to clarify some of the issues that are likely to arise. This work has been prepared from a selection of public and news sources and is contained in the Issues Paper which I have just tabled.
