SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That regulation 4 of the Workplace Relations Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 101 and made under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, be disallowed.

I have been a politician now for just one year and I am learning fast that the rules in politics are very different from the rules of business, which is my background. In politics, as in business, I have known what it is to negotiate with tough people and to negotiate on a tough basis. When I first came across the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), I told him not to expect me to be a pushover because I had experience of the Afrikaner ministers in South Africa. He took that to heart. Nevertheless, the 60 hours invested by me and by Senator Kernot in improving the coalition government's original Workplace Relations Act and then giving it passage through this parliament were not easy; they were tough.

Those negotiations culminated in an agreement which was publicly released. I have it here, and you have seen it before. Nothing has been changed in that. It was signed off by the minister and my leader and it covered every detail of industrial relations law, line by line, comma by comma, including unfair dismissals. It even listed the matters we did not agree on.

In my business life I could have every expectation that an agreement, once struck, would be honoured. I am learning fast that that is not necessarily the case. Today I am in the reluctant position of having to move this disallowance motion in order to enforce the agreement between the government and the Australian Democrats and in order to overturn a breach of contract, a breach of an agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —A breach of faith.

—A breach of faith indeed. I oppose this regulation on policy grounds and I oppose it on political grounds. The regulation, if allowed to stand, would exempt an employee of businesses employing less than 15 employees from any redress if they believed they had been unfairly sacked during their first 12 months of employment. If Mr Reith comes through with his threat of introducing new legislation this afternoon, the exemption might be extended to all employees in small business. Make no mistake, that exemption aims to allow small business to sack employees unfairly. That is the purpose of it.

SPEECH.PARA: To allow the regulation to stand is to create two classes of workers: 1.6 million workers in small businesses who would have no right to challenge an unfair dismissal, and the 6.8 million workers who would. That is a fundamental breach of the government's election commitments to provide a fair go all round for employers and employees on unfair dismissals. Where is the fair go in saying to 1.6 million workers, nearly a quarter of the work force, `The fair go all round does not extend to you. Your employer can be as harsh, as unjust and as unfair as they like and, so long as their actions are still lawful, you can't question it because if you do they can sack you without penalty'?

We have heard a lot of noise from ministers about mandates. The minister should check what he told the Australian electorate during the election campaign. During the election campaign, Mr Reith publicly and explicitly rejected the very proposal that he is now seeking to implement. I refer senators to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 February 1996 entitled `Small business fails with plea on sacking law'. This article describes how a COSBOA pitch to have an exemption in coalition policy was rejected by Minister Reith. In part, it says:
The author of the policy, the Opposition's industrial relations spokesman, Mr Peter Reith, said the redrafted system would not contain any exemptions.
I wish to table this article, if I may, so that it is available to all senators.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Nor was the proposal included in the drafting of the original Workplace Relations Act. I want to make that clear: it was not included in the original Workplace Relations Act. There is no mention of the proposal in there. It was not even seriously pursued by the minister in the negotiations with me and Senator Kernot, other than in a half‐hearted way, very late at night, at one of our last meetings.

SPEECH.PARA: Most importantly, it was not listed within the agreement as one of the matters reserved by the parties as not agreed. We specifically produced a list of items where we said what we did agree with and what we did not agree with. It was not listed. The agreement document, signed by the minister, covered all aspects of the policy, agreed and disagreed. That is why this issue is also about breach of promise, breach of trust, breach of contract and breach of agreement. Today we are being asked by the minister to allow the implementation of a policy that he has twice flatly rejected, on spurious policy grounds, and in breach of an agreement which I take seriously.

One cannot help but wonder whether this regulation was drafted simply in frustration with the hairy‐chested right within the Liberal Party, led by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who has privately bagged the Democrat‐government agreement from day one. The succession rivalry between those two ministers is plain for all to see, with no sign of slowing down—the latest round being reported only yesterday in the newspapers. Perhaps the Treasurer's line about IR was winning within the all‐important Liberal caucus and this really is about internal Liberal politics, not about small business and certainly not about jobs. This is not positive, constructive, cooperative workplace relations. In my view, it will be sanctioning employer thuggery.

This motion seeks to disallow regulations issued in April under the Workplace Relations Act. The regulation would exempt an employ ee of businesses employing less than 15 employees from the right to apply for redress for unfair dismissal unless the employee has more than 12 months service.

The Democrats strongly oppose this regulation and would urge all senators to join us in seeking to have it disallowed. We oppose the regulation because it is not fair to strip up to 1.6 million workers of the right to question an unfair dismissal, simply because of the size of the employer. It is not fair to allow employers to sack employees unfairly.

First, it is a fundamental breach of the government's election commitments. Second, during the election campaign, the coalition was asked by the Council of Small Business Organisations, as I have mentioned already, to exempt small business employers from unfair dismissal. Peter Reith ruled it out. When we finished the agreement we thought this was a dead issue.

It came to life after Peter Costello and the right wing of the Liberal Party and some employers started criticising Minister Reith's bill as not going far enough. It became an issue only when our much diminished Prime Minister (Mr Howard), shopping around for some diversion to take the heat off this government's appalling record on unemployment, seized on it. Then, stomping over clear election commitments, stomping over the agreement with the Democrats, stomping over the recommendation of their own Small Business Deregulation Taskforce, they brought down this regulation.

Which leads me to my third reason for opposing this regulation. It will not create one single extra job. Even under Laurie Brereton's unfair dismissal laws, the argument that small business employment was being seriously hampered was always nebulous. In 1994‐95, small business, the small business work force, grew by 6.4 per cent, compared with 3.9 per cent for the work force as a whole.
I would like to draw your attention, Senators, to the fair trading inquiry report, unanimously signed by coalition and Labor members. I draw your attention to page 2, item 1.8:

BREAK.PARA: . in the decade to 1994‐95, the small business sector accounted for almost all the 1.2 million net increase in jobs, increasing its workforce by an estimated 1.1 million compared to 270 000 for large business and a decline in public sector employment of 150 000.
. in 1994‐5 (the latest year for which data is available) the small business workforce increased by 6.4 per cent, compared with 3.9 per cent for total employment; and
. small businesses accounted for almost half of total employment in 1994‐95.

Come on, that was under the laws that you claimed were restricting employment growth. That was under the laws that you condemned, and they grew at twice the level of large business. So don't tell me that under the reformed Workplace Relations Act you have a problem with jobs growth in small business. Your problem is your policies, not the laws.

According to the Yellow Pages Small Business Index, the number of small businesses expecting to put on workers exceeded the number expecting to put them off by 10 to 15 per cent right through to January 1996, but since then, since the Howard government came into power, confidence has plummeted, and only five per cent of firms now expect to employ more. You are not delivering the conditions under which people will employ more.

So what are the factors that would cause small businesses to employ more? If you believe the Prime Minister, who in a fit of political senility even forgot he had changed the unfair dismissals laws in his new act, the second we get these unfair dismissal laws fixed, each of the 800,000 small business in Australia will immediately set out to employ one each of the 800,000 unemployed Australians. That is not going to happen.

Yellow Pages last month looked at the primary concerns of small business, and guess what: `regulations' was pretty low down the list, even after all the Reith‐Howard propaganda, marked by only seven per cent of the firms. The big issues were lack of work, lack of sales, low cash flow, consumer confidence and competition and fair trading laws. Yet you are busy defending the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser)—the minister for landlords—who will not introduce the fair trading laws that are necessary.

A similar result was evident in an earlier survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry of its members on ways to raise employment. In that survey, changing unfair dismissal laws ranked seventh out of a list of eight items. Both surveys showed that to create jobs, there is no substitute, no diversion, no smokescreen, that can replace good, sound, forward thinking, confidence boosting economic and small business policy. And small business, big business, the community, manufacturers—let's tick them off—are not getting it from this government.

Only 22 per cent of small businesses predicted that the government great More time for business statement, of which this unfair dismissal change was the centrepiece, would improve their situation. Sixty‐six per cent, three times as many, said it would make no difference or make things worse. That is hardly a ringing endorsement, especially from a sector which would prefer no laws at all, because they do not want any regulations.

And small business groups have hardly been falling over themselves to endorse it. The Motor Trades Association represents 40,000 small businesses—unlike the ACCI, which is a big business organisation with small business members. The MTA, employing over 275,000 workers, made it quite clear that it regarded reform of fair trading laws as the far more important issue, describing it as the crucial test of the government's commitment to generating jobs in small business. The Pharmacy Guild, which is entirely small business, backed up those comments.

The 10,000‐member Australian Retailers Association has run a similar line, arguing that reform of retail tenancy laws—a major aspect of fair trading—was the single most important issue facing their sector. In a letter to the Prime Minister, the association pointed out that occupancy costs now exceed labour costs and that freeing up the tenancy market would massively benefit the industry.

There is no doubt that beefing up the Trade Practices Act to enforce fair trading standards, ensuring small business has a fair go in competition with big business, would be of far greater benefit than changes to unfair dismissals. Indeed, the government now has recommendations before it to that effect—unanimous recommendations—from the House of Representatives inquiry into fair trading, an inquiry dominated by coalition members.

While Mr Prosser is minister for small business—or rather, minister for landlords—I am not holding my breath waiting for the government to fix the problem of fair trading. Mr Prosser, a major shopping centre owner, has made clear his firm preference for self-regulation on fair trading—it is after all in his self‐interest—despite and probably because of clear evidence that self‐regulation does not work. And it would take a `road to Damascus' conversion or a prime ministerial overruling to change the view of the minister for landlords.

This regulation—part of the government's response to the November report of the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce, which was headed up by the coalition‐appointed Charlie Bell—is actually completely contrary to the task force recommendation. That task force, while not reporting on fair trading, noted that the largest number of submissions it received were in regard to that issue. That task force found that, following the passage of the Workplace Relations Act, small business was `cautiously optimistic about the government's approach to amend the unfair dismissal laws'.

The task force did not recommend an exemption for small business from unfair dismissal. Have you got that? The task force, set up by you, did not recommend that. They recommended that the operation of the law be reviewed after 12 months to ensure that it is delivering a more balanced and flexible approach to small business. No-one in this chamber would object to a review of that kind, because we are interested in seeing what the facts are.

The Democrats have endorsed that recommendation. The Labor Party has endorsed that recommendation. It is the government that has rejected the recommendation of its own task force in bringing forward this regulation, while dragging the chain on the real issues concerning small business like fair trading laws.

So why is small business cautiously optimistic about the new laws? It is because the Workplace Relations Act fixed the unfair dismissal problem. Based on the minister's statistics, the number of unfair dismissal claims dropped by over half, by over 56 per cent. This regulation is trying to fix a non-existent problem about jobs and unfair dismissals and is trying to fix a very real problem between Minister Reith and Minister Costello about who can contest for the Prime Minister's seat.

Let me briefly outline the provisions in the Workplace Relations Act which deal with unfair dismissals and changes we made. Mr Brereton's law put the onus on the employer to show that they had a valid reason to dismiss an employee. Mr Reith's law reverses the onus, requiring an employee to show just how a dismissal was unfair or unjust. Mr Brereton's laws required litigation through the Federal Court, adding to time lines and costs. Mr Reith's laws are dealt with entirely through the AIRC—a faster and cheaper process. Mr Brereton's laws provided no protection for employers against vexatious or frivolous claims by former employees. Mr Reith's laws allow costs to be awarded against workers who pursue vexatious claims.

Mr Brereton's laws had mandatory rules about procedures that had to be followed. Mr Reith's laws do not but require all relevant circumstances to be taken into account. Mr Reith's laws require the commission to take into account the viability of the employer before awarding compensation. Mr Reith's laws extend the exception for probationary employees out to three months, giving employers a fair period, a long period, to determine whether an employee is going to work out. Three months is quite sufficient in a small business to work that out. Mr Reith's laws extend the qualifying period for casual employees out to 12 months before they are eligible to apply for unfair dismissal. They exclude employees who are terminated in accordance with a specified term contract.

All of these changes together—in the view of the government and supported by the Australian Democrats—were pro‐small business. We thought they corrected the overly pro‐union, pro‐worker bias in former minister Laurie Brereton's old laws. But we are not going to go the next step, which is to say that you can sack workers unfairly. That is what this is about—the right to sack workers unfairly.

The new workplace relations laws were predicated on the belief that they would deliver a fair go all round. We accepted that in good faith. We are holding to our side of the agreement but you, I am afraid, are trying to break an agreement, break our trust and break a contract that you have with the Australian people on this matter.

Those laws are pro‐employment. They are sensible and workable and should be given a chance. To simply say to 1.6 million workers `No, you can't have access to those laws because you are employed by a small business' is to perpetrate a gross injustice. I think ultimately your regulation would be to the detriment of small business. Knowing employees can be sacked without good cause would encourage sloppy management practices, which would lead to lower worker morale, lower productivity and poorer standards. It could lead to higher wage costs for small business, as employees would baulk at working for one employer when there is no legal protection. It would encourage unions to be extremely aggressive on the small business front. Most importantly, even if this regulation did get up, it still would not disguise the fact that small business is unable to put on employees because of the weakness in the Australian economy and the unfairness of competition against big business.

What precedent would it create to say, `We will strip workers' rights to prop up small business'? It could be the dismissal laws this year; it could be the superannuation guarantee payment next year; it could be an exemption from the award safety net the year after. The arguments are exactly the same: to discriminate against employees on the basis of the size of their employer is utterly and complete ly unfair. It is unfair, counterproductive and insupportable. Therefore, we commend the disallowance of this regulation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will be supporting the disallowance of the regulations that are before the Senate. When listening to Senator Murray I could not help but reflect on the very lengthy debate that occurred in this chamber last year and the contributions of both me and my colleagues, particularly Senator Collins and Senator Mackay, and others who participated in that debate. I think, Senator Murray, you should cast your mind back and certainly read the warnings that we gave on that occasion about what we believed would be the slow, gradual attempt of this Liberal government to strangle the rights of workers in this country. The regulations that we are, I hope, going to disallow today are a continuing attempt by the Liberal government to strangle the rights of workers in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I only hope that when you commenced your remarks today, Senator Murray, you did reflect on your past year's experience and the dishonesty and the breaches of faith which you have referred to in respect of the agreement that you reached on that occasion with Minister Reith and the Liberal government. I only hope that you are a good deal more sceptical in future about such arrangements.

In dealing with the issue before the Senate today I will reflect very briefly on the Labor government's provisions with respect to unfair dismissals. Labor believed that unfair dismissal provisions should apply to all employers irrespective of their size. Labor did, however, have an exclusion in respect of a number of classes of employees. These included employ ees serving a probationary period, provided the period was determined in advance and was reasonable and having regard to the nature and circumstances of employment.

The Liberals' unfair dismissal provisions, as provided by the Workplace Relations Act, which we debated for some two weeks last year—I think it was the second longest debate in recent history in the Senate chamber, and this issue was certainly considered very extensively—applied to all employers irrespective of their size. The provisions did, however, exclude a number of classes of employees, including employees serving a probationary period provided the period was determined in advance and the period was either three months or more than three months and was reasonable having regard to the nature and circumstances of employment.

The Liberals' new small business exemption regulations will, I hope, be prevented as a consequence of this debate in the Senate today. The small business regulation, as tabled in the Senate, will exempt small business employers from the unfair dismissal provisions but only for certain employees. The unfair dismissal provisions will not apply to employees where: the employer's undertaking employs no more than 15 employees; the employee was first employed by that employer on or after 1 July 1997; or the employee has been employed by the employer for more than three months or on a regular and systematic basis for a sequence of periods of employment during a period of more than 12 months. In other words, the regulations effectively create a 12‐month probationary period for new employees of small business.

What has been Minister Reith's response to our attempts to overturn the regulations that we are considering in the Senate today? Minister Reith, on behalf of the Liberals, has threatened a wider small business exemption if we overturn these regulations today. He has threatened that, in the case of small business, there will be an exemption for small business employers from the unfair dismissal provisions in respect of all employees in all circumstances. Put simply, the unfair dismissal provisions would not apply to employers who employ more than 15 employees. In other words, if you are employed by a small business employer who employs fewer than 15 employees, you have no rights. That is fundamentally unacceptable to the Labor Party—to take away any right of an employee because they work for a small business.

I would like to touch on the arguments against the small business exemption regulation that is being tabled in the Senate. Firstly, as I have already noted—and as we have already considered in a very lengthy debate last year—the government has already changed the unfair dismissal laws. The unfair dismissal laws were extensively amended by the government's Workplace Relations Act and those changes came into effect on 1 January this year. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Minister Reith have been praising their own new laws. Mr Reith said:

The government is replacing Labor's arrangements with a new unfair dismissal scheme—a system which provides employees with access to a fair and simple process of appeal against dismissal, based on the principle of a fair go all round. It is a scheme that . . . ensures legalism is minimised, while discouraging frivolous and malicious claims.
The Prime Minister said:
I am proud to say that the previous government's . . . unfair dismissal laws have gone. They have been replaced with a simpler, more balanced system that provides a fair go all round.
And, on another occasion, he said:
We have swept away Labor's . . . unfair dismissal laws.

He said, `We have swept them away.' What are we doing in the Senate today, if they have been swept away? The evidence so far has shown that changing the unfair dismissal laws has not improved employment. ABS statistics show that since January 1997 in Victoria—and we look at Victoria because that is a state where the new unfair dismissal laws, so heralded by Minister Reith and the Prime Minister, apply to all employees—employment trends have been negative since January 1997. In the very month in which these new unfair dismissal laws, so much hailed by Minister Reith and the Prime Minister, came into effect, unemployment went up in Victoria. Employment in Victoria took a nosedive. Employment growth in Victoria decreased by 100 in February, 600 in March, 1,200 in April and it has been accelerating. As a consequence of the Liberals' new unfair dismissal laws, unemployment has been accelerating.

Secondly, the proposal creates an exemption to the government's own unfair dismissal laws. The proposal will exempt small business from the operation of the government's own unfair dismissal laws, not Labor's. The proposal is inconsistent with the government's strong support for its own unfair dismissal laws that I referred to earlier.

Thirdly, the government's unfair dismissal laws should be given a chance to operate—although, on current evidence, they are in fact doing exactly the opposite to what was predicted. These laws have only been in operation for five months. They should be given a chance to operate. Minister Reith says that his other industrial relations reforms should be given time to work. What is different about unfair dismissals? The government's unfair dismissal laws already provide a probationary period for new employees, and I have referred to this probationary period in my earlier comments.

Fourthly, the proposed exemption is inconsistent with the recommendation of the Bell report. The Bell report only recommended that Minister Reith's new unfair dismissal provisions be reviewed after 12 months of operation. They did not make a recommendation for any exemption for small business.

The proposed exemption is inconsistent with the government's pre‐election guarantees—not that that has been a problem in respect of a whole range of other broken promises and so-called non‐core promises that have been breached by this government since it was elected. At no time prior to the election did the Liberals foreshadow an exemption from unfair dismissal laws for small business. In fact, a small business exemption was ruled out. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 February 1996, then shadow minister Mr Reith stated:

The Coalition has flatly ruled out any exemption for small business in its redrafted unfair dismissal laws, despite a plea that the sector should not be subject to the same treatment as `the big end of town' . . . The author of the policy, the Opposition's industrial relations spokesman, Mr Peter Reith, said the redrafted system would not contain any exemptions.
On 28 February 1996 the now minister, Mr Reith, stated:
Look, our position's very clear. If you've been unfairly dealt with at work, then you should have a right of appeal.
The now Prime Minister, Mr Howard, said on the John Laws show on 23 January 1996:

BREAK.PARA: I'm not going to have a law where an unreasonable employer can capriciously sack a decent, hard‐working employee.
That is exactly the sort of proposition that we are attempting to prevent. Mr Howard also stated:
I'm not going to make it open slather. I'm going to replace it with a law that's fair to both sides so that if you are doing your job properly you can't be capriciously dismissed.
Mr Howard stated in a speech to the South Australia Chamber of Commerce and Industry:
I'm not going to leave employees exposed to unfair dismissal by capricious employers.
He also stated:
We're not going to replace (Labor's unfair dismissal laws) with a law that gives ruthless employers carte blanche.
Mr Howard again stated:

Let me make a hard and fast commitment that when we win government we will ensure that Australian has a balanced unfair dismissal provision which is fair to both employers and employees. We won't tolerate unreasonable dismissals.

That was Mr Howard at his honest best as we all recall before the last election. If we look at the definitive document of the Liberal Party in its approach to the election—that well known pre‐election policy document; the non‐core and core promises document that has been so often breached—it states:
The Coalition believes that employees should have access to a fair and simple process of appeal against dismissal—based on the principle of a `Fair Go All Around'.

The proposal that the Liberals have advanced in these regulations will only add to job insecurity—one of the most important issues before the Australian community and before Australian workers today. It will add to job insecurity. Many workers now protected against being unfairly dismissed will lose that protection. Their employment will be far less secure. The government admitted this during recent estimates hearings. My colleague Senator Collins posed a question to Mr Anderson, the Director of the Legal Services Group in the Department of Industrial Relations. Senator Collins asked:

Does the department accept that if the proposed small business exemption regulation presently tabled in the Senate becomes law then some employees presently able to seek relief against harsh, unjust or unreasonable termination will no longer be able to do so?
`Yes' was the simple, succinct, open, honest and appalling reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it gets worse.

—You are right, Senator Collins, it gets worse. The proposal does not distinguish between unfair dismissal claims on the basis of the merits of the case. To the contrary, the proposal merely distinguishes between claims on the basis of the size of the employer. If you work for a large employer you have human rights. If you work for a small employer you do not have human rights. It is a fascinating new principle that the Liberals are establishing.
—Oh, is it?

—Senator Alston, you know nothing about industrial relations or what it is like to struggle on the workplace floor. The concept is that if you work for a small employer you have no human rights and if you work for a large employer you have human rights. It is the fascinating new Liberal principle. Senator Alston, find this new Liberal principle in the coalition's election promises that you went to election with. Find this fascinating new principle in what Minister Reith and Prime Minister John Howard have said over the last year.

BREAK.PARA: This proposal is fundamentally unfair to employees. The small business exemption will discriminate against employees who work in small business. They do not have protection against unfair dismissals whereas employees in bigger establishments do. The proposal is fundamentally unfair to decent employers who do the right thing. Labor acknowledges that the vast majority of employers do the right thing. Why should they have to compete with shonky operators who can misuse the new exemption they will have. Numerous examples have been brought to the parliament's attention in recent times by my colleague the shadow minister Mr McMullan. He has produced numerous examples, much to the embarrassment of Minister Reith and the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, that they have been unable to refute.

Small business has fewer unfair dismissal claims than other employers. Statistics from the 1995-96 Industrial Relations Court annual report show that small business has fewer unfair dismissal claims than other employers. The unfair dismissal filing rate is slightly under two per cent of all monthly involuntary terminations. Only one‐third of this figure is from the small business sector, notwithstanding that 91.7 per cent of employers have fewer than 20 employees.

The next point that I would like to make is that the proposal may be a disincentive to small business. The proposal may actually discourage small business from taking on new employees beyond the total staff of 15. And why is there this magic number of 15? Why should an employer with, say, 14 employees take on new employees if it means unfair dismissal laws will then apply? The proposal may encourage artificial employment arrangements. A business with 30 employees would be better off setting up two separate companies employing 15 employees each, thereby escaping the unfair dismissal laws. This will add to the complexity; it will not make doing business simpler.

Finally, unfair dismissals are not a high priority for small business. In surveys of small business, unfair dismissal, if it was an issue, ranked very low or not at all. For example, in the May 1997 Yellow Pages Small Business Index, unfair dismissal laws do not rate as a prime concern of small businesses, whereas lack of sales is a concern for 21 per cent of small businesses. That is what the small business community wants—a return to some consumer confidence. That confidence is sadly lacking; it has been wrecked as a result of the last two Liberal budgets.

Only three per cent of small businesses regard the cost of employing—which includes the impact of unfair dismissal laws—as a barrier to entry, whereas 32 per cent regard the lack of cash flow as a barrier and 23 per cent regard lack of work as a barrier. Only 15 per cent of small businesses are even aware of the government's proposed unfair dismissal exemptions and, of those, only one in five believe the initiative will improve the situation for small business.

An earlier ACCI survey ranked dismissal laws as a distant seventh out of eight as the main impediment to employment, well behind lack of sales, a weak economy and profitability. They are the critical issues that face small business—and big business for that matter—in today's economy.

The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants Small Business Health Index stated that almost 60 per cent of small businesses surveyed considered that John Howard's response to the Bell report would not help them. I suspect the only change to this survey of small business concerns would be that today the No. 1, and probably the No. 2, concern of small business is the performance of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser. I suspect that is the only change.

In concluding my contribution on behalf of the Labor Party to this debate, let me say that there is no good reason that can be advanced for changing the treatment of employees regarding small business and unfair dismissal. There is no good reason that has been advanced by the government; in fact, it is all to the contrary. This debate has shown the gross dishonesty of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, and of particularly the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, whom I have quoted here today, both before and since the election on this fundamental issue. And Labor believes it is a fundamental issue that employees, whether they work for small or big business, have a fundamental right to be protected in the event of harsh, unfair and unjust dismissal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, a contract under law normally is meant to be binding for two parties. There are conditions under which people sign up and, one would assume, under some sort of legal contract—and certainly one that has been registered— there is an assumption that both sides will be required to keep to the terms of the contract. That is, if each party observes their side of the contract, then that contract is binding.

SPEECH.PARA: Isn't it interesting that the government here seems to be saying, `No, the contract is only one‐sided'? The employee has to abide by their side of the contract, but the government is really keen to see that the employer does not have to do so. The government says that, if an employer, for unfair reasons, dismisses somebody, that is okay—even if that person has in fact abided by all that is required of them under their contract of employment.

People will know that it was not the Greens (WA) who pushed for individual contracts and that it was not the Greens (WA) who pushed for workplace agreements. Workplace agreements came up under the previous Labor government, but we have moved more and more towards individual contracts. This was the coalition government's entire strategy on employment creation, but it has not worked. But, when something has not been working, instead of looking at what is going wrong with their employment or lack of employment strategies, they decided to try again with what did not work the first time.

In the workplace relations bill, under unfair dismissal, we know there was an agreement between the Australian Democrats and the government to further limit the rights of workers. That was going to be the saviour of employment in Australia, but that did not work. But why should a further racheting down of workers' rights work any better? I am pleased to see that the Australian Democrats have realised that things may have gone too far and that, instead of the government saying, `We will try this, and this is what everybody wants', and then realising it was not the answer, saying, `Let's try it a bit more'.

I know I have said this before but, ironically, it is things such as consumer confidence, as Senator Sherry said, that have more impact on the current situation with small business than such things as whether workers' rights can be removed so that they can be sacked unfairly. It is about whether or not people feel that they can spend some of their discretionary income—that is, that income that is above the minimum income for things such as rent, a mortgage or food, the basic necessities of life. So it is that discretionary income that people hold back—if they have any, that is, when you consider the growing number of working poor in Australia—when they are uncertain about their future, when they are not sure whether they will be thrown on the unemployment heap. That will have more of an impact on small business than anything the coalition government is putting up.

We have to look at integrated policies. We have to look at what is causing structural unemployment. We have to look at the kinds of business and corporate decisions and directions and policy decisions that are causing structural unemployment in this country. Instead of dealing with that, once again we are pointing to those people who are most affected by these decisions, and we are saying, `If only business could be allowed to treat employees more unfairly', and, `If only you would let us make sure that contracts are not binding for employers but are binding only for employees, then things would be okay.'

How do you expect people to have faith in this system? Yesterday we heard Senator Newman talking about the necessity for people to have faith in the social security system. Just to make sure, she had thrown off 80,000 people who, in many cases, have no means of support. I know—those people come into my office. And I know that other people feel the same thing—people who have been unfairly thrown off for reasons of filling out the wrong form or for some reason they did not know about. They then have to go back and fight their case. You are prepared to do that—to create uncertainty for people who have no other means of support, to create greater fear and uncertainty amongst those people with the least bargaining power in our workplace. And now you are suggesting that this is the answer, `Let's take it a ratchet further.' I do not believe it is the answer and I for one will not be supporting the government's move to do so. I will be supporting the disallowance move today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot said in this debate about the rights of various individuals and the extent to which there has been a breach of an agreement or whether indeed this is about leadership rivalries. One thing we have not really heard is the extent to which small business actually wants to be freed from these shackles. I know where Senator Sherry is coming from: he is simply reflecting the rights of the ALP and the ACTU nexus. He has clearly been given his riding instructions, and he is carrying those out. Back in early May this year, the shadow minister for small business, Mr Martin, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect there is a lot of political heat that might be generated against us should we take a negative view on this particular issue.
So the Labor Party knows that this regulation is a good compromise, a good deal for small business and a bonus for jobs. Even Senator Cook said in March this year:
We won't be trying to block the bill in the Senate, but I think there needs to be a lot more work on it.
In other words, they know that small business wants this. They simply do not want it because they are not allowed to; their master's voice will not allow them to have it.

Senator Sherry talks about strangling the rights of workers. As we know, workers' rights is a mantra used to disguise the fact that often the self-interest of a particular peak council is put ahead of the rights of the unemployed. That is really what this is all about. This is providing an opportunity for small business not to be strangled in red tape. You have to go into intensive counselling exercises; you have got to caution people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! You have got no proof for that. This is rubbish.

—You have seen the horror stories. You have seen small busines ses, single employers, who find themselves dragged off to the Industrial Relations Commission, who are terrified at the prospect of being dragged through the courts, of being ordered to pay damages for all sorts of specious reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not in the business of depriving workers of their legitimate rights. The Workplace Relations Act will protect workers against dismissal for discriminatory reasons. They will be protected against dismissal because of protected industrial action. They will be protected against dismissal involving victimisation or matters otherwise contrary to the principles of freedom of association. And they will be protected against dismissal without notice or pay in lieu, except in cases of serious misconduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the other areas?
—I know how excited some people get because their preselections depend on it, but we know that the die is cast on this set of regulations.
—I have worked in unfair dismissals for years, Minister.

—I am delighted that you made a living out of it, and you are very disappointed at the prospect of that disappearing. I can understand why you feel personally threatened by it. We are more interested in the rights of small business than small businesses like you who—
—Small business does not want it. You have got no evidence, no evidence at all.
—Senator Collins, I think Senator Alston should be allowed to proceed.
—Senator Collins, that is interesting. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry have welcomed the government's regulation, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It would directly address the evidence in surveys of business views on unfair dismissal legislation that these legislative requirements adversely affect employers' decisions to employ.

I have not heard anyone get up and quote examples of small businesses themselves saying that they did not want these regulations to go ahead. The fact is that small business does want it and simply because there has been a growth in the number of jobs in the small business sector does not in any shape or form mean that you would get even more increase in jobs if you did not have these unfair dismissal provisions.

The fact is that small business has always been the jobs generator. We know that that is the experience around the world. We know that that is where it is crucially a factor in reducing unemployment. You are not interested in doing that. Small business has been traumatised by the Brereton legislation. It continues to have an aversion to employing new staff because of the carryover effects of that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you are talking about.

—This is a major issue in small business. You are seeing through the prism of the union movement, who rely on these things to so-called protect workers' rights, to be able to justify your existence. But the very reason that small business does not want to belong to trade unions is that they know that you are not acting in their interests at all. People are leaving the union movement in droves because they do not want to be strangled. They want people who are in favour of enabling them to expand their businesses. The fact is that this type of restriction simply does not allow for that. The regulation is pro jobs and pro small business. The opposition and the Democrats make it very clear that their priorities lie elsewhere. The exclusion would not lead to automatic and arbitrary sackings. Firing, hiring and training staff costs money, and small businesses will not incur unnecessary costs by turning over employees without any reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to prolong the debate, because I think we all know where it is going. I wanted to address one issue. Senator Sherry said about three times that there was some new Liberal principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Choice. That is what it is all about.

—No, what you said was that we have a human rights approach for large business, but there is no human rights approach for small business. Let me refer you very briefly to the Employment Protection Act 1982, New South Wales, introduced by the Wran government, which had an exclusion for employers with fewer than 15 employees. These employees did not have to provide official notice of intention to terminate and they were not subject to severance pay orders under that act. The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 introduced by the Hawke government excluded from its operation—
—And then what happened? They were dropped back again.
—You start off by arguing that somehow there is a new Liberal principle and you are arguing that we should not discriminate—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, I think we should allow Senator Alston to proceed, and I would appreciate it, Senator Alston, if you did.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. The essential argument was that we are discriminating by having special arrangements for small business. I am simply saying that, in both of those instances, the Wran government and the Hawke government introduced legislation that provided special arrangements for smaller businesses. In that second instance, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, acknowledged that small business did not have the capacity to undertake the full import of that legislation.
—You are being very selective, Minister.
—You make the general statement; I am simply responding to it. I do not want to take any more of the Senate's time on what is clearly a fruitless exercise.
—Senator Murray, do you wish the right of reply?
—I am not going to exercise it. I think we have heard enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report by 31 August 1997:
(1) The fairness of the recent settlement offered by the Commonwealth Government to recipients of human pituitary hormones, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a) whether the Government's response to the Allars Inquiry recommendations has been fair and adequate;
(b) whether the Government refused to make certain relevant documents related to the inquiry available to recipients;
(c) whether the Commonwealth's offer to the recipients was fair and adequate and gave recipients sufficient time and information to make a considered response; and
(d) whether legal aid has been unfairly denied to the recipients, placing them under more pressure to accept the Commonwealth's offer of settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Whether the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory (CSL) or CSL Ltd, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Department of Health and Family Services or any other Commonwealth department, agency or employee failed to adequately protect public safety in relation to the Australian Human Pituitary Hormone Program.

This motion is in two parts. At the outset, I wish to acknowledge the provision of some useful background material from Mr Lee's office and also Senator Herron's office. If this motion is passed, the two issues for review by the Community Affairs References Committee relate, firstly, to the fairness of recent settlements offered by the Commonwealth government to recipients of human pituitary hormones; and, secondly, whether a range of departments and agencies, including CSL, the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Department of Health and Family Services, have failed to adequately protect public safety.

This is a much vexed issue. It has been in the public domain for many, many years. Significant concerns have been expressed by members of the public in the last five or 10 years. Its background is on the public record and may be summarised as follows.

CSL was established by the Commonwealth government in 1916 to help meet the needs of an isolated nation at war. In 1964 CSL became involved in the preparation of hormones derived from pituitary glands at the time of autopsy. Between 1965 and 1985, 170,000 pituitary glands were collected by CSL. A total of 2,100 people received pituitary hormone treatment: 1,400 for infertility, and 700 for short stature.

In 1971 the issue of danger from unconventional slow viral infections transmitted by hormones from collected glands was first raised in the public domain. The first case of person to person transmission of Creutzfeld-Jakob disease was not reported, I am advised, until 1974. CJD is a rare and fatal brain disease. The program initiated by CSL was suspended in 1985, and collection of the glands ceased in 1986.

I am advised that, as at August 1995, five cases of CJD had been reported. CJD continues to occur on a sporadic basis. The average incubation time is something in the order of 12 to 15 years. Recent suggestions in a range of public forums have extended that period now to 25 to 30 years. In May 1993 the previous government commissioned a report conducted by Professor Allars, a law professor at the University of Sydney.

I am advised that a large number of claims are still outstanding in the Victorian Supreme Court, and there has been no progression of those claims since their lodgment in the registry. Those claims are novel because none of the claimants have contracted the disease. This directly relates, of course, to the lengthy incubation period of some 25 to 30 years.

In the follow-up to the Allars report, concerning the implementation of recommendations, the committee hopes to address in a public forum issues such as whether there has been full and adequate disclosure of all relevant documents made to that inquiry. It also wishes to address the human element of those persons involved in this terrible problem by determining whether legal aid has been unfairly withheld from those claimants or plaintiffs. In paragraph 2 of the terms of reference, the committee will examine whether a range of Commonwealth departments and agencies, in whatever form, and former companies have adequately protected public safety.

In summary, this is a relatively defined inquiry. I am hopeful that it can be concluded by the end of August. The essential thrust is to examine the issue of fairness to those who suffer, or who might suffer, from this most terrible disease of CJD.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —While I support all that Senator Bishop has said—and all that he is trying to do with this particular reference, and we will be supporting the reference—I am very disappointed to see that this is yet another backflip from the ALP in what has been a week of backflips. I spent a lot of time discussing with shadow minister Michael Lee the need to broaden this inquiry so we were not just looking at products where people were possibly facing CJD. We were going to have a broader inquiry to move away from just the pituitary hormone products and look at vaccines, blood products, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: This would have enabled the committee to look at issues such as the role of CSL in the issue of vaccine testing on wards of the state, particularly in Melbourne as revealed recently in the Age. We would have been able to look at the role of the CSL, the Commonwealth department of health and the NHMRC in the production, regulation and use of a range of different products. By taking out these words, we have restricted this inquiry to one issue. Yes, it is a very important issue and it has needed an inquiry for a long time, but it is most disappointing to see the range of issues we are not going to be able to look at. I would like an explanation from the ALP as to why this restriction has come about and why they have decided to go down this path.

I am only going to give a couple of examples of issues that we now cannot look at. There was work done in 1963, for example, looking at the influence of a particular anabolic steroid on children. It had nothing to do with human pituitary trials, and therefore we cannot look at it. Norethandrolone was also used on short children. It says right at the front of the paper:
Caution is necessary because each anabolic steroid is potentially androgenic and there are no satisfactory reports concerning their androgenic side effects.

This was supported by the NHMRC. As I said, that was 1963. Some people are arguing, `What does that really matter? We are looking at one issue and what is happening in the present.' I think we need to go back to look at the particular processes. I think it will give us a view into what is happening in the NHMRC as it is now structured.

Eventually, at the end of this research, it was decided that the possibility of any improvement was too remote to justify ethically the treatment of a large number of children, so it was only ever done on a relatively small number. The observations basically came back that there was no real effect. Then two years later they started another trial. In this particular instance the trial was on girls and the management of the stature of girls. Why were these particular children subjected to testing? I will give you a couple of quotes:
Some girls feel so embarrassed with boys shorter than themselves that they believe their choice of male companions, both in the immediate future and as adults, will be seriously jeopardised.
They may have difficulty in buying clothes appropriate to their age, and if clothes have to be tailor‐made, extra expenses can be a problem.
Some careers, for example, classical ballet, are closed to an unusually tall girl.
A woman taller than average is only rarely suffering from organic disease . . .
But these trials went ahead anyway. Page 212 of this report states:
In general, treatment was given to control the stature of any girl in whom the estimated mature stature was more than 177.7 cm.
In girls whose estimated mature stature was regarded as too small to justify treatment, reassurance was given that they would not grow to an excessive degree.

The particular hormone used was stilboestrol. In reports now we find that this is a cause of vaginal cancer in girls whose mothers had taken this drug in the first three months of pregnancy to reduce the risk of losing the baby. Later reports have since confirmed this relationship. Some treated girls went on to gain enormous amounts of weight and indeed became obese. Now that we have this narrowed down version of reference, we cannot look into these issues. These are just extra examples of where we cannot now go.

I want to move to the present. I think we need to answer some questions about the present, particularly now that CSL has a different structure and is supposed to be making a profit. As it is now privatised, pressure is on for it to be economic. I will raise a few questions and perhaps the minister can answer these. Is it correct that the messages we are getting about the pressure on CSL to mix blood to produce products for Australia is only being stopped because the Red Cross will not have a bar of it? As they are the major collection agency in this country, so far it is not happening.

The charge is that the watchdog, the federal government, is basically not interested. It is a company now; it is out to make a profit. They have blood coming in from other countries, particularly from Asia, that they treat and send back to those countries or they prepare products and send back to those countries. It is a process that supposedly we are monitoring and preventing from happening, but we cannot ask questions about that now. We cannot ask questions that have come to our notice about the possibility of contamination of vaccines with live viruses. We cannot do any of that.Basically the government is saying to us, `Don't delve into CSL. We don't really want to know. We want to limit this inquiry to as narrow an issue as we possibly can.

I am very pleased that the inquiry is getting up, as it was the Democrats who originally started pushing for one. Indeed, it was Senator John Coulter in 1995, around the time that laboratories were being sold, who started raising some of these issues. In that case, the Labor Party and the Liberal Party voted together to scuttle the inquiry.

I am now pleased to see that we at least have an inquiry getting up and that we are going to stop the pressure on the recipients to accept compensation until it is over. We are talking about some 2,500 who have had to wait far too long for something to be done. I want to stress that, while we are pleased that an inquiry is getting up, I really would like to know why the minister and the department of health are not happy to look more fully into what is happening with CSL.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me say to Senator Lees that I will take those questions on notice and get back to her. The government acknowledges concern in the community about how matters relating to the Australian pituitary hormone program have been handled over many years.

BREAK.PARA: We certainly recognise that it is the will of the Senate that there be some form of inquiry into this matter. We welcome the fact that Senator Bishop has confined his motion to matters relating to the pituitary hormones program. In fact, it is solely for this reason that the government does not oppose—(Quorum formed)

As I was saying, it is solely for this reason that the government does not oppose Senator Bishop's amended terms of reference. Paragraph 2 of the original motion was a Pandora's box just waiting to be opened. It had unlimited scope to inquire into a broad range of human biological products above and beyond the CJD issue at the heart of the senator's concerns. This would have answered no questions, invited all sorts of unsubstantiated allegations and conspiracy theories, and would have done so under privilege. I welcome the Labor Party's responsible recognition of the concerns that the government has raised and I refer to the matter as previously raised in 1995 by Senator Coulter and the problems then raised in relation to blood products.

As I have said, we are not convinced of the need for an inquiry, but we are prepared to accept an inquiry in the terms of Senator Bishop's amended motion on the understanding that the inquiry will not be a re‐run of the Allars inquiry and that it will be conducted with sensitivity and understanding. We therefore do not oppose the amended motion. I would, however, like to point out and put on the record that the government is concerned that the terms of reference for the inquiry, as proposed in this motion, will not deliver what the Senate intends to achieve through the reference to this committee. It may result in replacing uncertainty for hormone recipients, who have suffered enough, with even more uncertainty. I hope that I am wrong in this regard.

As far as the legal aid aspect is concerned, this could establish an unhelpful precedent and could risk politicising individual legal aid funding decisions which need to be made objectively and on the merits of individual cases. I might point out that there is a suppression order in relation to one of the mat ters, as I understand it, and there is correspondence from the solicitors for one of the people involved asking that the identity of that person be kept confidential. This motion requires the tabling in parliament of material which was provided in support of an application for legal aid funding and would involve the disclosure of financial or other circumstances provided to the Attorney‐General's Department in confidence. The government is not prepared to breach that applicant's confidentiality.

There is a longstanding practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys‐General from any political persuasion, to treat applications for financial assistance in this regard in confidence. The practice accords with the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988 in relation to information provided by natural persons and the general law on breach of confidence. Most of the information in the present case was supplied to the government for the purpose of the administration of the legal aid program in the Attorney‐General's Department. Noting that one of the criteria for granting assistance is hardship to the applicant it is necessary that the applicant disclose details of financial circumstances and other information.

If the confidentiality of such information could not be maintained there is a substantial risk that persons having legitimate applications for assistance would be dissuaded from making such applications. This would prejudice the operation of the legal aid scheme administered by the Attorney‐General's Department. This result would be contrary to the public interest. The public interest and test case scheme is a form of legal aid provided directly by the Commonwealth. The vast majority of legal aid in Australia is provided through state and territory legal aid commissions.

Senators should note that in New South Wales, for instance, there is not only a longstanding convention by successive Attorneys‐General not to release confidential information about individual applicants but there is also a statutory prohibition on disclosure. Indeed, similar secrecy requirements are imposed in the state of Western Australia. This motion is asking the Commonwealth to disclose information in relation to applicants that are made to it and could not be obtained from legal aid commissions in the states and territories.

In summary, the government resists those aspects of the motion which would identify successful applicants on the basis that this would be contrary to the principles of the general law of breach of confidence and would be contrary to the public interest. Given that it is the clear will of the Senate that this motion proceed, the government will not oppose this matter having set out the reservations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome this inquiry into aspects of CJD, the government's response to the Allars report, the treatment of the recipients of human pituitary hormones and whether certain government bodies—or other bodies, for that matter—failed to protect public safety. This has been a matter of interest to me for some considerable time. I am really very happy to see and to support the reference of this matter to the Community Affairs References Committee that is chaired by Senator Bishop. I am sure Senator Bishop and other senators on that committee will do a fine job.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the human pituitary hormone program is a history of broken rules. Women seeking help for infertility, and men and women of short stature were essentially guineapigs in an unlawful experiment which has so far killed four women and one man. Another woman is currently being assessed by medical authorities for suspected CJD. Recently, as a result of my questions in estimates committees, it was revealed that blood and tissue supplies included donations from people who later died of CJD.

Every day, recipients live with the possibility that they could be living incubators of the human equivalent of mad cow disease. I hope and pray that they can do so peacefully within themselves. A number of people take things differently. The Commonwealth government and the Commonwealth parliament have a responsibility in this area. I am very pleased to see this inquiry getting off the ground.

BREAK.PARA: A form of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), CJD is linked with a similar disease in sheep called scrapie. It causes spongy formations in the brain. Symptoms include loss of balance and coordination, decline of mental faculties sometimes leading to dementia, jerking movements and rigidity prior to death.

We should note that hormone recipients were frustrated from the outset in their attempt to launch a compensation claim. They were denied legal aid. As the plaintiffs' lawyers pointed out, there was an inherent conflict in that the defendant—the Commonwealth—was the arbiter in granting or denying the application for legal aid. On top of this extreme financial handicap, documents essential to the recipients' case were kept from them.

The history of the program is a history of broken rules. The report of Professor Margaret Allars, who was commissioned to examine the use of pituitary hormones in Australia, is a damning indictment of the program. Allars found, amongst other things, that CSL had not met all the requirements of the Australian regulatory authorities to manufacture and distribute hormones. Describing the program as `unlawful' and `experimental', she found that many participants were not informed of the experimental nature of the program or of the fact that the hormones came from human tissues taken from dead bodies.

The first guideline for selecting women for the program was that they should not be ovulating. However, ovulating women were given hPG. Allars also refers to other experiments including super ovulation for use in IVF experiments.

Australia was the only country to provide for a government sponsored program making hPG available free of charge to patients. Between 1967 and 1968, more than 2,500 people were treated with human pituitary gonadotrophin or human growth hormone manufactured from human pituitary glands taken from cadavers—hPG is the fertility hormone and hGH is a growth hormone administered to children of short stature.

CSL collected the glands, manufactured and distributed the products. A total of 171,091 pituitary glands were collected from dead bodies, with removal carried out mainly by mortuary staff who were paid a fee for each gland collected. Relatives had not given their consent for harvesting the glands.

Dr P. Schiff—CSL's representative on the Human Pituitary Hormone Advisory Committee and responsible to the Minister for Health in overseeing the program—advised the gland collectors that `unless the body is badly decomposed, it is never too late to take the gland'. In other words, decomposing body parts could be removed and processed for use in living humans.

In 1966, CSL issued criteria to exclude pituitary glands taken from people who had died from certain diseases, among them viral hepatitis. In 1971, the College of Pathologists recommended that neurological diseases, including slow viruses, be added to the list.

However, according to Professor Allars, neurological diseases were removed from the list of exclusions in 1977. Allars stated that CSL was warned in 1966 that viruses would not necessarily be eliminated in the hormone manufacturing process. There was enough information in 1966 to indicate that the program should not have been allowed to proceed. But it did, and the women I referred to, who only wanted help to have babies, lost their physical and mental health and their lives because of it. The Australian pituitary hormone program was closed down in May 1985 after two hGH recipients in the US died from CJD. The first Australian woman died in 1988. There were two subsequent deaths, yet the department of health waited until 1991 to advise those people who had been on the program of those deaths.

All overseas cases involving hormone recipients have been settled in favour of the recipients. In France, some of those responsible for the French pituitary growth hormone program have been prosecuted and could be imprisoned. But in Australia no‐one has been prosecuted and no‐one has admitted fault. This goes to the next point I am making. There are so many things done by persons who are imbued with the idea that the techno logical imperative should prevail. This is happening in a whole range of areas, particularly when it comes to women's health. I will deal with that at a subsequent stage.

While I welcome this inquiry, I must register my disappointment with the opposition for removing the reference to human biological products from the terms of reference. The whole CJD episode is a window into lax processes and cover‐ups by those responsible for regulating human experimentation and by those whose grave duty it is to ensure the highest standards in the regulation and manufacture of biological products derived from blood, tissues and organs.

A broad inquiry has been necessary for a long time. For too long the manufacturers of Australian products of human biological origin, made for the Commonwealth on behalf of the Australian people, have consistently failed in their mission and evaded discovery. The harvesting of organs and other human tissues or fluids for vaccines, hormone preparations and other biological products used by millions of Australians has not always met these high standards. As brought to light recently, blood donors have died of CJD. This demands further investigation.

We know, too, that CSL Ltd has secretly mixed Australian and foreign plasma over the decades. Until now, the Therapeutic Goods Administration has shown itself to be inadequate in its ability to regulate products of biological origin. I have had cause to be quite critical of the Therapeutic Goods Administration in various other areas. This is not a criticism of the minister or the parliamentary secretary. Under their sharp eye, no doubt things have improved vastly.

The problems that I alluded to really boil down to a betrayal of public safety and cannot continue. It is my hope that the committee commissioned to conduct the inquiry concerning matters relating to CJD recipients will recognise that there are related matters which also deserve detailed consideration. I wish the committee every success.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
