PROCTEXT.PARA: AGED CARE BILL
Consideration resumed from 25 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Aged Care Bill. The question is that the bill as amended be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 1-2, page 2 (lines 10 and 11), omit "on a day or days to be fixed by Proclamation", substitute "on 1 January 1998".

When we concluded yesterday, we had dealt with the government's three amendments. We now proceed to deal with the opposition's amendments, firstly amendment No. 1. This amendment seeks to specify the date of commencement of the act as 1 January 1998.

There are some very good and cogent reasons for this amendment. The first issue is the fact that the bill states that the act will commence on a day to be fixed by proclamation. It was originally proposed by the minister that this act should come into force on 1 July. That was the position put by the government in the August budget of 1996 when the structural reform of aged care was announced.

I do not think there would be a person involved in the aged care sector who believed it was ever going to be possible for this package and this quite detailed, voluminous legislation to commence operation on 1 July as had been announced by the government. For a start, the authorising legislation was not introduced into the parliament until 26 March 1997. That was only three months prior to the intended date of commencement.

We have since then had the minister recognise that that date of 1 July was extremely optimistic and propose that it now commence operation on 1 October. Of course, the act does not specify that. That is what the government hopes it can achieve.

There are many outstanding issues to be resolved with people in the aged care sector before one can be certain that the implications of the act are fully understood. For example, it has been only in the last couple of days that a position has been reached on the amount of the concessional resident subsidy. The minister has been forced to rethink that issue on at least two occasions, and it was really only two days ago now that the announcement came that a deal had been worked out with the Democrats to get their support for dealing with the legislation this week.

There are clearly people out there who still have to assess what is going to be the impact of that announcement on concessional resident subsidy, because it is less than what was clearly identified by the industry as being the minimum appropriate amount needed—that is, $12 per resident.

We are yet to see the final form of the principles that will be attached to this legislation. Indeed, many of the important elements of this legislation and its impact are really going to be known only when the principles are finalised and in operation. The latest exposure draft, the revised exposure draft on the Aged Care Bill principles, in itself runs to about 290‐odd pages on top of a bill that is 370 pages. I am advised that comments are still coming in and that the date for that process to be finalised is tomorrow. So it is going to be some time yet before we know fully what the principles will be.

We would submit that it is premature—to say the least—and indeed reckless to be trying to put this legislation through this chamber this week simply because it is the last week of the session before the winter recess. I believe that that is the position that many in the industry and indeed the Democrats themselves would really subscribe to, notwithstanding their agreement.

I might point out, for the benefit of Senator Woodley, because I think he has probably forgotten this—and this also relates to issues that we were discussing yesterday—that the Democrats recommended in their dissenting report:

The Australian Democrats recommend that the commencement date for the aged care structural reforms be delayed until information concerning all the issues is available, outstanding problems and concerns have been resolved and the impact of the proposed reforms have been fully explored and debated, but no later than 1 January 1998.

That is your recommendation, Senator Woodley. That committee report, as you know, was tabled only a few days ago. So it is hard to believe and accept that, in the space of a couple of days, all of these outstanding problems and concerns could have been resolved that would lead you to a position to say, `Yes, we now feel confident that this legislation can come into force from 1 October.' That is just plainly untenable.

Our proposal is one that I would think the Democrats particularly should subscribe to—notwithstanding their eleventh-hour agreement—that there should be a date later than 1 October, that the date should be specified in the legislation so there is certainty out there in the industry and in the aged care sector, and that that date should be 1 January next year. If the government have a good hard think about this, they themselves must know that it is impossible to really get everything resolved before 1 October.

We say that the sector needs certainty. There are major changes which will occur as a result of this legislation. You only have to consider the implications of the accommodation bonds proposal. We do ask the government and the Democrats and the Independents and the other parties in the Senate to think seriously about, and support, our amendment for a specified operative date in the legislation of 1 January 1998.

I might also refer to some of the myriad of correspondence that I have received from various nursing homes and aged care institutions and organisations in recent days. I understand that they have also been sent to many other members of parliament. For instance, a letter from the Leichhardt Uniting Church Homes and Community Services—and this is yesterday, so this is after the Democrat-government deal—comments about the impacts of this bill and new operational funding arrangements. They say:

I attach for your information a summary sheet from our working party of `grass root practitioners' which clearly indicates that the ratings as they currently exist will create chaos if introduced on October 1st.
And they have some 550 residents in their care. Similarly, there is a letter from the Diocese of Maitland-Newcastle Catholic Care of the Aged, dated 19 June. It states:

Only in the last few days have I and my staff gained access to the Resident Classification Scale Weightings which enable residential aged care providers to estimate their future income following the reforms.
We are still undertaking this exercise as it is quite time consuming, however it is becoming obvious that all of our nursing homes and hostels will lose significant sums of money.
Then they give some examples. They go on to say:

We implore your assistance in the debate in the Senate to stop the passage of the Aged Care Bill and associated legislation until more adequate assessment of its impact is completed and until we can be sure the new legislation will result in improvement rather than deterioration of aged care services.

I have a similar letter from a nursing home in the area that I live in, which is the Sutherland shire in Sydney. This comes from the Stella Maris Hostel/Nursing Home at Cronulla, calling upon the parliament to delay the implementation of this legislation until they have had more time to consider the impact of the new funding arrangements that are proposed in this bill. I am sure, as I said, senators would have received heaps of correspondence from right around the country indicating concerns about a substantial reduction in funding.
Finally, I might refer to a fax from the national body of the Uniting Church Community Services Australia, which was dated 20 June. They say at the end:

The current financial variables as identified to date under the reform strategy clearly indicate major problems with the capacity of the new legislative framework to meet the stated policy objectives.
It is crucial the passage of the Bill be delayed until the financial variables have been more thoroughly tested and flaws eliminated.
They also refer to the care subsidy and to the new standard classification as well as to the issue that the Democrats now say has been resolved; that is, the concessional resident subsidy.

So that is just a microcosm of the amount of concern that is out there in the aged care sector about the impact of this legislation. We would submit that we should endeavour, as a matter of good policy and as a matter of ensuring that when this legislation comes into force—as no doubt it will, because the numbers are here for it to be passed eventually—we at least give people in the sector some certainty. We should give them an opportunity over the remaining part of this year to more adequately and properly assess the implications and enable them to have all of the information, have the details and have the principles. As we saw yesterday, the government cannot give us information about the committee structures that they envisage being established by the minister.

So I would particularly ask the Democrats, Senator Woodley, to have a look at your recommendations in the report, contained at page 87. Do not do what you did yesterday, which was ignore your own recommendation with respect to the establishment of an independent review committee. We put up an amendment to have that provision inserted into the legislation, and you did not support it, even though your own recommendation was that the legislation be amended so that that committee would be established under the legislation. So I implore you on this occasion to support the opposition's amendment with respect to the operative date of the legislation, and that should be 1 January 1998.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw has put a lot of matters before the committee which I may not be able to answer completely, but I will certainly do my best. In relation to the last issue, which he keeps raising, I am happy to debate that when we are considering his amendment which deals with that issue. But let me deal with the issue of the date, which is before us at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Forshaw that he and I could read letters from different groups until the cows come home and really not resolve anything. But the problem he has is in catching up. The last letter that he read, from Community Services Australia, was from the group that was involved in the discussions over the weekend and who signed off. So the problem with reading this material is that we need to put it in context.

BREAK.PARA: He read from a press release from Community Services Australia, which is the Uniting Church peak body. Libby Davies, Harry Herbert and Les McDonald were all involved in the discussions and following that press release were prepared and happy to sign off on the agreement which was reached. That is the problem with standing here and reading from these various bits and pieces of paper. However, I know that I do it, too. I am not giving Senator Forshaw a caning over that; I am just saying that that piece of paper from which he read was out of date.

Let me deal with the substance of this issue because I think it is an important issue. I will deal not only with the points that Senator Forshaw made, which were good points, but also with some points made by Senator Margetts in her speech during the second reading debate which went to this matter. I quote what she said:

We should be spending more time on these bills. There is an unseemly rush to deal with something of such major importance to all Australians. And I am not the only one who believes this. Yesterday, the Australian Nursing Federation put out a press release entitled `Aged Care Bill 1997—Democrats let residents and staff down'.
She then quoted from that press release as follows:
ANF acting federal secretary, Denis Jones, said the break‐neck speed at which they sought to do a deal with the Government . . .

I ask Senator Margetts: is this the same Denis Jones who published the most appalling photos of what were apparently, according to him, patients with bed sores, to show what would happen if the bill is passed? The only problem was that Denis Jones did not explain, in publishing the photos, that they were 20 years old. My wife, who was working voluntarily in my office last week, who is a registered nurse and who works in an aged care institution, opened the envelope and I had to get her down off the roof because she was so angry at the misrepresentation of those photos, given her experience in working in aged care. So Senator Margetts ought to be careful about who she takes advice from.

I will quote further from Senator Margetts's speech because I am a bit angry about it. She went on to quote a little further from the Nursing Federation's press release. I do not blame the Nursing Federation; I want to pin this on Denis Jones. I think most nurses would dissociate themselves from much of what he has said. She quoted from Denis Jones's press release as follows:
He criticised Senator Woodley for his selective representations to the Government on behalf of church organisations, because they ignored the interests of aged care staff and consumers.

I do take umbrage at that. I say to Senator Margetts that I have spent 10 months—in fact, I have spent years, but certainly the last 10 months—consulting as widely as possible, not just with churches, but with Aged Care Australia, the RSL war veterans homes, the Australian Nursing Home and Extended Care Association, the Council on the Ageing, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, Tricare, the Older Women's Network and the Australian Nursing Federation. I attended the hearings of the nursing home inquiry conducted by the Senate. I did not see Senator Margetts at many of those hearings.

I have been a director of an aged care institution. I have served on management committees of aged care institutions for years. I have been a chaplain for years to aged care institutions where staff and residents were my major concern. In the last 12 months I have consulted face to face with and visited nursing homes such as the Freemasons Home in Sandgate, the RSL War Veterans Home in Caboolture, Pleasantville in Wynnum, the Shalom Elders Village in Townsville, the Helping Hand Centre in Adelaide, and Ballycara in Scarborough. All the other Democrat senators have done the same.

We have consulted widely. Selective advice—I think that is a joke. If there is any group in the Senate that takes selective advice from people and makes selective representations, it is certainly the Greens. I normally do not attack people, but I have to say that I was fairly angry about that kind of accusation.

I have consulted as widely as I possibly could, as have the other Democrat senators. We have received very diverse advice—sometimes conflicting advice. We have tried to take on board all that has been said to us. We have taken account of it. We have not always agreed with every piece of advice that we have received but it is certainly not selective. I believe the advice is as wide as any human being could receive.

There is another issue associated with selective advice—and I am not accusing Senator Margetts of this, but it is certainly very widespread in this community—and that is an anti-church attitude which says that if it comes from the churches it must be wrong. I am pretty sick of that attitude. I make no defence of the proposition that the church should have a privileged position in the community. I certainly do not believe that and, in any case, that is excluded by the Australian constitution. But I do believe that the church and Christians have a right to put their point of view along with every other citizen, especially when they have expertise. In this area, they have very much expertise. They have been there from the very beginning.

Let me remind the Senate that the not for profit church sector has 30 per cent of all aged care residential places, 80 to 85 per cent of hostel beds and 20 to 25 per cent of nursing home beds in Australia. It was very appropriate, along with the other consultations I had, to include those church bodies in the consultations and the agreement I reached with the government. That is especially so when we were discussing disadvantaged people, because they are the ones that the Democrats were most concerned about. We said all along and constantly that it was the concessional residents who were our major concern, and they certainly were the major concern of the church groups.

There is something else that has escaped the Greens and Labor. That is the money for infrastructure which was in the budget and which was put there by the previous government and has now disappeared. I am not happy about that, but being unhappy about it will not bring it back. There is no point supporting amendments to try to return to the previous system under Labor. That system has gone. What the Democrats tried to do was work within the new situation. We have helped to claw back $40 million for infra structure improvement. That is a lot more than was allocated in the last year of the Labor administration. The figure I understand that was allocated for infrastructure upgrading by Labor in the last year of its administration was $10 million.

What we are now proposing is $40 million‐plus for concessional residents, accommodation bonds for those who can afford to pay, plus another $10 million in reserve for regional, remote and disadvantaged areas. I am not an accountant, but it seems to me that those figures add up to a lot more than Labor spent in the last year of its administration.

I am aware and Labor are aware that they opposed many of the key elements of this reform from the very beginning. Do not only read the dissenting report by the Democrats, but read the report in toto and you will see that there were many key elements of the reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did, Senator Woodley.

—We both did, I am sure, because we are both avid readers. You will see there that the Labor Party was never going to support key elements of this reform. Once I understood that, I was aware that it would not matter how much time we took in this debate—Labor were not going to change their position. In August, in September, in November or at the end of 1998, the position that Labor would take would be the same.

BREAK.PARA: Having been able to come to an agreement with the government that answered many of the issues which were being raised by significant groups in the community and having been given written assurances that those concerns would continue to be addressed by the department and the minister, I believed there was no point in further delaying the debate and certainly, as the Greens have said, not delaying the debate to beyond the 1 January 1998 date nominated by Labor. I remind the Senate that what we are debating is government legislation and not Democrat legislation, but we have been prepared to work very hard to improve that legislation. I believe that in the agreement we have been able to make very significant improvements. That is why the Democrats will not support this amendment and would urge the Senate to continue the debate and to pass the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, the government would like to acknowledge the contribution made by Senator Woodley in this matter and his experience in relation to aged care. (Quorum formed) The government shares Senator Woodley's concerns in relation to the misleading campaign that has been led by the Australian Nursing Federation and authorised by Mr Denis Jones.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I draw attention to the fact that those photos that Senator Woodley referred to are misleading. They do nothing to advance the cause in this matter of disseminating information on this proposed legislation. In fact, the reverse is true. The government has engaged in extensive consultation, as I outlined earlier. There is no reason to delay this legislation one day more. The minister has already compromised on the date of 1 October 1997, and it would be a disservice to the people of Australia were the implementation of this bill put off until 1 January next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I make some comments in response? At the outset Senator Woodley said that he was happy to debate the issues I raised about the Democrats' foreshadowed amendment in the report which they did not pursue yesterday. Then he went right off the topic of the amendment to deal with some matters raised by Senator Margetts. I took it from Senator Woodley's comments that in no way did he make those allegations about me or the opposition. I certainly acknowledge Senator Woodley's integrity and his work in this area over many years.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the operative date of the legislation, Senator Woodley referred to the letter from Community Services Australia, the national body for community services in the Uniting Church, which I quoted from. As I said during my earlier remarks, I readily concede that that letter was sent on 20 June, which was prior to the announcement by the Democrats by way of a press release on 24 June. Senator Woodley was kind enough to inform me that the agreement had been reached. But I do not think that media release answers whether or not you should now backtrack from your earlier position in the report regarding the date of operation. In that report the Democrats stated that the introduction of the bill should be delayed, but that it should be delayed no later than 1 January 1998.

Of course, the Democrats were aware—as indeed were all the participants in the committee when they were finalising the report last week—that the minister had already indicated an operative date of 1 October. So clearly it was the position of the Democrats to propose a date later than 1 October but no later than 1 January. So the fact that the Democrats have negotiated this deal with the government in the last few days does not in any way detract from expressions of concern right across the aged care sector, from providers and people who are residents or representatives of residents in those establishments to employee organisations and the professions. The fact that that agreement has been reached does not in any way overcome the many concerns that still remain.

The Democrat press release put out on 24 June indicates that the Democrats, together with the three main church providers and the government, have agreed to these points specifically: firstly, an increase in the concessional resident subsidy, which I acknowledge was of major concern to the Democrats—as it was indeed to the Labor Party as we have been saying all along that it should be increased to $12; secondly, that there will be a review of the entire aged care reform package in two years; and, finally, that there will be an independent review of the residential classification scale. Associated with that are the matters raised by Senator Lees with respect to the complaints committees. But, as you know, Senator Woodley, there are lots of other issues that are of concern.

I think it is a bit of sophistry to say, `Oh, well, all these groups have been writing to us up until today; they had all these concerns last week but things have moved on and it is an entirely new world today where the agreement has been reached between the Democrats and the government so all the issues have been resolved.' Clearly that is not the case.

Senator Woodley, you know as well as I do that you and the Democrats, as expressed in the report, are also concerned about the fact that the principles have not been finalised and about issues such as how the level of daily fees will impact upon people who will be seeking to gain access to nursing homes. One could go on and itemise all those issues, but they are quite adequately covered in the report. But I still put the point that, notwithstanding your agreement on one major issue—that is, the level of the concessional resident subsidy—there is still a need for further discussion and for further time to allow the impact of this legislation to be fully understood and assessed out there in the community.

Essentially what we are saying is that the commencement date should be put back by three months, from 1 October to 1 January. That, I believe, is really the position of the providers and of the organisations out there. Solving one issue has not solved all of their concerns. I take you back to the report. I will not read it in full, but I just note that chapter 1 of the report details the various organisations that have been expressed their concern—Aged Care Australia, the ACTU, the New South Wales Aged Care Alliance, and a range of other groups.
As the committee recommended, the commencement date should be delayed until 1 January 1998. We continue to push for that amendment. We ask the Senate to support the amendment that has been moved.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.

TITLE.XREF: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996 [1997]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 December 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 26 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Environment, Sports and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill which, as senators would be aware, is essentially a technical bill which amends 15 acts of parliament to improve the administrative processes of those acts to bring Commonwealth legislation into line with the resolutions of the 16th consultative meeting of contracting parties to the London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping Wastes and Other Material and also to correct a number of drafting errors. The opposition will support this bill following the government's agreement to amend section 40 dealing with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects of this bill on which I would like to briefly comment. In its original form, the bill sought to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to remove the Australian Defence Force or the defence force of a foreign country from the application of an offence of waste discharge on the Great Barrier Reef. The opposition opposed this amendment to the act. Had the government not agreed, the opposition would be moving amendments to the bill to remove the resultant inconsistency between defence and commercial vessels.

We need to acknowledge that the reef is a highly sensitive world heritage area that demands strict environmental controls on waste disposals, whether they be from commercial, private or defence vessels. Of course, the Labor Party in government had an out standing record of protecting the world heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef. The government's decision to amend the bill to remove the exception for Defence Force vessels is one that is welcomed by the opposition. I hope it will be welcomed by other senators.

The second aspect of the bill that the opposition would like to draw the chamber's attention to is the amendments to the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 to increase the period for the minister to make a decision on inclusion or removal of an item from the endangered species list from 30 days to 90 days. I think we all acknowledge in the chamber that the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, is particularly slow in his decision making processes, but does he really need three times as long as other environment ministers have had to make these very important decisions? I think this is a very reasonable question to ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and other senators.

I suppose poor old Senator Hill as the Minister for the Environment has to go and consult with a whole lot of his colleagues who are really running environmental policy in this country, but we do seriously question whether even someone as tardy, as slow to act, as indecisive and as wimpy as Senator Hill really needs three times as long, from 30 days to 90 days.

However, in the spirit of generosity for which we are known, and I particularly am known, I would like to say, in conclusion to this outstanding speech on this bill, that after removal of section 40 from the bill dealing with waste disposal—

TALK.START.PARA: —We won't accuse you of modesty.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I have not been accused of modesty. I must say, Senator Margetts, as you would be aware, there are very few senators whom you could accuse of modesty. I think even Senator Margetts would have to acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: The removal from the bill of section 40, dealing with waste disposal on the Great Barrier Reef, is a very important improvement to this bill, as far as the opposition is concerned. With its removal, the opposition has no objection to this bill and will be supporting its passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. The government has now removed this particular section from this bill—a section to which we also objected—relating to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. As has been said, it would have exempted Defence Force vessels and aircraft from the existing 38J and would have meant that, basically, they no longer could have been fined. It would no longer have been an offence if they had discharged waste, either intentionally or negligently, onto the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

SPEECH.PARA: We complained to the government at the time that, had that section stayed in, the legislation would not have been able to be dealt with as non-controversial. We are pleased to see that it has gone. Therefore, we support the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I am not on the speakers' list, but just very briefly: originally, when we saw this legislation, we called this particular part of it the tandem thrust amendment. We were very concerned that it was poised as being likely to go through before the exercises, which many, many people in the community would have thought a travesty. There were certain exemptions that were available to the exercises anyway. Even in the post-tandem thrust report, there was some level of aggravation about how many levels of checks and balances the community, in fact, forced them to look at—even if at times they had legal ability to override them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am still concerned that there should be any precedence for us continuing to have any exercises like that on the Great Barrier Reef. I am very pleased that this part of the bill has been removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the previous three speakers for their support for the bill. As Senator Faulkner has indicated, many of the amendments are technical— some of which, I suggest, probably emanated in the time Senator Faulkner was the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Great Barrier Reef, I think we have a conclusion that is appropriate and one that we all support. I think all Australians are very keen to protect the Great Barrier Reef to the most extreme extent possible. So I do appreciate that we have been able to reach an agreement with all the parties that gets the result we all want.

Finally, I think I should indicate that I know Senator Faulkner was speaking tongue in cheek. He, like all of us, recognises that Senator Hill is one of the hardest working and most conscientious ministers in the parliament. Senator Hill is very, very prompt and efficient in all of the dealings with his portfolio. It has been indicated that the 30 days for the making of decisions did not allow for the appropriate amount of consultation with all the necessary groups that needed to be consulted. The suggestion that it be extended to 90 days is one that is reasonable, and I appreciate all parties acknowledging that by supporting the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory note relating to the amendment to the bill. The government opposes item 40 of schedule 1 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 40, page 20 (lines 24 to 28), to be opposed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that item 40 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 10 February, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill was introduced into parliament on 21 November 1996. We do find it somewhat extraordinary that it has taken a non-controversial bill nearly eight months to pass through the parliament. This delay has certainly not been caused by non-government members.
—Mismanagement by the government.
—Exactly, because the government has not shown any interest in legislation until very recently.

SPEECH.PARA: But, most certainly, we are happy to pass this legislation. It is an omnibus package of amendments concerning banking, financial corporations and insurance. The major issues include the strengthening of the prudential regulation of financial conglomerates regulated by the Reserve Bank and the ISC by liberalising information exchange rules between regulators and between domestic and international regulatory agencies; extending the deadline by two years for taxation concessions applying to foreign bank subsidiaries who convert to branch status—

TALK.START.PARA: —Explain clause 6.

—No, I am going to leave Senator Kemp to explain clause 6. Further issues include allowing the Wallis inquiry to report and for the government to respond to the report; improving the supervisory arrangements that apply in the insurance industry to allow related companies to be formally included in supervision regime; and improving insurance policyholders' security by disallowing the review of some regulatory decisions of the ISC where those decisions are agreed to by the minister—in this case, Senator Kemp, giving you much enhanced power, which we hope you use responsibly.

BREAK.PARA: Other major issues include providing legislation back into industry codes for the general insurance industry and for insurance brokers; and other matters such as using gender neutral language—we hope you use this power wisely too, Senator Kemp—updating references to the Corporations Law and removing drafting areas from existing legislation. None of these matters are contentious and Labor is happy to support the legislation without amendment. In particular, the information sharing provisions concerning the prudential regulation of the superannuation industry is welcomed by Labor as a worthwhile and necessary reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make my comments to the Financial Laws Amendment Bill as brief as possible. The issue I want to raise is one of ministerial approval of Insurance and Superannuation Commission decisions and the inability for appeal. I understand why these things are being proposed, but I need to put a few points on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC, monitors the practices of insurance companies with the primary objective of protecting policyholders and ensuring that there is money to cover their policies in the event they need to be paid out. The ISC operates effectively under heavy confidentiality, since an open admission of a problem under investigation by the ISC or action taken by the ISC would have strong negative impact on the business of the insurance companies.

The ISC has the power to take action to ensure there are sufficient economic resources available to safeguard the interests of policyholders. It takes such action rarely. The usual practice is for the ISC to raise issues with a company and a resolution to be made by agreement. Only where a company refuses to address the problems raised by the ISC does it take the step of issuing decisions to rectify situations.

The problem this legislation is designed to address is that once a decision has been made by the Commissioner of the ISC the company can, and in some cases has, gone to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and launched an appeal. The justice system generally allows the ISC decision not to be enforced until after the appeal is judged. The result is that a delay, sometimes a substantial delay, can be imposed on what is a last ditch effort to protect the interests of consumers from bad corporate practices.

The solution government came up with is to say that no appeal can be launched for five years. As a safeguard, the commissioner will now need ministerial approval for almost any decision. While sympathetic to the need for a solution, I wonder if it could not be done differently. I am uncomfortable with eliminating the right of appeal. I think some application of the precautionary principle might be incorporated where a company could appeal but a stay order could not be issued by the AAT against an ISC decision.

The precautionary principle effectively reverse the onus in cases where action is being taken by government to protect consumers. It is best seen in cases such as the use of chemicals in various commonly used consumable products where the onus is on a company to prove it is safe, rather than on the government to prove it is not. I think the same principle could be usefully applied to consumer protection supervisory agencies like the ISC without eliminating the right of appeal.

On the issue of ministerial approval as a safeguard, I think it has the potential to politicise what could be a non-political process. On that point, the minister can be lobbied to prevent the ISC from making a decision. While it is probably true that in most cases the companies the ISC makes decisions against are small ones treading the margins of legal and ethical practice, I am not reassured by claims that the minister would not want to be seen as irresponsible, particularly given the record of government involvement in bad deals in Victoria and elsewhere.

I am not reassured because, in the first place, ISC decisions are not public for valid commercial reasons. In the second place, should the problem be with a major company, the ability to effectively lobby government or a minister may be much greater. In short, this bill creates the potential for politicisation of what should be a judgment made from the standpoint of a consumer guardian.

I understand that this bill does have the support of other parties, so there is little point in calling divisions or putting up amendments. But I do wish to note that we are not happy with the approach. The only reason I am not objecting more strongly is that I believe a company in enough trouble for the ISC to wish to take action will be one where the policyholders are already aware that something is definitely wrong, and should they discover that the ISC had tried to make a decision and had that decision overturned by a minister, there would be a substantial cost to government, one that should give a minister pause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their comments. A number of issues were raised. Senator Sherry reflected that it had taken some time to bring the Financial Laws Amendment Bill before the chamber. I think he omitted to mention that it had been referred to a Senate committee late last year and that committee reported in May. It might have helped if Senator Sherry had mentioned that, which some might say is a key point.

SPEECH.PARA: We note the comments of Senator Margetts. I know there have been intense discussions between her office and my office on this particular issue. On some of these matters we will have to differ. We think the protections are in the bill. The exemption of ISC prudential decisions from AAT review processes, we believe, is necessary to safeguard the interests of insurance policyholders. We think that the transparency of the decision making processes would subject ministers to media and parliamentary scrutiny which acts as a check which you feel is needed in the system. With those few remarks I thank senators for their comments. We, like Senator Sherry and others in the chamber, are very keen that this bill now progress.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Senator Alston:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —Time prevents me from making a substantial contribution to this very important piece of legislation that affects all woolgrowers. However, the Wool International Amendment Bill is part of the road to recovery for this great Australian primary industry. I seek leave to incorporate my brief remarks in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

I rise to speak to this bill at a time when wool prices have shown some recovery over recent months. Wool growers across Australia have waited a long time for this. We can only hope that the upward trend continues.

The Wool International Amendment Bill 1997 builds on some of the most important work the Coalition has done for the rural sector since coming to office. Simply, this bill establishes the wind up procedures for Wool International, through liquidation, and the distribution of equity to wool taxpayers in Wool International.
Shortly after the 1996 election, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, set about the major task of restructuring the wool industry.

He consulted with the various parties—growers, agents, administrators, and marketers in an effort to establish a viable, independent and deregulated industry. He was looking for ways to improve the marketing of Australian wool, both here and overseas; looking for ways of increasing returns to growers, and for a way to resolve the question of the stockpile and grower equity in it.
This bill is the result. It legislates for several changes, among them:
. The gradual scaling down of Wool International's responsibilities, with a corresponding reduction in the size of the board
. The eventual wind up of Wool International, once the wool stockpile has been disposed of, and the debt associated with the stockpile retired
. The return, for the first time, of equity to wool taxpayers, and the establishment of a mechanism to achieve this
. The transfer of equity to a grower's investment trust if that is the wish of individual growers.
Importantly, the granting of entitlements to wool taxpayers provides a more secure basis for those growers who need to sell, or borrow against their entitlements.

By now, wool taxpayers should have received a consolidated wool tax record from Wool International. It is vital that growers respond as to the accuracy and completeness of this record by 1 August this year. This will ensure they gain their correct entitlement to Wool International equity. When it is finalised, this register will form the basis for the payment of entitlements and equity distribution.

The proposed changes in this bill will make a significant difference to thousands of wool growers and their families. These people have supported their industry through some of the toughest times on record, and this bill goes some way towards ensuring a more prosperous future for the industry.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all speakers on the Wool International Amendment Bill and for the support of all parties in the chamber. This legislation is of significant importance to the Australian wool industry. I have been tremendously impressed by the Wool Council and the wool industry's willingness and resolve to work on these issues over the last year and develop mature and practical policy guidelines for the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The virtual unanimous support for the monumental changes to be implemented in this act is a striking tribute to the success of the wool round table process chaired last year by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, where the wool industry's preparedness to accept the need for cooperation and mutual support has led to a much more promising outlook for the industry. I firmly believe that with these changes and a clear end in sight for the stockpile the industry can now work towards a strong, independent and prosperous future. I thank colleagues on this side of the chamber for their help and support on this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (ACTIVITY TEST PENALTY PERIODS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 June, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important piece of legislation—the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill 1997.
—Good speech. I did it once for 15 minutes on a bill I knew nothing about.
—Wasn't bad, was it?
—Very good.

—Thank you, Senator Herron. I know that you are a considerable fan of the speeches that I make in this chamber. I would like to briefly revisit the history of the legislation that is before the chamber at this time. The government announced their proposal in relation to a new activity regime in the 1996-97 budget. It consisted of a six‐week non-payment penalty for the first breach and a 13‐week non-payment penalty for the second and subsequent breaches. We made our point clear—and I might say very effectively—during the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 in the Senate in December of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: While we support tough measures in relation to fraud and compliance, we do not believe that people should be cut off from payments without good reason or for inordinate or indefinite periods of time. We believe that the government's original activity test regime—the one that was proposed—was excessively harsh and excessively unreasonable, particularly in the absence of positive measures by the government to assist the unemployed to return to the labour force.

During the debate, the government withdrew the provisions that would have given effect to their proposed penalty regime. The government made an alternative offer, as I recall it, of five weeks non‐payment for the first breach and eight weeks non‐payment for second and subsequent breaches. Senator Newman, of course, undertook to negotiate an agreed position with the opposition and minor parties and bring legislation back to the chamber that reflected that agreed position, and, of course, tomorrow, at the conclusion of the debate, winter will be here.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we'll be off.
—And we will all be off—you are quite right, Senator Collins.
—You're off now.
—Senator Herron, would you care to withdraw that remark?
—If it offends you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—I didn't even hear it.
—I said you were off. I said, `You're off now.' I didn't think that was offensive.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The point of order is this: nothing that Senator Herron could say to me could possibly offend me. I have never asked senators to withdraw comments that they might make about me. I could not care less what they say. I did not hear it.

—With respect, senators, I am glad you have all worked it out, but there is a chair and the chair has drawn Senator Herron's attention to that comment. He has withdrawn. Senator Faulkner, would you like to proceed?
—Yes.
—It's a good speech.
—It is a good speech. I thank Senator Patterson for that interjection. I can only agree with her.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that the government is not treating this debate seriously because the government's 1997 budget announced a revised penalty regime that was actually more severe than the offer made by Senator Newman in December, especially for a third or subsequent breach, and the penalty for this in fact reverted from an eight week to a 13 week non‐payment.

Following that, we had further negotiations, which I must say could have taken place before March of this year and avoided all the toing‐and‐froing that we have seen on this matter had the government been reasonable, which of course it is not, as you know. That would have led to this regime being in place before today. The government amended the bill in the House of Representatives to give effect to a much more reasonable penalty regime—an 18 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks for the first breach, a 24 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks for the second breach and an eight week non‐payment for third and subsequent breaches. We recognise that the government has seen the strength of the arguments that have been mounted by the opposition, and the result will be that there is less need for unemployed people to beg, borrow or steal.

There are also government amendments before us on the bill. We will support these. They give effect to a beneficial measure announced in the budget this year that allows pre‐ and post‐natal women relief from meeting the requirements of the activity test in some circumstances. I sum up the opposition's approach on this bill by saying that we will be supporting the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill 1997 is listed as non‐controversial and the Democrats will not be opposing it, but it does deal with an important issue. It also deals with an important principle, and I intend to speak on it, perhaps at some length.
—Was that a threat?

—That is a threat. The main purpose of this bill is to amend the section of the Social Security Act that deals with penalty periods imposed on unemployed people who are deemed to have breached their activity test. The bill makes a number of changes to the length and means of imposing these penalty periods.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats will not be opposing this legislation because we believe the changes made will make for a simpler and, on balance, less harsh system. We believe the penalties are still too harsh, but in most circumstances they will be less harsh than those that were imposed by the previous Labor government. That is an interesting proposition, given Senator Faulkner's speech a moment ago. We will also be supporting the government amendments, which I believe are being put forward with this bill.

The bill follows the government's previous proposal in this area, which was withdrawn after it appeared clear that it was to be rejected by the Senate back in December last year, just before Christmas. The first thing to say is that this new proposal has some significant improvements over the previous one, and I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) and her office for consulting and taking on board concerns expressed by groups, such as the Welfare Rights Centre, on this issue.

Specifically, this bill seeks to implement a system whereby, for a first breach of the social security activity test, an unemployed person will lose the equivalent of approximately 4.7 weeks worth of social security payments. For a second breach, that person will incur a penalty of the equivalent of 6.2 weeks of lost payments, and any subsequent breaches will incur a penalty of eight weeks of lost payments. For the first and second breaches, the penalty is a rate equivalent to 4.7 weeks and 6.2 weeks because these penalties will actually be served as a reduction in the person's rate of payment over a 26‐week period rather than being a total payment withdrawal.

The Democrats are pleased to see the government introduce this system of rate reductions. It was something that we urged on the previous government but it did not take any notice. We believe the current system, whereby people are having their payments withheld totally for extended periods of time—a system put in place by the previous Labor government—is an appalling system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Colleagues, Senator Woodley does deserve a hearing. The noise from my left is a little high.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not mind if they do not listen as long as they do not speak too loudly. Let me repeat what I said. The Democrats are pleased to see the government introduce this system of rate reductions because we believe the current system, whereby people are having their payments withheld totally for extended periods of time—a system put in place by the previous Labor government—is an appalling system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said this on previous occasions, and I will say it again: people who have their social security payments totally withheld are being thrown into total financial chaos. Many have difficulty maintaining stable accommodation; they cannot keep their cars in good running order; and many struggle simply to meet basic living costs. For these people, the effect of these penalties is totally counterproductive in that it severely impairs their ability to get out to continue looking for work. Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask senators to talk quietly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, your point is very well taken. Would my colleagues on the left remember and recollect the whisper, instead of talking so loudly that I can hardly hear Senator Woodley.

—Thank you. In other words, the penalty that the department is imposing on people for not looking for work is actually making it even harder for those people to fulfil their activity test. If there is something that is counterproductive, that is certainly it. In that regard, the system of payment reductions being put forward in this bill by the current government is a positive step forward. I congratulate the minister's office for recognising the importance of this.

BREAK.PARA: However, the Democrats must again express our opposition to the magnitude of the penalties being proposed. It is important to remind the Senate and the people of Australia that it was the Labor Party which originally devised these overly harsh and punitive measures. Unfortunately, as in many other areas such as tariff reductions and HECS fees, the Labor Party opened the door a little and enabled the current government to drive a truck through and so continue going further down the wrong path.

The Democrats believe that the punitive scapegoating approach to welfare policy is very much the wrong path to take both on social and economic grounds. To put the impact of the penalty periods in financial terms, for a single unemployed person who gets the basic rate of $321.50 a fortnight, these penalties equate to fines of $752 for a first breach, $1,086 for a second breach and $1,286 for any subsequent breaches.

Comparing these fines with the figures provided to the Senate by the Welfare Rights Centre last year on the fines for various summary offences gives us some indication of just how severe these proposed penalties still are. I will give you a couple of comparisons. For traffic offences with low levels of alcohol, the fine is $200 to $400. For traffic offences with high levels of alcohol, the fine is $500 to $800. For common assault, the fine is $200 to $500. For assault causing bodily harm, the fine is $300 to $700. So you can see that, for driving an automobile while you are a drunk, you are fined as little as $200, but for falling foul of one of the Department of Social Security's rules and regulations you are effectively fined $750 for a first offence.

For breaking into and entering a person's house and stealing from it, you can receive a community service order. But for a second breach of your social security activity test, you are slugged with a fine of over $1,000. Finally, for assaulting a person and causing them bodily harm, you might incur a fine of $300. But for a third breach of the Department of Social Security rules, you lose nearly $1,300.

I am disappointed that penalties of this magnitude are still being inflicted on people who are likely to be amongst the poorest and most disadvantaged. I ask all senators to think long and hard about the effect that these penalties are going to have on people and their families. The extent of these penalties has much more to do with responding to mistaken public perceptions than it has to do with good policy. The minister is allowed to go on talkback radio or A Current Affair to proudly declare how tough this government is on social security recipients, but it will do very little to help people get back into work.

Once again it will be left to the charities and welfare groups to pick up the pieces. The Department of Social Security should be looking to alleviate poverty, not exacerbate it. It seems to me that when you are dealing with people's only source of income—that is, their ability to feed and clothe themselves and their children—you need to have some pretty solid backing before you would even consider increasing periods during which those people would lose their income.

The opportunity to test that evidence came up when the previous Labor government introduced the current system of penalties a couple of years ago. The system was far harsher than that which preceded it and, as such, a comparison of breaching patterns before and after the introduction of these tougher penalties would have shown us the effectiveness or otherwise of the tougher penalties. Unfortunately, as I understand from responses to a number of questions on notice that I have asked, such a comparison is not possible because the data simply is not available. That is a great pity. I would hope that, if this new system is to go through, the department will maintain some fairly detailed records on any changes to compliance behaviour that might occur.

That information would be very useful to the Senate if, at some stage in the future, the government comes back to us with a proposal to increase those penalties even further. I hope that never happens, but if it does it would be far preferable to have some sort of hard evidence to show in what way these penalties do influence people's behaviour.

The other sort of information which I think has really been lacking from this debate is information on the human impact of these penalties. We have been arguing over numbers of weeks and rates of reductions and whatever else. But in the end these provisions will have a profound effect on the livelihoods of many people.

What I would seek from the minister is an understanding that some form of research will be conducted which gives us an indication of just what the human impact is of these penalty periods. It would seem that the impact must be severe, if not devastating, for many people. I wonder if the minister might indicate whether the government would go back and indeed provide some resources for research to be undertaken in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senators Faulkner and Woodley for their comments in this regard and particularly their traversing of the areas of history, particularly those comments of Senator Woodley that pointed out the tension on these issues in the Labor administration in its former term.

SPEECH.PARA: I would draw to Senator Woodley's attention the report on fraud and compliance that was tabled by Senator Newman yesterday, and the important principles that were underlined in that review. Certainly that information is important. I acknowledge the point that Senator Woodley makes with regard to the good and proper research that underpins decision making in this area. We will certainly be very mindful of the comments he has made in that regard.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill 1997 introduces a new activity test breach regime into both the Social Security Act 1991 and the Student Youth Assistance Act 1973. The primary features of the new penalty regime are as follows. A first activity test breach within a two‐year period will attract an 18 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks. A second activity test breach within a two‐year period will attract a 24 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks. A third or subsequent activity test breach will lead to withdrawal of payment for eight weeks.

BREAK.PARA: Any multiple activity test or administrative breaches and waiting period would be served concurrently, and I stress that. The current penalty arrangements for activity test breaches are too complex. Penalties can vary according to unemployment duration and previous breach history. Unemployed people do not know what penalty might apply to them and even DSS and CES staff have difficulty working them out. For such penalties to act as an effective deterrent to non‐compliance they need to be known and understood.

The new approach to activity test penalties has been developed to take full account of the concerns about the current penalty arrangements, and after consultation with community welfare groups. It is an approach that is fair and eliminates the worst and most complex features of the current arrangements while still maintaining a strong deterrence effect for failure to meet reasonable requirements.

Although concerns have been raised in the past about the impact of penalties which involve a complete withdrawal of income support on both individuals and groups responsible for providing emergency assistance, it is considered necessary to maintain a non‐payment penalty for a third or subsequent breach. To allow a further rate reduction in this situation would allow someone to continue to receive unemployment allowances at a reduced rate indefinitely even though they continue to refuse to meet their reasonable and legitimate obligations. Fortunately, current DSS customers rarely have three or more activity test breaches. With the administration of the new penalty periods providing a better understanding of the consequences of not meeting their activity test obligations, it is envisaged that even fewer customers will incur a third or subsequent breach.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. I seek leave to move the government amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 16), omit `subsections (2), (3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8) and (9)', substitute `this section'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this bill. There has been much support expressed in the community broadcasting community over a number of years to have these amendments to the broadcasting arrangements made. The opposition supports these changes. They will make it an easier and more sensible regime for the granting of temporary licences to community broadcasters. Rather than using an artificial device through other legislation, which often limits the ability of community broadcasters to develop and license an operation that is properly funded in a 90‐day period, they can get a temporary licence for 12 months and then make an application to become a permanent community broadcaster. We support the bill. To save the time of the Senate I will not go any further other than to commend it to the Senate forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens are pleased to support this legislation, after we consulted with the community broadcasting sector. And I am pleased to be able to speak on the subject of community broadcasting—not an issue I often get the chance to address in the chamber. However, community radio is a section of the media that the Greens deal with a lot.

SPEECH.PARA: Community broadcasting plays an invaluable role not just in airing views and ideas seldom heard in the mainstream media, but also in giving access to the production of a broadcast to groups in the community who would not otherwise get the chance to be heard. This is one area in which the Greens were pleased to gain assurances from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) before agreeing to this legislation being deemed non-controversial.

It is important that community radio remains just that—for the community and by the community. That is the critical factor. We do not want the good work of the community radio sector being diluted by the development of quasi-commercial operations abusing the community licence system. I am pleased that the minister wrote to me this week assuring us that guidelines to ensure community involvement in the production and management of community broadcasting will be adhered to in these measures.

We are also pleased that it is not just the existing community broadcasting aspirants' stations that will benefit from this legislation. The minister has also assured the Greens that new aspirants that emerge `will be eligible for temporary licences on an equitable basis with existing aspirants'.

The government has also given us assurances that the budget funding cuts to ATSIC have not affected broadcasting to remote Aboriginal communities—one of the really important community broadcasting functions. I would have to say, though, that cuts to ATSIC have meant that, by maintaining these extremely important communication functions, other areas of ATSIC end up being cut. So it is no real advantage to the rest of ATSIC funding programs at this stage.

I would like to take this opportunity to redress some misconceptions, however, about the importance of community radio, in particular the size of its audience share, gauged by its ratings. This has been a matter of some controversy in Sydney lately. It was even picked up in today's Telegraph Mirror. But the issue is the same everywhere, including in my home state of Western Australia. The radio ratings that are periodically published are at best grossly misleading because they fail to record listenership to community radio.

In Sydney the surveys for radio ratings consistently show over 10 per cent unaccounted for. This is a staggering figure if you consider that the top rating station in Sydney in the last survey had 13.3 per cent of the listeners while ll.9 per cent of listeners were unaccounted for. So it is not the `don't knows'. There are no `don't knows' here; they are people who were listening and their votes have not been recorded. It is likely that a large proportion of these people are listening to community radio. The figures are collected and published by the commercial broadcast sector whose interest it is not in to reveal the listenership of the non-commercial sector.
I would like to quote briefly from a press release put out yesterday by Mark Robinson from radio 2SER. The press release says:
Yesterday's radio ratings have been slammed as a "sickening joke" by community radio station 2SER FM.
The station's Current Affairs Producer, Mark Robinson, believes the published figures are misleading, anti‐competitive and detrimental to the perception of the radio industry among advertisers.
"The survey is NOT a true reflection of Sydney radio listening. Simply adding up all the percentage figures for each station reveals how dodgy the survey is," said Robinson.

"The total is 88.1%. The questions beg being asked!! Where are the other 11.9% of Sydneysiders listening? When will the Federation of Australian Commercial Broadcasters stop kidding themselves?" he asks.
That is important in relation to resources, sponsorship of commercial radio stations and policies in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I confirm what Senator Margetts has said in relation to ATSIC having confirmed that there will not be any detriment to their broadcasting program as a result of funding cuts elsewhere, and that the government is committed to considering the development of a future strategy for the community broadcasting sector which might include a more flexible funding model. The provisions of the current act will also apply to the proposed category of `temporary community licences'. New licensees will also be subject to the community broadcasting code of practice. If licensees are found to have breached licence conditions the ABA has the power to revoke or suspend a licence. It also has the power to review all licences as they become eligible for renewal. In the case of temporary community licences this will be every 12 months; for long‐term licences it will be every five years.

SPEECH.PARA: In allocating a temporary community broadcasting licence, the ABA will be able to specify the particular hours and days and total number of days and hours during which broadcasting will be permitted. This will allow the ABA to determine spectrum arrangements where there is not enough spectrum for each aspirant to broadcast full time and should enable as many aspirants as possible to share available spectrum.

The ABA will shortly distribute a discussion paper to the sector calling for comment on the implementation of the legislation particularly with regard to areas where there is limited spectrum. The issues to be canvassed include determining eligibility and representation of community interests, determining spectrum availability and competition for air time, new aspirants and probationary test transmissions and licence area determination by signal coverage. The priority for ABA is to deliver a transparent, equitable and flexible temporary broadcasting regime without diverting resources from its main planning task.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill, although small, is an important bill for the claimants of the Bohemia Downs land claim. This bill gives effect to the settlement reached by all of the claimants and is supported by all of the parties to the claim and the opposition supports the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the bill to the Senate and seek leave to incorporate my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 (the Land Rights Act) provides two ways for a grant of unalienated Crown land to be made to an Aboriginal Land Trust which holds title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Land can be granted as a result of a hearing by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner or through a statutory grant of land by including specified land in Schedule 1 of the act.

This amendment bill provides for the inclusion in Schedule 1 of the act of three parcels of land which were the subject of the Bauhinia Downs Land Claim, the Brumby Plains Land Claim and the Western Desert (North) Land Claim in the Northern Territory. In all cases, the Northern Territory Government, the relevant land council and the claimants have reached a negotiated agreement which settles the land claims without the need for a hearing by the Land Commissioner.

There are a number of benefits by proceeding to schedule the land. Most importantly, the claimants will secure title to the claim areas more expediently. In addition, proceeding by the way of scheduling eliminates the need for a costly land claim hearing and reflects the growing commitment of the parties to settle claims. Accordingly, it deserves the full support of the Commonwealth.
There are no financial implications arising from thi. bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some extensive comments to make about this, but I will be brief and then seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech. I have shown my comments to Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.PARA: I would draw to the Senate's attention that this legislation is based on a Labor initiative that was embarked upon to rewrite the income tax legislation through the tax law improvement project in 1994. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—
The process
This legislation is the second tranche of the complete rewrite of the income tax legislation embarked upon by Labor through the Tax Law Improvement Project (TLIP) in 1994.

Passage through the Senate of the first package of three bills commencing the rewrite occurred on 17 March. This legislation, which also commences on 1 July, has been laying in the Senate since March 26 and is being passed at this late hour to ensure that it is not retrospective.
Labor supports this legislation, and the project underpinning it, as it is essential that the enormously voluminous and complex income tax legislation must be simplified.

Hopefully this will both reduce compliance costs for both taxpayers and administrative costs for the Tax Office. In addition, the rewrite will also take the opportunity to improve certainty in some cases where there is currently considerable uncertainty in the operation of the law.
This whole process is necessary because the old legislation, the 1936 Act, has been amended and expanded so often that it had lost an overall coherent structure.

Because of the sheer enormity of the task the rewrite has to occur in tranches. This partial ongoing rewrite process provides its own challenges as it is not possible to repeal the entirety of the 1936 Act and replace it entirely. Labor does not criticise this process, we understand it was the only realistic option.

However, because of this process there has been some disquiet in some sections of the industry. There are a variety of opinions—some believe there should be absolutely no policy changes at all involved in the rewrite, yet some such as Judith Ward from Price Waterhouse are reported (Financial Review 11 October 1996) as arguing that the resources of the Tax Law Improvement Program should be redirected towards a tax reform taskforce. That is change policy first and then rewrite the legislation.

Clearly Labor favours the current process which we instigated. The Assistant Treasurer has the authority to make small, limited changes—especially to clarify the law. However this process should not be used to significantly alter policy, in a somewhat backdoor manner.
Labor thought that the Government agrees with this policy neutral project, however, this legislation, as introduced, goes beyond the neutral rewrite role.
The Bill

The particular tranche being rewritten in this bill includes assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. The more specialised areas include entertainment expenses and primary productions.
As with earlier bills, this bill was sent to the JCPA for consideration. The Committee has reported on the legislation, report no 348, with the report tabled in the House on 6 March.
Whilst the Committee generally endorses the neutral rewrite, it expressed concern about the relatively significant policy changes proposed within the bill.

In particular, this concern arises about the proposed alteration of the depreciation provisions concerning hire‐purchase transactions and the proposed alterations to the trading stock provisions where assets change their character from normal business assets into trading stock and vice versa.
Accordingly, the Government, with Opposition support, amended the bill substantially in the House.

The Government has now got agreement from the relevant stakeholders on some of these contentious matters—such as the trading stock provisions—and are proposing to further amend the bill to implement the agreed position.
Labor will be supporting this bill and the circulated amendments.
I make the point in closing that the Government should have resolved these issues earlier and dealt with this major bill more expeditiously.

This would have enabled the tax and accounting professions more than a mere couple of days to be expected to get across the substantial rewrite of the law, involving around 550 pages of legislation, that this bill achieves.

I acknowledge that their continues to be criticism of the Tax Law Improvement Program process from the tax profession. These views are noted by the Opposition, however, we do not think that they warrant the termination of the process—there is also a substantial body of opinion which supports the rewrite process.
In closing I mention that this legislation is being dealt with as a non‐controversial bill because some contentious provisions were removed by the Government.

I acknowledge their actions to enable the swift passage of the legislation. Although I'm not sure about the logic of the decision—because the very same matters are to be debated later today or tonight during the consideration of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 1).
However, I leave the merits of that argument to the later debate. The Opposition supports the rewrite of the law and I will not detain the Senate further.

TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)
