SPEECH.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding, I have a statement to make as Chair of Committees. I draw to the attention of the Senate the government requests for amendments to this bill which have been circulated. These requests reinstate in the bill provisions which were removed from the bill in the House of Representatives as a result of representations made to the government. The explanatory memorandum accompanying the requests makes it clear that they will result in a substantial amount of tax being paid which would not otherwise have been paid.

SPEECH.PARA: The government drafters have drafted the amendments, as requested, in accordance with their theory that amendments can be requested in the Senate to a bill which does not impose taxation where the amendments would increase the tax payable. This theory has not in the past been accepted by the Senate. The moving of such requests in the Senate results in a bill which does not impose taxation being turned into a bill which imposes taxation and therefore is in violation of paragraph 1 of section 53 of the constitution which provides that laws imposing taxation should not originate in the Senate. In effect, the provisions contained in these requests are laws imposing taxation and the making of the requests means that they have been originated in the Senate.

The proper course would be for the bill to be taken back to the House of Representatives and the provisions initiated there. No doubt this course is not acceptable to the government because of the further delay which would result in the bill being so treated. If the two Houses agree to the requests, there is no remedy against any violation of section 53, but the Senate should be aware of the situation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have a great deal of concern about the amendments in this legislation which allow a change in the cross‐media rules. We have those concerns because there is at present taking place a major review of cross‐media ownership rules in this country. It is in secret; it is behind closed doors. We do not know what is going on there, but we do know that the intention is to have a real shake‐out of those cross‐media ownership rules at the end of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems illogical, to say the least, that we have changes to the rules—even if it is argued that those changes are on the margins—occurring here in this legislation before that review has been completed. This is a fundamental issue as far as the people of Australia and democracy are concerned. We should not be having serial alterations to it—`shifting sands', as the current government accused the last government of having in its approach to cross‐media rules. It should be open, it should be transparent, and it should come after a full public debate; but that cannot be said about the changes here.

The changes involved are specifically to facilitate the O'Reilly group of Australian regional newspapers. They have run foul of the cross‐media rules because their Queensland Times, which circulates in the Ipswich region, is in breach of the provision of the rule that a proprietor not have more than half the circulation of a newspaper within an area where that same proprietor has the licence to run a radio station. To get around that, the Australian Broadcasting Authority has given permission for provincial newspapers to artificially circulate papers at no cost outside the area, so that it can say, `More than half our circulation is outside the area', whereas in fact that is not the case as far as the purchase of those newspapers by the public is concerned.

We have an artificially created loophole, and the intention in this legislation is to get around that by catering to the way in which that loophole has been created. The loophole should be closed. We should not be in the business of facilitating somebody who has found a way to get around the media ownership rules. It should be up to Mr O'Reilly and Australian Provincial Newspapers to divest themselves of whichever they wish—the newspaper or the radio station—to comply with the rules. Who else in our community is able to get government to move on legislation like this, in order to facilitate a personal interest? (Time expired)
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, is it a fact that from 1 July 1997, `Black Tuesday', child‐care fees will rise between $5 and $20 per child as a consequence of your government's funding cuts? How do you reconcile that with the statement contained in your party's policy document prior to the last election that the lack of access to affordable child care was one of the major barriers to many women entering the work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me there is only one shot in the opposition's locker at present, and that is child care. We have had questions about that throughout the week. As I have pointed out several times, it seems to me that we have an opposition that is more interested in the child‐care work force than it is in the child‐care customers, the families and the children.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also reminded in some of the questions that have been asked about child‐care centres that have been closing that we are looking at a situation that has been a very definite result of the previous government's inadequacy in child care which we are trying to address—a national child‐care planning policy which will make sure that child‐care centres are available where families need them and that there is not a plethora of child-care centres with too many places struggling to compete for the declining market or the lack of children.

In a very real way, parents have not been advantaged by the previous administration. We are putting substantial new measures in place to increase the number of places and to make sure that children and families in regional Australia will at last have access to some child care. Seventy per cent of child‐care provision in Australia is not provided through the community centres which are currently running this campaign about fees.

It seemed a very sad thing that we had an especially vociferous campaign in Tasmania from some of these child‐care centres which claimed from late last year for several months that the world was going to fall in and that they were going to have to massively increase their fees. Madam Deputy President, do you know what has happened to those child‐care centres? Some of them have frightened off the clients—to the extent that they have now joined the 70 per cent of families who are getting child care outside the community child‐care sector. That has not done those organisations much good at all. Most of them are remaining viable, but they are having to adjust their management practices so they do not put up their fees massively.

Parents are not stupid. Parents do have alternatives. Parents will vote with their feet when it comes to accessing child care, and organisations who persist in this industrial campaign by trying to put up their fees to a level that the market will not wear will lose their clientele. That is a pity because we believe in high quality, accessible child care for Australian families. The previous government's lack of planning has added to the problems of families now. The campaign being run by the union and their mates in this chamber has added to the insecurity which families feel, and they are looking for child care elsewhere rather than pay the sorts of claims that some of those friends of yours are making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I remind you that the question I asked you was: is it not a fact that fees will rise between $5 and $20 per child as a consequence of your funding cuts? Is this not inconsistent with your election commitments? I also put this to you, Minister: is it not a fact that your government policies are forcing more and more Australian women to stay at home and not enter the work force, not because they choose to but because they have no access to affordable child care? Is that not your problem, Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the Anne Summers line, and it is downright untrue. In February this year the labour force figures recorded the highest ever labour force participation rate for women—54.4 per cent. The blast from the past, including Senator Carr, who thinks he is doing a bit of blasting too, has failed utterly. The women are in the work force; they are here to stay.

ANSWER.PARA: Under our government the industrial relations scene will mean that they will have access to permanent part-time work, which your government was never supportive of because you come from such a union dominated background. Women will have a fairer go in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many in part‐time work?
—They need accessible child care, and we are increasing the number of places to 83,000 places over the next four years. Bellow as you like, those are the facts. (Time expired)

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the New Zealand House of Representatives led by the chairman of the primary production committee, Mr Eric Roy. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.
— Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. In March 1996 an overwhelming number of Australians voted for a new approach to governing our country that embodied strong leadership, a clear sense of direction and a commitment to keeping promises. Against this background, will the minister please outline to the Senate some of the major achievements of the coalition since the government came to office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a long list of the initiatives that this government has taken in keeping all of our key election promises: the family tax initiative, which will assist some two million families; private health insurance incentives, which kick in on 1 July; industrial relations reforms designed to make Australia more internationally competitive; capital gains tax relief for small business; a $1.2 billion Natural Heritage Trust Fund; and an increased tax free threshold for self-funded retirees.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of other examples of where the government is demonstrating a very clear sense of direction. The policies we are putting in place will significantly reduce unemployment over time; there is a raft of measures to enable small business to realise its potential and there is the vital role of families, small business and young people—all the initiatives we have announced in recent times; and we are now tackling major environmental problems.

BREAK.PARA: Leadership is a vital element of any successful government and, again in this category, the government has demonstrated very strong leadership in getting the budget back into order—back into surplus—something which our opponents have been vigorously opposed to. They are not interested in fiscal responsibility; they are simply prepared to wallow in deficit and debt and see Australia become an international laughing stock.

We are tackling the tough issues of tax reform. What are we getting from the opposition? Absolutely nothing on the subject. We tackled the guns issue and to date some 427,000 guns have been surrendered. Of course, the Prime Minister is currently demonstrating very strong leadership in advocating Australia's position on greenhouse to the international community. Indeed, one would have noticed in today's Financial Review a report saying that business yesterday strongly backed the continued tough stance of the Prime Minister.

It is in stark contrast to all that that we look at where Labor are going. If you look at the polls, you will see that Labor are clearly going nowhere at all. But it is worse than that because, as I would have thought even they would have realised by now, if you do not stand for something, you will fall for anything. They are now being castigated by commentators who one would have thought were not traditionally Liberal Party supporters, advocates and patsies. We had Mike Steketee the other day saying that Kim Beazley had overplayed his hand by blocking legislation on the people's convention. But, much worse than that, we had Alan Ramsey talking about Labor's obscene rollover. He starts off by saying:
Sooner or later the Labor Party will have to stop making a fool of itself if it expects despairing voters to start taking it seriously again.
This is serious stuff. We are nearly halfway through the election cycle. The voters out there are wanting to see what the alternatives are, and what do they get?

If you look at last Sunday's Age you will find that the person we thought was supposedly in control of policy formulation, Gareth Evans, is now regarded as simply someone who has been overseeing the process. In terms of the draft policy which was made available to Paul Daley—presumably by the likes of Lindsay Tanner, who will not have a bar of it—it is now being described by insiders as being very light on for anything at the cutting edge of political debate.
That is what the former Senator Evans has achieved—virtually nothing in 15 months of alternative policy formulation. If one looks at Alan Ramsey's piece just briefly again, he says:

In a rousing speech on Friday, Labor Senate leader John Faulkner recounted how working for the dole was simply the government's latest measure to blame and punish the unemployed, listed a long string of proposed Labor amendments . . .
He goes on to say:
However, Senator Faulkner humiliated himself before the Senate on Monday by announcing he was withdrawing all of Labor's proposed amendments.

It was the same with the cuts to immigration where the opposition made a lot of noise but then, of course, just rolled over. So there is a very stark contrast in terms of leadership, in terms of the sense of direction and in terms of commitment to promises. You lot don't believe in anything; we know that. That is why Wayne Goss is determined to get in here, throw aside the old guard and try to inject something. But it will not be until it is too late for the next election. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a parliamentary delegation consisting of members of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Branch Parliaments study tour, from Tonga and Tuvalu. On behalf of honourable senators I have pleasure welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both be informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, is it a fact that from 1 July, Black Tuesday, young unemployed people and rooming house residents will lose up to $12.50 per week in rent assistance? Is it not a fact that from next Tuesday single people in shared accommodation, both young and elderly, will see the real value of their rental assistance decline?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that the Senate passed legislation last December which will introduce a rate of rent assistance for people who share which is more than a couple receives. Therefore, on that basis, the government decided it was fair to change the rate for sharers from what it was previously. It is still, as I emphasise, above the rate that couples receive.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not a fact that prior to the last election you promised that a coalition government would maintain the real value of rental assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had this question a few times in various guises over the last few months and the answer is still the same. This government inherited a massive mess, in terms of national accounts—a deficit situation of over $10 billion, in which difficult decisions had to be made. We did not like being faced with those decisions. It was the previous managers who left it to us and, therefore, the responsibility for things which have any sort of downside for Australian citizens has to be worn by the Labor Party for their previous administration. I do not walk away from that; they were difficult decisions. Nevertheless, as I say, that was fair in that two people sharing are still receiving more money than a couple.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. From 1 July the government will deliver significant tax benefits for Australian families and small businesses—both groups badly neglected by the Labor Party. Will the minister outline these and other benefits flowing from the coalition government's sound and responsible economic management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon, the new Senator for Victoria, for this important and good question which really goes very much to the heart of what many Australian families, and particularly taxpayers, are concerned about. It has to be said that this government likes nothing better than to provide tax relief to business and to families. Small business, in particular, is the job generating hub of our economy.

ANSWER.PARA: We are unashamedly pro small business. We are very happy that we are able to provide small business with substantial tax relief. From next Tuesday, small business owners will be eligible for CGT rollover relief. The original measure has been bolstered by dropping the like business test—and this has been welcomed by many people in small business—and allowing the sale of companies also to qualify. At the cost of $300 million a year, this will promote small business and help create jobs.

I think it is also worth noting that, from Tuesday, small business owners will be allowed a CGT exemption on retirement. This will benefit those small business people who provide for their retirement by investing in their businesses.

We are also helping families. Families have already been able to claim the family tax initiative through the PAYE tax system or social security. Those who have not will be able to claim through their normal tax return from 1 July. The family tax initiative provides benefits to two million Australian families at a cost of $1 billion in a full year.

From 1 July, low and middle income families who have or take out private health insurance will receive a tax rebate of up to $450 per year. This initiative will cost around $600 million in a full year. As I said, this government likes nothing better than to provide tax relief to small business and to families.

How does this contrast with the policies of the Labor Party and the performance of the Labor Party? They have not got any current policies. We know that. You have got no policies. That we understand. As my colleague said, the hardest question that could be asked of this side of the chamber is: what does the Labor Party stand for? It is a question that no-one over here could answer and no-one over there could answer—let us be clear on that.

When the opposition were in government, their policy was simply: spend, tax, spend, tax and borrow. That is what it was. It is no wonder that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gary Evans, has indicated—and I will quote this because it may be of interest to senators on the other side—
Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, this is what your shadow Treasurer said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . since we are so undertaxed by any relevant international standard, there is a case for having some overall revenue increases.
That is the only known policy statement that the shadow Treasurer has put forward. In other words, it is more and more taxes.
The fact of the matter is that the government's policies are already delivering substantial results. The future prospects are bright. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, can you confirm that from 1 July, Black Tuesday, 33,000 holders of Commonwealth seniors health care cards will no longer be eligible for hearing services from Australian Hearing Services? Given that those currently with hearing aids will not have them replaced in the event that they break and that Commonwealth senior health care card holders currently without hearing aids will not be eligible for them, isn't this just a heartless cut aimed at people who are most in need of government support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —We are getting a re-run of last year's sad, gloom and doom stories from the Labor Party. These are all things that were debated in this chamber over many months last year. It is a pretty clear indication that question time under this opposition that has been in opposition now for 15 months is not going anywhere very fast. They are a pretty ineffective opposition. You better stay in opposition a bit longer and learn the job a bit better.
—What about an answer to the question?

—I am afraid that the answer to this question comes into a similar category to the previous question I answered. We had to make difficult decisions in the first budget which were forced upon us by the financial mess which we inherited.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, Australians understand that that was a tough budget but a fair budget in the circumstances in which we found ourselves. Our next budget still maintained our efforts at fiscal responsibility, to the long-term good of Australians of all ages, seniors included, because we are hoping by the next budget that Australia's accounts will at last be in surplus. That is a big turnaround from what we inherited.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: Senator Newman was asked a specific question about whether 33,000 holders of Commonwealth seniors health care cards—

—It is true, from next Tuesday—whether they will no longer be eligible for hearing services from Australian Hearing Services. Senator Foreman went on and asked a number of other detailed questions on the same matter. Madam Deputy President, could you please direct Senator Newman to have a stab, just this once, at answering the question.
—Minister, I am sure you are about to get to some of the specific parts of the question.
—Actually, Madam Deputy President, I was coming to the end of my answer. I did not think there was anything useful for them to learn.
—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how much does the government expect to save from withdrawing this benefit from the elderly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to get that answer from the Minister for Health and Family Services for you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the acting Minister for the Environment, Senator Parer. I would like to pursue the Prime Minister's claim that legally binding uniform targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions would lead to a 20 per cent wage cut by the year 2020. Can you tell us whether the initial research behind this outrageous claim was later withdrawn after the modelling was disputed by a leading economist? Can you also tell us if this claim is based on the assumption that a carbon tax is introduced by government and simply kept in the public purse with no redistribution?

QUESTION.PARA: Isn't it just as valid to argue, for example, that binding targets could lead to a doubling in pensions, funded by ABARE's projected carbon tax, or perhaps that there would be no cut in take-home pay at all if other taxes were cut? Hasn't the Prime Minister been left badly exposed to ridicule at the highest level of international relations by being advised to promote this outrageous and suspect claim? Who advised him? Did you advise him? If you did not advise him, who did?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, there is no doubt about Senator Lees. She is a masochist, isn't she? She is a real devil for punishment. I might say from the outset that to assist the Democrats I have asked ABARE to distribute this document, from the ABARE Current Issues series, which is called International climate change policy: economic implications for Australia . The aim of this is to try to educate the Democrats. I hope that they do read it carefully. Let me point this out. In an ABARE issues paper—this is the one to which I refer—two Megabare simulations were run to demonstrate the economic consequences of uniform greenhouse emissions. Both simulations are for OECD countries. There is a less stringent and a more stringent scenario.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the less stringent scenario, OECD countries reduce their CO2 emissions from fossil fuel to 1990 levels by 2010, and further reduce emissions to 10 per cent below 1990 levels by the year 2020. The welfare loss for an Australian under the less stringent scenario is 22 times more than for a European and six times more than for an American.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us all the assumptions in the model.

—Senator Kernot says, `Tell us all the assumptions in the model.' I think you might have put a question or a request for this. We will give you this. We will get a truck to deliver them. I hope you enjoy reading all the equations, Senator Kernot. I could not help noticing Senator Kernot was wont, as most of the Democrats are, to put out one of those breathless press releases yesterday. An interesting thing is that they used to say—I have not heard it for a long time—they are here to keep us honest. Do you remember that? They said they were here to keep us honest.

—Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order on relevance. I specifically asked about the Prime Minister's claims that we were going to see, by the year 2020, a 20 per cent wage cut in this country. Can we please have that question answered?
—Order! Minister, I am sure you—

—The answer, Madam Deputy President, is that I indicated that it was 22 times greater. Senator, when you receive this document, you will notice that in it there is a graph. It is fairly simple, which means, I hope, you will understand it. It talks about reductions in real wages with less stringent emission reductions in OECD countries. It shows the figure. I am not entirely correct with 20 per cent. I would like to correct that figure for the records of the Senate. It is, in fact, 19 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The other comment I would like to make is that yesterday Senator Lees asked a question about how we could justify a figure of something like $1,800 or $1,900 per person in Australia—which I reminded her was the present net value of welfare losses with emission reductions in selected OECD countries. I would like to correct that figure. I said it was substantially higher; I was not sure what it was. That figure is about $US6,500 in present net value terms—in other words, about $A8,500 to $A9,000. I think I have answered the question. It is ABARE—
Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not like ABARE, Senator? It does not support what you want? All I can do is remind you, as I did yesterday. It is about time that you did what the Labor Party did yesterday—it took a lot of time—and come on board and do things that are going to be for the benefit and the interests of Australia, at the same time addressing global emissions. (Time expired)

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. That document that you have referred to is the one that was challenged and withdrawn. It never made it any further. It never made it into the reports. It never made it into your modelling—thank goodness! So I challenge you, Minister. You told the Senate that Megabare was refereed by two bodies: domestically by the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University, and by the Wilfred Laurier University in Canada (by Randy Wygle). I ask you, Minister—or rather I challenge you—to put the referees' comments on the table and tell us whether or not you made any changes to the models as a result of the referees' comments.
—I think you are flogging a dead bear, Meg.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the interjection from Senator Bob Collins says it all. The Megabare model—I do not know how often I have got to say this—is internationally recognised. Every model has its pluses and has its minuses. There is no such thing as a perfect computer model—there is no such thing. But it is internationally recognised. I might say to you that ABARE, over the last 50 years, has given independent advice to governments of all shades—not just to this government, but to the previous government as well. If you have got a better champion, whether it be Clive Hamilton or his mate Jacob, get up and say so.
—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former Senator Sid Spindler. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, can you confirm that from 1 July, Black Tuesday, people receiving payments of up to $5,400 will no longer receive a beneficiary rebate, pensioner rebate or low income rebate, while those receiving more than $5,400 will have their rebate calculated differently? Can you confirm that, as a consequence of this measure, the Australian Taxation Office has calculated that 210,000 people will pay more tax? Can you also confirm that, according to the same calculations, another 220,000 Australians who previously paid no tax will become taxable to some degree? Can you also confirm that an unknown number of people who were non‐taxable and lodged no returns will now be taxable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome that question from Senator Conroy. It is pleasing that Senator Conroy has had the guts to put his face up after the appalling comment he made last week. It is nice to see that courage has returned to you, Senator Conroy. I refer of course to the comment you made on the capacity of former Labor members of parliament to get jobs. It is good to see you back on your feet again.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, Senator Conroy was not listening to the answer I gave to Senator Synon, who showed the interest that we have in providing sensible tax relief to Australian families. Senator Conroy, in your question you did not mention that we will be providing tax benefits through the family tax initiative to up to two million Australian families at a cost of $1 billion a year.

You also did not mention the tax rebate of up to $450 per year that we are going to give for private health insurance. That will be at a cost to revenue of some $600 million. The reality is that families are going to benefit very substantially, Senator Conroy, from the measures that we have announced.

You raised a question in relation to the beneficiary rebate, a question which, I might say, was asked by your leader in the other place and was extremely well answered, I thought. I refer you, Senator Conroy, to the answer that the Treasurer gave to your leader when he posed this question.

The basic objective of the beneficiary rebate is that a person receiving the full rate of benefit for the full year with no other taxable income should not have to pay any tax. Do you understand that? This objective is still achieved with the revised formula. Under the previous formula, many benefit recipients received more rebate than they needed to offset the tax on their benefits. There is no reason why someone with $1 of benefit should get the beneficiary rebate when someone with a similar income but with no benefit receives no rebate.

If you go back and see how that formula works, Senator Conroy, you will see just what a silly question you have posed to this chamber. When you look at the major tax relief that this government is delivering to small business and to Australian families, there is no question that we are the low tax government and you come from a party which was a high tax government. That is the difference between us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that at least 430,000 Australians will be worse off as a result of these measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, don't you listen to the answers that are given to you? I have explained to you the changes in the revised formula for the beneficiary rebate. We have explained that to you. I would have thought that the logic behind that simply could not be rejected. But if you are worried about tax relief to Australian families, let me refer you once again, Senator Conroy, to the family tax initiative, a major election promise which is being delivered to Australian families in full and on time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, I refer to the situation in Hong Kong, which is being taken over again by China on Monday. Is the minister aware of reports, such as the one in today's Herald‐Sun , that democratically elected leaders fear arrest. Martin Lee, for the Democrats, the biggest party, has said, `We are at their mercy.' Emily Lau, from the Frontier group, has said, `They will wipe us out.' I ask what representations Australia is making or will make through the foreign minister attending the functions on Monday on behalf of the democratic process—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown, can you just hold it a minute, please. Can I just have some order, because I do not know if the minister can hear the question fully, but I certainly cannot hear the question through the noise on both sides.
—Order! Can I have some silence on both my left and right so that I can hear the question. Senator Brown, have you completed the question?

—No, Madam Deputy President. I want to know from the minister what representations have been made to the Chinese government to assure the safety, the liberty and the freedom to operate of those democratically elected leaders in Hong Kong after the handover and what measures the government will take if their fears are realised. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian government is clearly very concerned about the changeover arrangements. Certainly that is why Mr Downer will be in attendance. This underlines the support of the Australian government for the new Hong Kong special administrative regime.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not in anyone's interests that the new Hong Kong special administrative region should begin its life in controversy. We want the concept of `one country—two systems', promised by the People's Republic of China, to be given a chance to work. It is important that Australia as a country with an extensive stake in Hong Kong does all it can to ensure a successful and smooth transition and to signal its support and understanding at this important time.

The Australian government's position on the provisional legislature is well‐known. It was disappointing that Britain and China were not able to agree that Hong Kong's current Legislative Council should serve out its full term and that China thought it necessary to establish a provisional legislature.

Our concern over that outcome has not changed. The provisional legislature is an interim body. The government expects that elections for a legislative council will be held as soon as possible after the transfer of sovereignty on 1 July 1997, consistent with undertakings by China under the 1984 Sino‐British Joint Declaration and China's 1990 Basic Law for Hong Kong to provide an elected legislative council for Hong Kong.

There will understandably be concerns expressed by those who have been in positions of legislative authority in Hong Kong and who have some concerns about the way in which the transition will be affected. We have taken the view that China does deserve support. We are prepared to accept the assurances that have been given to date. We do not think one should be all doom and gloom on the prospects. We do believe there will be every opportunity to ensure that Hong Kong retains its special status and that it does, indeed, end up with a system of government that reflects the interests of those who remain there and who are prepared to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I did not ask the minister about policy. I asked about action. I ask the minister again: what specific action has the government taken to get from the Chinese authorities specific assurances about the safety both to operate and to stay free of arrest, as they fear, of the democratically elected leaders in Hong Kong after the takeover on Monday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any threats that have been made. As I say, there may be concerns that could be held by people such as Martin Lee, but the Australian government's position is clear. We have made it known to the Chinese authorities that we expect the transition to be a seamless one. We do not believe that disruptions to the process will be in the interests of any of those who have held contrary views under the previous arrangements. We are very confident that that will be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no doubt that when Mr Downer is there he will make the Australian government's position very clear. In the business of diplomacy, Senator Brown, that is the most effective way of expressing your point of view. They do not have paddy wagons to climb into. Mr Downer is not going over there with a team of cameras. He is not prepared to grandstand. He will make the Australian government's position clear in the manner that is the most effective, and he will do that by making representations to the authorities in the appropriate manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, are you aware that last year 70 per cent of taxpayers who were audited were found to have made mistakes, which resulted in their having to pay back $67 million in additional tax? Are you aware that, as from next Tuesday, taxpayers will have to wrestle with 10 pages of `ridiculous, complex and confusing calculations'?
—In your view.
—No, they are the words of the National Tax and Accountants Association, Minister.
—Bad luck, Richard.

—Bad luck, Richard. I will just repeat that for the Minister: `ridiculous, complex and confusing calculations', in the words of the National Tax and Accountants Association, in order to claim the family tax rebate. Minister, will you ensure that those who inevitably make mistakes in their calculations will not be penalised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have an attack on the family tax initiative, which has been welcomed throughout the Australian community. Up to two million families will benefit at a cost of $1 billion. So what do the Labor Party do? They get up and then they carry on. Isn't it a terrible thing that all these Australian families are going to receive these huge benefits? Isn't that an awful thing? It is incredible. It shows you how far the Labor Party have sunk that they could get up and attack the family tax initiative. That is what they are attacking.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht, I do not know whether you have seen the Tax Pack. I think even someone as silly as Senator Schacht could fill it in. If you were entitled to it, Senator Schacht, even you would be able to get it right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—I am sorry, Senator Alston. I do not agree with you there. I think that even Senator Schacht, who is not the brightest on a very dim frontbench, could certainly fill it in.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make this clear to you, Senator Schacht. We make no apology for the family tax initiative. We want to help Australian families, Senator Schacht, and we are delivering on time and in full. It was a major election promise. I suggest it shows what the Keating Labor Party is really like. Their frontbench is littered with former ministers of the Keating government. The only thing they can do is to get up and attack the family tax initiative. They are truly hopeless.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I point out to the minister that it was the National Tax and Accountants Association which described the 10 pages—
—And Watson's a member.

—Watson's a member. They described those pages as having `ridiculous, complex and confusing calculations'. Minister, I give you one more chance to answer the question to clarify for taxpayers, who make unfortunate mistakes in trying to fill those 10 pages in, that they will not be penalised because of the confusing document that your tax department and your government have put together.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Give him all the support you can, Johnny, because he really needs it. He is the dope who got up and attacked the family tax initiative. How absolutely hopeless! Senator Schacht, the forms are out. The forms can be filled in even by someone like you. The tax commissioner always takes some account of unintended mistakes, Senator Schacht. So I do not think you have to worry about that.

—My question is to Senator Newman, Minister for Social Security and Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, next Tuesday is 1 July, and it is promising to be one of the most significant days for average Australian families for some time. Several government initiatives are to commence on 1 July, providing assistance to low and middle income families. What benefits will families be receiving from next Tuesday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that Senator Macdonald is interested in what good things are available for families on `Bright Tuesday'. The Labor Party seems to have no interest in things that will benefit Australia's families. They are simply not interested in looking after families. The lot opposite, of course, are the ones who kicked the Australian family, month after month, for 13 years; they left them with a government debt of $600 million and denied their kids the hope of work. That is how much they cared about Australian families.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling calculated that the average Australian family lost $12 a week over the Labor years. So much for their care for Australian families—$12 a week taken out of the pockets of middle Australia. Not only did things not get better under Labor; families actually went backwards. The Howard government is not about kicking families; we are about helping them.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Macdonald said, 1 July is the day on which these families get greater recognition. In social security, there are many very good measures, such as increased help for carers and the continuation of family service centres. These will be built on by other measures announced in the recent budget, such as the more than minimum family payment for families who have a child going overseas for up to eight weeks, and an increased maternity allowance. These are measures for families which we will see in the coming year.

The two measures on which I want to focus are the family tax initiative and the private health insurance incentives. Let us be very clear about this: the family tax initiative is a tax cut for families. Labor, as we know, increased all sorts of taxes. We are cutting tax for families. Approximately 800,000 have already received their benefits through social security or their pay packets. For those claiming the family tax initiative through their tax return, 1 July is the day from which they can get their tax cut. One million families will benefit in that way after 1 July. They will get $200 for every child, and for single income families, including sole parents, there is an extra $500 a family. That will be a very great help. All up, two million Australian families will benefit from this family tax initiative which recognises the dedication and hard work involved in raising children.

Nearly 1,300,000 families will also benefit on 1 July when they receive, for the first time, help to pay for private health insurance—$450 a family, cutting their insurance bills by up to 20 per cent so that they can have the security and confidence of health cover. This, at the same time, ensures that the resources of the public hospital system are targeted to those in need. Labor tried to ignore the vicious cycle of declining insurance coverage in an over‐stretched public system. Labor hoped it would just go away, but we have been prepared to act and people have responded.

It is interesting—although the people opposite do not seem to want to hear—that the health funds in Australia have had to put on staff to deal with inquiries. I am informed that the department of health's hotline has been swamped, with 2,000 calls a day for the last five weeks. Opposition senators may not want to know that, because they would not recognise their need, but Australian families have recognised that we are helping. They called out for help under Labor; they got no help at all. They got no help on tax cuts recognising the costs of raising children, no help on health insurance for families. But we are different—we are here for Australia's mothers and fathers and their children, and 1 July will be a very bright Tuesday. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order. Could I ask Senator Newman to table the document from which she read every word?
—No.
—Are they confidential documents, Minister?
—It can't be confidential; she's just read it out.
—Would you like me to table this other document? Madam Deputy President, I would like to table this family tax initiative document.

—Madam Deputy President, I take a further point of order. Now that Senator Newman has tabled the document she wasn't requested to table, could she give consideration to tabling the document from which she read every word?
—No.

—My question is directed to the acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Victorian government's abandonment of its proposal to relocate the Coode Island facility to Point Lillias. Is it not the case that Senator Hill and the entire cabinet were persuaded by Mr Kennett's argument that this relocation was a matter of `urgent national interest'? What has happened to the urgent national interest now? When did Mr Kennett inform you that it had evaporated? Is it true that Mr Kennett is now citing environmental considerations as the reason for his decision, and why is it that Mr Kennett is more concerned about the environment than the federal government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the national interest is what is paramount in this decision. The Victorian government had the opportunity to consider Point Lillias. It did that exhaustively through a consultative process. It has now decided that it is going to consider bringing the Coode Island facility up to world's best practice. The judgment on this is a matter for Victoria. The Victorian opposition and the federal opposition are reported as wanting to move the Coode Island facility from Port Melbourne.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth was asked by the government of Victoria to excise 20 hectares from the Commonwealth‐listed wetland at Point Lillias. The request was made on the basis that the relocation from Coode Island was in the national interest and that an environmental package from Victoria much more than compensated for the excision. Based on the evidence provided by Victoria and the compensation package, the Commonwealth agreed to this proposal. The government is very conscious of its environmental responsibilities, which is why we are providing $11 million for the national wetlands program under the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Didn't Senator Hill tell a Senate estimates committee on 9 May that if the Victorian government changed its mind—and I will quote Senator Hill—`we would be all very embarrassed'? Are you all very embarrassed? You did not sound too embarrassed just a moment ago. Isn't this decision a slap in the face for Senator Hill, in his absence, and the entire federal government? Will cabinet now reverse its decision to excise land from the Ramsar listed wetland at Point Lillias?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Collins was at the estimates committee hearings, but if she was then she—
—Is that relevant?
—Oh, I see—it is not relevant. If you are quoting from a meeting you did not attend then I would have hoped you would quote accurately—
—What about the quote. Don't you read Hansard .
—Just a moment. I am talking to you about quoting—
—Senator Alston, if you were to talk to the chair you would go much better.
—Senator Hill's commitment at the estimates process was that the Commonwealth—
—I read Hansard .

—Just a moment. If you listen you will learn. Senator Hill's commitment was that the Commonwealth would excise the wetlands in the event that the project did not go ahead. On the basis that the project is not going ahead there is no commitment to excise so we are not embarrassed.
—Oh, you're not? Senator Hill is.

—Senator Hill is no more embarrassed than anyone else. The only people who are embarrassed are those who find difficulty in accepting a rational decision—one that was made after a great deal of consultation. It was a decision made by the Victorian government that has always had responsibility for it. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President. My question—

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my right!
—Order on my left and right! You have the call, Senator Lees.

—Obviously the government is getting very uncomfortable with continuing questions on greenhouse. This is the Democrats' ninth question to the minister on greenhouse. Do you remember your record pause when we asked you to confirm the referees you claimed had examined the Megabare model in December last year? Today you are very reluctant—indeed I do not think you have agreed—to table their reports. Do you remember laughing off changes to rainfall patterns, saying it would help farmers who need more rain? Do you remember personally denigrating top economists who disagreed with you—and you had another go at them today? Would you care to hazard a guess as to how many interjections you have relied upon to fill up your time?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want an answer to this last question minister: do you care about global warming?
—What's the question?
—Order! Minister, did you hear the question?
—No.
—The minister did not hear the last part of the question, Senator Lees. Could you please repeat it.
—I ask the minister finally to give us a clear answer as to whether or not he cares at all about global warming, and why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is very conscious of the fact that there probably has been human intervention which has had an effect on global warming.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the comment that has been made, and we accept that. I am trying to answer and I could if it was not for big mouth over there.
—Can I have some order in the chamber.

—We are prepared to address it globally in a fair and equitable way. I have said over and over again—and I will say it again—Australia's contribution to global CO2 gas emissions is 1.4 per cent. If, as I said yesterday, you close the whole country down and get rid of not only the sheep but also the belching cows the effect globally would be minimal. Notwithstanding that, we are prepared to address it in a fair and equitable way.

BREAK.PARA: The position we have taken as a government (and I notice in the last 24 hours that we have the belated support of Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Beazley) is that we are not prepared to accept legally binding fixed target emissions—in other words, emissions that are mandated. The reason for that is that we believe that we can address it through a process of differentiation. I know that you do not like differentiation, because it appears that you tend to represent the vocal minority or vocal communities from some other parts but not Australia. We are prepared to address this in a way that is not just fair and equitable but will not harm the economic prospects of this country.

The view taken by the European Union is that they do not agree with our differentiation process. Yet they are practising it themselves. There is enormous inconsistency between what the European Union is saying they can do and what they say we cannot do. If we go down the route the Democrats want to go, we would put at risk our major industries in Australia and the jobs that go with them. We are talking about reducing enormously one of our major export industries, the coal industry. One of the good things about coal that comes from this country is that it is relatively clean compared to other coals around the world.

You are going to put at risk the energy intensive industries. Are you going to say this to me? We have proposals before us for expansions on the North West Shelf for gas. That gas will go to other countries, particularly in the Asian regions, to replace dirty types of fuels. In the process it is going to emit CO2. From a global perspective, the further development of the North West Shelf is going to be the benefit of the global CO2 emissions. That seems to be sort of thing you are pushing.

I know that you are going to get up and say, `Let's talk about renewables.' That is what I was referring to before in the previous question you asked, because of Senator Kernot's remarks. There is a market out there for renewables, and it is a growing market. I do not dispute that. But in the breathless statement put out by Senator Kernot yesterday she did not get her figures right. Her gross figures were right, because she talked about employment in the renewables sector. Of the 6,400 people, 5,000 are involved either in hydro‐electricity or wood heater manufacture. The Democrats oppose both of those. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. One can understand the coal industry's determination to do whatever they can to stop Australia signing on to binding targets. If we sign on, we will probably have to reduce our use of coal as we increase our use of solar, wind and other sources. We can understand the coal industry working internationally to undermine international efforts because, if internationally we accept targets, the coal industry will probably sell less coal overseas. But if we retrain those coal workers that we are so worried about, bring them up from underground and actually put them into new, clean, green technologies, they will still have jobs. Your modelling does not take into account all the positives that should be there. So, Minister, while we can understand the coal industry's position, surely the government cannot be excused for simply swallowing their line hook, line and sinker, and for going out internationally and selling the coal industry's line.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I do not know that there was a question—
—I am still looking for one.
—But I think I know what it is all about. I think if there was some balance from the Democrats the general public could understand it.

ANSWER.PARA: What you are saying is, `Let's get rid of the coal industry.' You do not believe in any increase in hydro. The real facts are that, in the foreseeable future, base load power stations to provide electricity, not only to industry but to households, will come from coal or gas. In the UK, where they have taken such a high and mighty position at the moment, they closed their coalmines because they were inefficient. Do you know that they generate 25 per cent of their electricity by nuclear power?

BREAK.PARA: There are only three major things you can use for base load power stations: coal, gas and nuclear. Are you suggesting that we switch to nuclear? That is the alternative to base load power stations. As regards renewables, there is a market, but it is a niche market. It is a growing market—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services: Training Workshops

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have some additional information for Senator Gibbs following a question that I took yesterday. I request that the answer be incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The answer reads as follows—

Senator Gibbs: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, how do you justify the Department of Health and Family Services paying over $1 million to a consultancy firm, People First International, to conduct training workshops over the next 18 months for the department's senior executive officers? Isn't it true that this $1 million would restore more than two years' funding for the Community Sector Support Scheme which your government has cut?
Supplementary Question

Senator Gibbs: I appreciate that but I think it is a bit of a cop‐out. While you are asking the Minister, could you also ask her whether it is true that the Combined Pensioner and Superannuants' Federation, the Australian Community Health Association and the Family Planning Association, who were all funded under the Community Sector Support Scheme, have now had their funding cut? Are you saying to these groups that $1 million is better spent on departmental training workshops than on them?

SPEECH.PARA: The funds in question are from two separate appropriations. Running costs and program funds are not interchangeable. The Department of Health and Family Services advises that People First International has been contracted to design and deliver leadership training to approximately 800 of the Department's senior management staff, at SES and Senior Officer levels. People First International will be paid close to $1 million for 40 programs, over an 18 month period. The programs are essential to assist senior staff in their leadership role and in their management of $22 billion worth of programs in a rapidly changing environment.

National Secretariat funding under the Community Sector Support Scheme was recently reviewed. Some organisations will not be funded as a result of the review. Others, including the Carers' Association, Australian Council for Volunteering, Heart Support Australia and the Deafness Forum, will now be supported under this program. The current appropriation for the Community Sector Support Scheme was not reduced as a result of the review.
The management of staff in public service departments is a matter for Departmental management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Sherry in relation to Australia Post. I said I would be seeking further information on this matter. My response is as follows. The surcharge was introduced as an equity measure, meaning that superannuation remains attractive for high income earners but not as concessional as previously.

SPEECH.PARA: The government believes that it is not appropriate to cushion high income earners from the surcharge by passing it on to customers of GBEs. The government will be writing to all GBEs to advise them of its views on this matter, and we will be suggesting to Australia Post and other GBEs that they review the manner in which they treat the superannuation surcharge.

The accountability and other regulatory arrangements that currently apply to Australia Post and the other GBEs were established by the former Labor government. These arrangements are designed to improve the efficiency of GBEs by moving them towards a commercial basis. These arrangements limit interference by the government in detailed matters of administration of Australia Post and other GBEs, including remuneration matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Jacinta Collins this day, relating to the Coode Island chemical storage facility.

Some three months ago this government accepted the advice of the Victorian government that the movement of the Coode Island facility to Point Lillias was a matter of national significance, a matter of national interest. At Coode Island we have a chemical waste dump facility some four kilometres from the central business district of Melbourne. It is surrounded by many tens of thousands of residents throughout the western suburbs of Melbourne. It is a very dangerous facility within half a kilometre of residents of Yarraville in Melbourne.

This is a facility which, according to the Victorian government only three months ago, as a matter of urgent national interest should be relocated. At the time Senator Hill said, before the estimates committee, that this government would be very embarrassed if the Kennett government actually changed its mind.

I raise this question: what was it three months ago that, in the national interest, was forcing the removal of this dangerous facility to Point Lillias but now is no longer forcing this in the national interest? What is it that has changed in those three months? Why was it that this government was so prepared to turn aside from its international obligations under the Ramsar convention to move this stuff as a matter of urgent national interest? Why is this government now so meekly prepared to accept the change of heart in Victoria to endanger so many people in the city of Melbourne? If it was of national interest three months ago, why is it not now still a matter of national interest?

It is not surprising that this matter is being treated seriously in Victoria. It has been the position of the Victorian government since 1990—that is, of the Victorian government under Labor. In 1990, the coalition in opposition committed to moving Coode Island away from Melbourne. Following that, of course, were the horrendous events surrounding the fire of 1991.

I recall that fire. I lived in a house less than a kilometre away from the site. I actually stood on a railway bridge overlooking that fire, watching the firefighters trying to deal with that menace and watching that toxic cloud drift across the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. So I understand in a very personal way what the real dangers are to the people of Melbourne through the location of such a dangerous facility in an environment where the risk of serious loss of life is so great. How is it the case—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you still live there?
—No, I do not, as a matter of fact.
—Moved up‐market a bit, have you?

—I live up‐market all right, in the Paris end of Broadmeadows; really up‐market in Pascoe Vale. What I ask, though, is this, on behalf of the residents of the western suburbs of Melbourne: what action is this government taking to force the removal of this extraordinarily dangerous facility from Coode Island to some safer location? If this government was prepared to so meekly accept the advice three months ago of the Kennett government that this was in the national interest, why now is it not pressuring the Victorian government to actually move this facility? Why is it not finding out why, suddenly, there has been such an enormous change in attitude in Melbourne?

BREAK.PARA: I recall the way in which the Victorian government dealt with the casino and the amazing lengths they went to to subvert any possible planning restrictions on the casino in Melbourne. I recall the extraordinary scandals that were involved in building that monstrosity on the banks of the Yarra. When it comes to this facility, look at the extraordinary lengths the Victorian government is prepared to go to to avoid its obligations and to avoid its commitments to ensure that the facility on Coode Island be moved.

The Labor Party has a very good record on this issue. It set up the procedures to ensure that relocation occurred and undertook to see that that facility was in fact moved. The Labor Party is committed to the removal of the facility from Coode Island. They would like to know what the Victorian government is doing with the amounts of money that have been allocated for the relocation of it. I would like to know what has been the relationship between the Victorian government and Terminals Pty Ltd, the company that operates Coode Island. The minister for planning in that state said just a few months ago that it was not safe, that it was not in the national interests that that facility stay where it was. He now says that the facility is safe. What has occurred in three months to make the difference? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same topic, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—A very keen Victorian, are you?

—Senator Ferguson, the reason I raise this is that, as a member of the ERCA estimates committee, in September of last year and in early February of this year I asked a number of questions of the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), who was at the table, about the Point Lillias site. I also asked him what his view was about the habitat for the orange‐bellied parrot.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to give Senator Hill his due. He gave a very comprehensive answer, knowing all about the orange‐bellied parrot, its habitat, its other habitats around south‐eastern Australia, its migratory pattern, et cetera. It was a very erudite answer and I complimented him on it at the estimates hearing at the time. I thought, `This parrot has a chance with this site at Point Lillias. If this minister has taken such an opportunity to learn about this bird, it has a chance.'

What we found with this minister was that, after knowing all of that, in the end, he crumbled under the pressure to Mr Kennett. He made it quite clear in the end that, if the Victorian government put the weights on him, he was going to roll over and excise about 20 hectares from the site and make it available for the chemical plant to be relocated from Coode Island. He got roundly condemned by us and by other people in the community for having rolled over for Jeff Kennett.

BREAK.PARA: Two days ago, Jeff Kennett rolled over on top of him and did him over. It is just as well for Senator Hill that he is over in New York, not here at the table today or yesterday, because he would have looked like a dope of the first order. What it really says is that Jeff Kennett does not give two hoots about the standing or the credibility of this government and its environment minister. A matter of only a few weeks ago Jeff Kennett and the Victorian government were saying that this was a matter that was in the urgent national interest, that a decision had to be made. That was the view of the Victorian government. What did Senator Hill say about what the situation would be if this decision of the Victorian government were not to proceed? At the estimates hearing on 14 March, he said:
The Commonwealth government has accepted Victoria's argument that there is an urgent national interest to relocate the Coode Island chemical storage facility to Point Lillias.
At estimates hearings on 9 May—less than two months ago—he said:
I think we would all be very embarrassed.

I wonder whether Senator Hill realises how lucky he is to be out of the country this week so that this embarrassment is not inflicted upon him personally, publicly, right here in Australia. I can assure the Senate that when he returns in the next session of parliament, he will be reminded here and in the estimates committee of his embarrassment.

The final point is that I think this situation really does say something about Jeff Kennett's view of this federal government. He can treat it with contempt; he can put the weights on it. He can break arms to get decisions that he believes at a particular time suit him. When something does not suit him, he can drop the decision and leave a federal minister—the No. 3 minister of the Liberal Party of Australia, the leader the coalition government in the Senate—looking awfully embarrassed. I think that is a further interesting point about what Jeff Kennett thinks of this government.

All I can say in conclusion is that, as one who raised the question about the habitat of the orange‐bellied parrot, I do hope the government can now reconsider this matter and can put back into the habitat the 20 acres they excised. I think that would be at least a partial recovery, but it will not save this minister from his awful embarrassment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This result is a bad result for the people of Melbourne but a good one for the Friends of Point Lillias. I want to talk about that for a few minutes. The Friends of Point Lillias did a lot of work. No doubt they came to Senator Kemp's office, and he would have given them some assistance in their attempt to save Point Lillias. The organisers of that particular group, Rosemary Faris and Kathy Barker, did outstanding work in trying to preserve this particular area that had been declared under the Ramsar agreement. Not only were they intent upon doing as much as they could for this area, the Wathaurong Aboriginal Cooperative was also foremost in trying to preserve this area. I mention the protection committee, which consisted of Trevor Edwards, Lynne McInnes, Allan Browning and Ernie Kinsey, who had a lot to do with my office.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of all the work that was done, in spite of, no doubt, the sympathy of all Victorian senators, it was thought proper to sacrifice—and that is a word I use advisedly—this area. In spite of what the Aboriginal community wanted, in spite of what the local community wanted and in spite of what the world heritage people wanted, the moving of the facilities at Coode Island was so important that all those things had to be sacrificed.

What would a reasonable person say about the decision now to leave the facilities at Coode Island? As far as we knew, a week ago all these people were to be frustrated in their attempts to save this area. That frustration came about because of what the state government said about the need to shift the facilities at Coode Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —It isn't safe.

—If it was so unsafe, why has it suddenly now become safe? I take up Senator Carr's interjection. If it was so important to shift the Coode Island facilities to this pristine land, this great example of the natural heritage of Australia, then the danger presented by Coode Island must be great indeed. No reasonable government, no reasonable Premier, no reasonable Prime Minister and no reasonable environment minister would be prepared to sacrifice Point Lillias unless the danger from Coode Island was so great as to justify it.
—Will he sacrifice the people of the western suburbs? That is the issue now.

—Senator Carr, that seems to be the issue here. Senator Ferguson and Senator Calvert understand that the people of Melbourne must be under threat. Why else would your government and you, Senator Calvert, as one of its most eminent members, be prepared to sacrifice a place like Point Lillias unless the danger at Coode Island was so great? The potential danger to the parrots at Port Lillias resulting from the shifting of facilities at Coode Island has now been left to the people of Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed here is an explanation, a full explanation, to the people of Victoria, to the people of Melbourne and to the people of Australia. Why is it now `safe' to leave this facility at Coode Island? It cannot be. This issue is not capable of being resolved by simply saying that things have now changed. A full and complete examination must be made of the facilities at Coode Island and a conclusion reached as to just how safe these facilities are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the previous three speakers with some interest. None of them seemed to offer a solution to the problem before us.
—Move it. That is what I am saying. Move it.
—Where to? Where to?
—To a safe Tory seat will do for a start.

—To a safe Tory seat. Give us a suggestion. You have obviously looked into this very closely, Senator Carr. You have obviously done a lot of work on it. Perhaps you can give us the locality and explain why you think, in environmental terms, that is the appropriate place to put it. I think we can even give leave for you to speak again if you have a sensible solution as to where it should be, a solution that meets all of the Commonwealth's fairly strict environmental guidelines—
—Are you recommending another inquiry?
—and the Victorian government's guidelines. I would like to hear what the Labor Party proposes.
—What about another inquiry?

—It is easy to get up and criticise, but tell us what your solutions are. It is typical of the Labor Party. They get up and criticise, criticise, criticise but never have a constructive thought. Tell us what your policy is about. Tell us what you think we should do.

SPEECH.PARA: In case you have not worked it out, this is the federal parliament. The Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, has responsibilities under the Commonwealth laws relating to the environment. What Senator Hill has done has been appropriate and correct and completely in accordance with processes. You would all be aware of the particular facts of the matter.

You know now that there has apparently been some change in the Victorian government's mind on relocating the Coode Island facility and that the Commonwealth has now decided that it will not excise the 20 hectares from the Port Phillip Bay Ramsar wetland. That is appropriate. In this instance Senator Hill and the Commonwealth government have done exactly what they were supposed to do.

If you people cannot get your colleagues in Victoria to run those political points in that parliament, why do you bother coming here to do it? We have a lot of Commonwealth matters that we want to deal with in this parliament. We have some major issues to be put through the Senate before we rise in a couple of days. Yet, you people seem to be running a Victorian political campaign which obviously—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look after the western suburbs.

—Well, obviously your colleagues in state parliament cannot do it. They are pretty useless, I know, but you seem to be indicating that you have no confidence in the ability of your state colleagues to make whatever political point you think might be appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: In all instances, the Commonwealth government has been very correct with, and very careful of, the environment—just as we always are. The Labor Party runs the old line of criticise, criticise. You might recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is what it did when the government tried to make the greatest investment ever in our natural heritage. The Labor Party opposed it all the way through. Do you remember? We wanted to sell one-third of Telstra, and the Labor Party did all in its power to stop us. It fought us right to the wire so that we could not get that money to invest in our natural heritage. That is typical of the Labor Party all the way through. Cringe, cringe, cringe, whinge, whinge, whinge, and no constructive comments or suggestions whatsoever.

We have a great environmental record. Senator Hill, through his great enthusiasm and his ability to understand the problems—as he has demonstrated in this Point Lillias matter—has shown himself clearly to be the best environment minister that this parliament has ever seen. He has proved just what a sensitive and understanding environment minister he is.

The Labor Party obviously has no interest in this matter. Its members try to act as henchmen for their Victorian colleagues, who are too useless to do it themselves. They wander away when the facts are put to them.

Certainly, in this Parliament, in this chamber, we have nothing at all to worry about. We have dealt with this matter very appropriately, just as Senator Hill always does. It is a pity that the Labor Party cannot get on to the real issues and put forward some constructive suggestions on what should be done to correct this position. I hope that Senator Murphy, from Tasmania, now will get up and help the Victorians—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison is first.
—He will be after Senator Allison.
—Senator Allison is first. I would like to hear Senator Murphy's suggestions on how he can help his Victorian colleagues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I want to say that the Democrats did welcome the decision not to go to Point Lillias. However, as my colleagues have pointed out, this government has egg on its face.
