Indeed, Senator Hill said during estimates, in response to my question about the urgent national interest, that, yes, it would be most embarrassing for this government and no doubt the Victorian government to turn their backs on that decision to excise a very important part of Victoria, a very important Ramsar site in Port Phillip Bay.

SPEECH.PARA: The government will have to wear that embarrassment, because some weeks ago I went down to have a look at Coode Island. I examined the fire services that have been installed there. I looked at the way in which, for instance, there is nitrogen drenching into the top of each of the storage tanks to prevent them from exploding in the way the last fire back in 1991 was caused. Altogether, $18 million has been spent on that site. It was very clear to me at the time—as it should have been very clear to the Commonwealth government also—that there was no longer the same urgent national interest.

The government realised that; it realised it last year at a meeting attended by the Department of Finance, the minister's own department and several others, where concern was expressed about whether or not the Victorian state government had demonstrated an urgent national interest. We received a copy of the minutes of that meeting, and at the time we pointed this out to Senator Hill.

So there have been a number of occasions on which the minister has been warned that urgent national interest has not been demonstrated. And, of course, the decision the other day very clearly points this out.

Government senators have talked about there being no other option, but I would like to put one today—and that is, that we take a really close look at the need for us to store chemicals in the longer term. I think we need to accept that chemicals should not be stored close to where people live—there is no doubt about that. We need to examine the use of the sorts of chemicals that are stored on a site such as this; and we need to make provision for seeing they do not pose a threat to human health in the future. The way to do that is not only to have a very strict safety regime in place but also to see that we do not keep a combined store of such materials in one place and that we do not have them close to a city. But, of course, we also do not want to destroy very important environmental considerations. For instance, we do not want to see the Ramsar site being destroyed through our moving such a complex there.

I just want to conclude my remarks by saying: yes, the minister does have a case to answer. Indeed, he should be embarrassed, because we all know that he knew at the time that there was no urgent national interest; that the work that had been done at Coode Island had satisfied those problems to some degree. I think that leaves us then with the question of why, indeed, the Commonwealth government did go along with the Victorian government's plan.

I think we saw recently with a decision over the Essendon airport that the games that are being played here between the federal government and the Victorian state government are those that indicate that neither government cares about getting the real answer—the answer to the question which will be in everybody's interest. They are more interested in games. They are more interested in the sorts of contradictions, the sort of complicity and the sorts of interparty tricks and games that are being played between those two groups. They are not so interested in the environment, and neither are they so interested in the future of either the industry or, I should say, those people who currently live around the Coode Island complex.

There is just one other point I want to make. Coode Island is actually surrounded by heavy industry. It is surrounded by a very large petroleum complex. I think this is an opportunity for us to say, `Well, these are the measures that—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the answer given to the question about the Coode Island facility. It should be of concern to all of us, in terms of the decision making process that has taken place, that in the first instance a significant national interest was found for shifting this facility, and I think rightly so. There was a very significant accident in 1991. As a result, the Victorian government set up a review process. I think they established what was called the Coode Island review panel.

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Ian Macdonald's information, the review panel I think identified five different sites. Point Lillias was not one of them but they identified five sites. Somehow Jeff Kennett did not seem to care too much about the trumped-up corella, which is what he seems to think the bird is. It is very important, from the point of view of the orange-bellied parrot, that we take all necessary measures to protect every piece of its habitat.

As honourable senators probably know, it breeds in the south-west of Tasmania, and there has been a lot of money spent. I think the minister said in answer to a question in estimates that over a very short period of time nearly half a million dollars has been spent in an effort to ensure that this bird can survive. It is registered under the Endangered Species Protection Act. The minister has every responsibility both under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the Endangered Species Protection Act to ensure that, if there was a proposal to shift this facility from Coode Island to Point Lillias, there was not going to be any impact.

What should be of concern to us is the process of decision making. How come it was of significant national interest to shift this facility one day and the next day all that suddenly changed? A lot of money has been spent by both the Victorian government and the Commonwealth government in establishing where this site can be moved to. As Senator Hill rightly identified, the government would be embarrassed if Jeff Kennett turned around and changed his mind. He did, and the government ought to be embarrassed. I hope that in future, when you are dealing with these issues, you take more account of the decision making process.

I can recall when we were in government that you used to be very critical of hasty decisions with respect to environmental matters. Indeed, we have a situation where one day there is major significant national interest for the Coode Island facility to be moved and the next day that is not the case. It is not proposed to move it anywhere but to leave it where it is. What happened to the concern, as Senator Carr and Senator Cooney said, for the residents of Melbourne with regard to leaving the facility where it is? What has changed?

I think Senator Allison pointed out that some $18 million has been spent in improving the safety of the facility. It still does not answer the question that, throughout the process, there was this claim of significant national interest to move the facility, whether $18 million was spent on it or not.

I think Senator Macdonald said, `Look, this is not a major issue. The government is addressing major issues. The people want us to participate in the process of major issues.' One thing the people of Australia do not want us participating in is some of the major issues that you have brought about—cuts to child care, work for the dole, cuts to education funding and charges for aged care. That is what the Australian people do not want.

We may as well take some time to debate matters that ought to be debated because this government, on the one hand, is taking money off the people of Australia and, on the other hand, wasting it with stupid decision making processes. It is not acceptable. The government ought to be embarrassed, and I assume it is. I am probably right in saying that is why Senator Hill is overseas and not here. He will be back, and estimates will occur again. I am quite sure some interesting questions will be put to the minister at that time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend and then move general business of motion No. 666.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I amend the motion by omitting the words `the record of all communications, whether by letter, facsimile, e-mail or telephone' and substituting the words `copies of all correspondence, whether by letter or facsimile with identifying material other than postcodes removed'. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the table by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), no later than midday on 27 June 1997, copies of all correspondence, whether by letter or facsimile, with identifying material other than postcodes removed, received by the Minister and by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) from community organisations, businesses, corporations or individuals expressing interest in being sponsors under the Government's work for the dole program, as contained in the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill 1997.

Minister David Kemp has repeatedly asserted, even in question time today, that he has been inundated with expressions of interest from potential sponsors of work for the dole schemes. I do not disbelieve him. I think that is quite likely. The interesting thing is that this is before such expressions of interest have been formally called for. The Democrats thought it would be appropriate to see, to be able to look at and to make some judgment on the nature and the number of this correspondence.

When I first moved this return to order, I had in mind that there ought to be evidence for this repeated assertion available on the public record. One of the minister's objections was that it would not be appropriate to identify the organisations. There was a suggestion of possible intimidation, but basically he said that it would not be reasonable to identify them.

Having thought about that, I amended the motion so that we now only require identification by post code. That enables us to see the regions of Australia which have expressed interest. I think it would be useful for us to match those against the government's proposal to target areas of high youth unemploy ment in this country, particularly regional and rural areas.

The parliamentary secretary on duty (Senator Campbell) representing Senator Kemp has indicated to me that this is still not acceptable. I believe that the Senate ought to insist that we have a look at this; it is not commercial‐in‐confidence. Schemes will be up and running soon and if the minister has been inundated why can't we see what has been proposed and in what areas of Australia? I think there is a great deal of public interest in it. I do not mean the normal use of `public interest' but public interest—parliamentary interest—in the fact that the minister makes these assertions and that we have something to measure against those assertions. I just do not believe there is any reasonable excuse for the government to deny the parliament—in this case, the Senate—the opportunity to peruse this material with identifying names removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this motion and will require a division on the matter. I want to just briefly, without taking much of the Senate's time, indicate why that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: A return to order against someone in the Senate is one of the most powerful weapons available to this chamber to scrutinise parliamentary activity. No‐one, I presume, in this chamber would deny the need for such an opportunity to be there, to have a return to order which says basically—for those who do not understand that terminology; students in the gallery—we want all these documents and you will have to provide them. Because it is the most powerful weapon available to the Senate, it is pretty obvious that it was never, ever intended to be used for a cursory examination of whatever is in a government file that may be of interest. That is, in fact, what Senator Kernot wants to do on this occasion.

Perhaps she does not regret not being in government because having no prospect of ever being in government brings with it, of course, a lack of responsibility. You can say and promise whatever you like knowing that you will never be in a position of having to deliver it. But every now and again there is this sort of passing lingering thought that maybe it would be nice to be in government and see everything that a government can see. She wishes she was in that position, so she wants senators opposite—Senator Harradine and Senator Colston—effectively, to come and support a return to order, one of the most powerful tools available to this chamber, to peruse some correspondence that we have received in support of a measure that she is not in support of. That is what she wants—to be able to walk in and out of files looking at letters that people have written.

There is no doubt about this point, Mr Acting Deputy President: this government will always be more accountable than the last one. You may ask, how will we be accountable on the work for the dole scheme? When the schemes are up and running, when they are work for the dole schemes and people are successful in getting on them—with all the documentation in relation to that—of course we will have to be accountable. But the government should not have to account to the opposition for the sorts of letters that people write in support of the policy.

There is no question of not being accountable for the scheme when it is up and running, much as it will be regrettable to Senator Kernot as she does not want the scheme to be running. No doubt Senator Carr does not want it to be running; he just got bulldozed in his party room and they had to come in here and do a triple 10 backflip and say, `Yes, yes, we support it.'

Someone might say, `Well why not release the letters anyway?' The first point I make is that this is a matter of interest just to Senator Kernot. There is no national interest in general letters of support for a scheme being released so Senator Kernot can peruse the correspondence files of a minister. There is no national interest there; it is just a passing interest of hers.

Secondly, we know that a group has been formed to oppose the work for the dole scheme, which is determined to discourage participants from taking part. Despite the fact that the parliament has voted to endorse this scheme, there are people who are grouping together and saying, `We want to make sure that this does not go ahead.' Senator Kernot believes that by whiting out names and addresses these people will be protected, but that is not always the case. Just because a name and address is not there does not mean that it is impossible to locate someone. From the nature of some letters you would be able to see that it would not necessarily be that difficult to perhaps identify some people.

So if this motion is passed, regrettably, we will have to look very carefully at each letter. It will be very time consuming. I would ask Senator Kernot to consider whether she is prepared to re‐amend her motion and change the time. This is wanted by midday tomorrow. The Democrats would like something, so we have to stick on a whole lot of extra public servants and get them to do this work, on overtime, because Senator Kernot would like this by midday tomorrow. Perhaps, Senator Kernot, you would be prepared to amend it to, say, 5 o'clock tomorrow? That would be at least of some assistance, if it is to be passed.

I conclude by making the point that this is one of the strongest weapons available to a parliament, and since we have been in government it has been used and used and used to the point that its currency has been devalued. You have devalued the currency of one of the most powerful weapons available to parliament. In doing so I believe you continue to diminish the power of parliament and invite this government and future governments to give as little as possible, which is, I think, a very unsatisfactory situation.

I equally conclude by repeating that this government will be accountable to parliament, but I we think we should be accountable for the government's programs, not for public expressions of interest in the government's programs. That is not something that we ought to be accountable to parliament for. Everybody who writes to a parliamentarian does not necessarily expect their letter to be made public. The expressions of interest to us are not a matter of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time I will not speak at length. I will just indicate to the Senate that the opposition will be supporting this return to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to amend the motion in terms of the time for reporting, but certainly not to 5 o'clock because we will out of here by then, I hope. I seek leave to amend the motion by replacing the word `midday' with `3 p.m.'

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the fact that we think this is an unreasonable and irresponsible use of Senate power if this motion is passed, we are nonetheless grateful for some commonsense prevailing. We thank the Democrats for shifting the time to 3 o'clock.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Kernot's ), as amended, be agreed to.

AGED CARE BILL 1997

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 2-1, page 4 (lines 5 to 13), omit paragraph (a), substitute:
(a) to provide for funding of *aged care that ensures that the care provided:

PARA.TAB: (i) is of a high quality;
(ii) is of a type and level appropriate to the needs of the people who require care;
(iii) is available to the people who require care, irrespective of their capacity to pay for that care;
(iv) results in appropriate outcomes for the people receiving the care.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 2-1, page 5 (after line 14), at the end of subclause (1), add:
;(k) to ensure that providers of care are accountable for the funding they receive and for the outcomes of the people who receive aged care services.
(5) Clause 2-1, page 5 (lines 15 to 19), omit subclause (2).

These amendments seek to amend the objects of the act as set out in clause 2 and, in particular, they seek to amend the objects clause of the bill to spell out what it is that the bill is designed to achieve.

We have heard a lot of comment from the government for some time now about the objectives that they have for their so‐called reform package for aged care. It is striking, therefore, that some of the important aspects that they claim will be advanced by this legislation and the principles that underpin this legislation are not appropriately reflected in the objects clause.

One of the key issues that has surrounded the debate on this legislation has been the question as to whether or not we will in the future have a situation where access to aged care, particularly in nursing homes, will be a right, as it has been for all time, or whether it will be determined on the basis of the means, the income, the assets, of individuals. It is the opposition's firm view that, once the act is in operation, it will not take too long before the views that we have expressed about it will be shown to be true; that is, that in the future access to aged care will depend more upon your ability to pay and what assets you have and less upon the needs of the individual.

As I said earlier, I believe it is a fundamental tenet of our society that it has prided itself on ensuring that all people in this country have access to adequate health care. Labor governments have in the past had to restore access to adequate health care after the destructive periods of Liberal governments which, for instance, have in the past dismantled Medicare.

But access to adequate health care should be a right for all Australians, and particularly should continue to be a right for Australians in their latter years. That is why it is important that all persons who need access to nursing homes have a right to such care. They should not have to worry about, for instance, whether or not they have sufficient assets to buy their way in. We will come to talk about those issues in more detail later, particularly when we deal with the issue of the accommodation bond.

These amendments, therefore, substitute firstly a new paragraph (a) in the objects clause, so that funding for aged care will ensure that care is of a high quality, is of an appropriate type and level, and is available irrespective of a person's capacity to pay. As noted in paragraph (iii) of clause 2‐1 in the bill, the current objects of the act are:
the need to ensure access to care that is affordable by, and appropriate to the needs of, people who require it;

The inclusion of the words `that is affordable by' demonstrates the real purpose and intent of this legislation. Whilst the rest of the objects may refer to such things as the needs of people—and that is highly appropriate, of course—and refer to the promotion of high quality care and accommodation, the protection of health and wellbeing, the thing that really stands out in the objects clause are those words `the need to ensure access to care that is affordable by people who require it'.

Once you read that part of the objects clause, everything else pales into the background, because that is what drives this entire legislation. This is seen in other aspects, such as the fact that, unless you can qualify as a concessional resident—and those provisions are limited to a narrow group of people with very few, if any, assets—then you are going to have to face the prospect, if you wish to get into a nursing home, of finding large amounts of funds, estimated up to $80,000 or $100,000, to be sure of getting a bed in a nursing home.

Access to aged care under this legislation will depend on people's wealth, not simply and only on their health. As I have said before and as people from right across the industry sector have said, people do not choose to go into nursing homes in the way that they may choose to sell their home and move to a smaller home unit, or sell their home or their unit and move into shared accommodation, move into hostel accommodation. They are decisions that people themselves can make when they have the time to consider the options and the needs.

Certainly, when people make decisions to go into hostel accommodation, they have in mind that it will make their life easier in terms of not having to cope with all of the demands that they may have had when they owned their own home and so on; that there is certain assistance available in such accommodation. But they are all choices that people can make, and they can have regard to their circumstances when they do so. But that is not the situation when it comes to nursing homes. Therefore, we believe that it is entirely inappropriate to have a system whereby up‐front in bold letters is that statement that access to care under this legislation is on the basis of your wealth, of whether you can afford it or not.
There is also a requirement in subclause (2) of the objects clause which states:
In construing the objects, due regard must be had to:
(a) the limited resources available to support services and programs under this act;

So once again we have the concept of `affordability and limited resources available to support services and programs under this act' overriding this legislation. That is what drives this government in its move towards a market based `if you've got the wealth, you can afford it' approach. It is only after those principles that underpin this legislation are highlighted in the objects clause that you then actually find references to such things as needs of people who require it or the need to consider equity and merit in accessing those resources. Those needs, the principle of equity, should not be subject to some overriding concept of affordability.

We also seek to amend the objects clause, as I have outlined and is detailed in the amendments circulated, because there is no evidence of a fundamental commitment to ensuring access to high quality appropriate care for everyone who needs it, irrespective of their capacity to pay for that care.

Our amendments make that commitment explicit in this part of the bill. It makes it explicit in the very part of the bill where it should be; that is, up‐front in the objects clause. I can recall in earlier debates dealing with the industrial relations legislation, and I am sure my friend and colleague Senator Cooney recalls this. We had some discussion about objects clauses in that legislation. When we drew attention to the fact that certain matters that should have been contained in the legislation were not provided for in the body of the legislation, we were often told, `Oh, yes, but if you have a look at the objects clause, that is where it is. So, if it is in the objects clause, you really should not be too worried about the rest of the legislation.'

Here we have the reverse situation. It is a matter of concern that these principles that we say should be reflected in the objects clause are not contained therein. By supporting our amendments, it will actually bolster those other aspects of the objects that we do certainly agree with. For instance, the object of paragraph (h) is `to help those recipients'—that is, recipients of aged care—`to enjoy the same rights as all other people in Australia'. That is precisely what our amendments will do. They will ensure that recipients of health care will enjoy the same rights as all other Australians.

Our amendments ensure that the objects clause will reflect a commitment towards providing aged care based upon need, not simply on affordability or capacity to pay. We would ask that the Senate support the amendments that have been moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me advise that the government opposes these amendments in relation to amendment (2). Clause 2‐1(1)(b) ensures that care is available on the basis of need. The government does not see any need to change that. It is not a question of only finances or economics. The subclause I mention states that one of the objects of the act is:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) to promote a high quality of care and accommodation for the recipients of aged care services that meets the needs of individuals;
Amendment (3) is about accountability of providers. That is provided for quite squarely in clause 2‐1(v). That states:
(1) The objects of this Act are as follows:
(a) to provide for funding of aged care that takes account of:

PARA.TAB: (v) accountability of the providers of the care for the funding and for the outcomes for recipients;

SPEECH.PARA: Accountability is mentioned squarely there. As for amendment (5), the subclause that the opposition objects to is identical to section 4, subsection (2), which is found in the Disability Services Act 1986, which the opposition enacted when it was in government. So that comes right from the opposition itself when it was in government. That is straight out of the Disability Services Act, as I have men tioned. For those reasons, the government opposes these amendments as not being necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I should indicate that the Democrats will not support these amendments for some of the reasons that were mentioned by the parliamentary secretary. I also really find it hard to see whether there is any improvement in the wording that has been submitted. In fact, I am concerned that it may be more limiting than freeing up. That is the concern I have. I have already indicated to the opposition that I would not support these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of amendment (5), I would have thought that the opposition would have agreed with that one that limited resources. That is what we are hearing all the time. I must say to you, if we had unlimited resources, the Democrats would have lots of good ideas about how we could spend them. I think it is quite appropriate to draw attention to that fact in this legislation. So we would not agree to omitting that clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the opposition is right in this, and Senator Forshaw is correct. If you look at the objects clause 2‐1(1)(d), that is, as it reads, an imperative. It is an obligation that is cast on people under this act; that is, `to ensure that aged services are targeted towards the people with the greatest needs for those services'. Others are recommendatory. If you look, for example, at 2‐1(1)(g), it is `to encourage diverse, flexible and responsive aged care services'. But I think everybody would agree with (d); that is, that the services ought to go to those most in need.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at subsection (2) of 2‐1, that qualifies it by saying, `Oh, well, the limited resources must be taken into account.' People can understand that there ought to be limited resources, but it seems to me to be contradictory to say that those most in need are going to be the target of the provisions of this act and then create a situation where it is those with resources, those with the most money, who, in fact, are going to get the best services. That is brought out, as Senator Forshaw says, by 2‐1(1)(a), which says `to provide for funding of aged care that takes account of' these things.

It will be too easy for people who have the duty to carry out the provisions of this act to say that 2‐1(1)(d) is impossible to do anything about because of 2‐1(2)(a)—that is, the limited resources that are available—and that the issue of quality is only a matter that has to be taken into account.

What is going to happen is that those without money are going to be put off into places that do not have the same sort of quality that other places do. Unless there is a provision like the provision suggested by the opposition, then I think ingrained into the objects of this act is the very problem that the opposition wishes to avoid; that is, that, depending upon the resources you have available to you, you will get better or worse quality services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some other comments and pick up the points which were made by Senator Cooney. If you look at the amendments which we have proposed, and the bill as it is currently drafted, you will see that we are strengthening it by referring to objects of the act as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that ensures that the care provided:
(i) is of a high quality;
(ii) is of a type and level appropriate to the needs of the people who require care;
(iii) is available to the people who require care, irrespective of their capacity to pay for that care;
(iv) results in appropriate outcomes for the people receiving the care.
Senator Cooney is quite right when he says that the objects are to ensure that something happens; it is a lot stronger than simply saying, as the bill states:
The objects of this Act are as follows:
(a) to provide for funding of aged care that takes account of . . .

A range of criteria are then listed. It is clearly a weakening of the very commitment that the government says that it has, and that we all should have. Let us face it: we should have a commitment to providing high quality care to the aged. What sort of a society are we if we do not have that commitment? We should have a commitment to providing access to care on the basis of need, not on the basis of affordability, wealth or capacity to pay. If people are in need of hospital care, they should be entitled to get it. Equally, if they are in need of nursing home care, then they also should be entitled to get it. It should not be something that comes from legislation that says we will `take account' of those needs or those rights. The legislation should say that we will ensure that those rights are delivered. I think Senator Woodley is wrong. The amendments clearly strengthen the objects of the act by ensuring that these commitments will be delivered and will be available, rather than simply taken account of.

The other aspect of the amendments, particularly amendment No. 4, relates to a redrafting of the current (1) (v). Rather than take account of the `accountability of the providers of the care for the funding and for the outcomes for recipients', we are saying that the objects of the legislation should ensure `that providers of care are accountable for the funding they receive and for the outcomes of the people who receive aged care services'.

I strongly suggest that it is important that the objects of the act should be ensuring that that accountability exists. We should not be just taking account of it because, as Senator Woodley knows, there are provisions in this legislation which change dramatically the future structure of financing of nursing homes in respect of capital infrastructure and that, of course, is particularly in relation to the system of accommodation bonds.

It is important that the legislation ensures that those providers of care who are going to be negotiating with residents, or potential residents, of nursing homes about how much bond needs to be put up, who are going to be entrusted with those people's significant sums of money, be accountable, and the legislation must ensure that they are accountable.

We have already expressed our concern, and I am sure the Democrats agree with our concern—indeed, they have indicated it themselves—that, as yet, we still do not have the prudential arrangements that will apply to providers of care with respect to the funds that they will raise through accommodation bonds. We stress that these amendments should be passed and go into the legislation, because it will strengthen the commitment that we are told is there.

I am very surprised that neither the government nor the Democrats can agree with the proposals. They add to the legislation; they do not in any way detract from the legislation. They do not in any way contradict the express commitments that the minister and the government have made about what this legislation is going to do. But if the reason you do not support the amendments is that they are contrary to what you are telling the parliament, and what you are telling the aged care sector and the community, then you should at least come clean and tell the parliament today.

For instance, I ask: why can't you agree with an object of the act that will ensure that the care which is provided is of a high quality? Why can't you agree that the care that is provided is of a type and level appropriate to the needs of the people? Why can't you agree, particularly, with an object of the act which would provide that care is available to people who require care, irrespective of their capacity to pay for that care?

The fact that you cannot agree with that amendment sends a very clear signal to people out there in the community that you know that the system is not going to work along the lines you said it would. We know and the community knows that, notwithstanding your assurances, for instance, on the issue of whether or not people will have to sell their homes, people are going to be forced to sell their homes because they will have no other choice in order to raise the bond money to be able to negotiate a bed in a nursing home. That is what is going to happen. No amount of assurances and commitments from the government is going to alter that fact. If we are wrong and if you believe that it will not occur, then put it up‐front in the objects clause—agree to the amendment and put in an objects clause that says that aged care will be available to all aged Australians irrespective of their capacity to pay and it will not be based simply on affordability.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 4-1, page 9 (lines 4 and 5), omit ",except as provided in an agreement under section 4‐2".
As well the opposition opposes clauses 4-2 and 4-3 in the following terms:
(7) Clause 4-2, page 9 (lines 7 to 15), TO BE OPPOSED
(8) Clause 4-3, page 9 (lines 16 to 24), TO BE OPPOSED.

The issue here is whether or not the Commonwealth is going to continue to have a role in aged care in the future. One would think that, when you pick up a piece of legislation which is almost 400 pages long and has two or three other bills attached to it and you look back at the focus that has been given to this most important issue since the budget of last year when the government announced its intention to bring about major changes in aged care, this government has a commitment to continue to be involved in a major way in the provision of aged care. When you look at section 4 you wonder why it is that there is an application clause in the legislation which states:
This Act applies in all the States and Territories, except as provided in an agreement under section 4‐2.
Section 4‐2 states:
Agreements limiting the application of this Act
The Minister may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, enter into an agreement with a State or Territory under which this Act, or specified provisions of this Act:
(a) cease to apply in the State or Territory; or
(b) apply in the State or Territory only in the circumstances specified in the agreement; or
(c) apply in the State or Territory with the modifications specified in the agreement.
Section 4‐3 states:
Grants to States and Territories

(1) The Minister may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, make grants to a State or Territory for the purpose of assisting the State or Territory to carry out its obligations under an agreement under section 4‐2.
(2) The grants may be made on such conditions as the Minister determines in writing.
(3) Payments under this section are to be made out of money appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose.

That is what is known in the industrial relations arena—an area I have become rather familiar with over many years—as an opting out clause. This is a whopper of an opting out clause. This is the biggest opting out clause you have ever seen. We have a bill, a bill for an act, that is made up of 400‐odd pages. We have 300 pages of draft aged care principles—and what you cannot find in the act, you hope to God you can find in the principles. There is other legislation, prudential arrangements and guidelines and so on to come. Yet we have in this bill a proposal whereby the minister can enter into an agreement with a state government or a territory government to abandon its involvement in the provision of aged care. That is a disgraceful proposition to even entertain.

Certainly we support, and have always supported, the position that the Commonwealth should be involved in negotiations with the states in entering into arrangements with the states and territories to improve the delivery of, and access to, aged care services and to ensure efficiency, because this is a national issue. Many aged people in this country have access to the pension system after they retire and they may have access to a range of other social welfare or social security measures or entitlements. `Entitlements' is a better word because that is what aged people are entitled to in recognition of their role in our society, entitlements that they should get, having made a tremendous contribution through their working years to the development of this country. That extends beyond state or territory borders.

Yet in this legislation, which is intended to reform aged care and, as this government continues to tell us, lead to a new era of improved facilities, better access to nursing homes and so on, we have a provision whereby the Commonwealth government can enter into an agreement with a state minister—maybe Jeff Kennett, Premier of Victoria—whereby the Commonwealth can just walk away from that state and say, `You look after it all.' There is no requirement for any of the standards that will be set and obligations that will be required under this legislation in all states to necessarily continue to apply in that state. These agreements can contain anything.

For instance, the Commonwealth could enter into an agreement with Victoria, just to pick one state, whereby the prudential arrangements in relation to accommodation bonds do not apply in that state. That is possible. You might stand up and say, `It won't occur,' but under this legislation it can occur. Given the attitude of the Victorian government in respect of a range of other issues where they have been very keen to wipe out rights and entitlements for people in that state, anything is possible.

Over the years the Labor government has recognised the need for the Commonwealth to take a greater role in this area, just as it had to do in a range of other areas because of the disparities in important services across the states—whether it be education, health, hospitals, dementia care, and so on. Let us not go back to that time in the past when we had major disparities between one state and another because the states were left with sole responsibility, or most of the responsibility, in the aged care sector.

This government has a strong desire to divest itself of responsibility in a range of areas and return those responsibilities to the states. Let us be frank. Senator Ellison, you know and I know that many people on your side do not like specific purpose payments to the states. I heard those arguments time and time again when I was a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. You do not like the fact that the states have to comply with ensuring equitable provision of services across the country. We are seeing this divesting of responsibility back to the states in so many areas.

If these clauses remain in the bill then there certainly will be an opportunity for responsibility for aged care to be handed back to the states and territories on a whim or by a simple decision of the minister. This parliament can be by-passed in that process. I urge you to not let us go back to that previous era when aged care was of very poor quality, when we had different fees and standards across the country. It is quite contrary to the very things you say that you are trying to achieve in this legislation through, for instance, the provisions that will be enacted in respect of setting daily fees and the amount for the concessional resident subsidy.

The government has just finalised a deal with the Democrats and settled on a subsidy figure of $7 per resident in homes with up to 40 per cent of concessional residents and then $12 per resident in homes with more than 40 per cent of concessional residents. That is the position that the minister has announced. That is what we are told will apply right across the country. Yet under this clause it would be possible to have an agreement with another state for a different regime to apply in that state.

I urge the Senate, and I particularly look to the Democrats, to support this amendment. It is vital that this parliament has a say and continues to have a say in the delivery of aged care throughout the nation. We must remove this provision in the bill to take away the unfettered capacity of the government to enter into agreements with states and territories which would override the provisions of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting these opposition amendments. We have looked at this carefully and do agree with the arguments put by Senator Forshaw. I would just add a few comments. Over the past 12 months, the federal government has raised the possibility of devolving the responsibility for a number of health and community care related services to the states. This proposal was one of the main areas of discussion at the COAG meeting in June 1996. At that time the government said that aged care would be one of the first areas to be handed over to the states if the proposals went ahead. Although, at least to some extent, the devolution of aged care seems to have fallen off the agenda for now, thanks to the states' and territories' strong opposition to devolution, I think this is an important amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the responsibility for health and community based services is shared jointly by the Commonwealth and state governments, with the Commonwealth being responsible for directly administering funding for nursing homes and hostels. The Democrats, along with almost all the organisations involved in the provision of aged care, do not support the devolution of aged care to the states—certainly not at this time. Much of the progress in aged care which has been made over the last decade has largely been the result of strong Commonwealth intervention and the establishment of enforceable national programs and national standards. The devolution of aged care services to the states would lead to a variation in services and standards across the jurisdictions and result in a lower standard of care for Australia's elderly, and that is why the Democrats will support the opposition amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a remarkable provision, as Senator Forshaw and Senator Woodley have said. Division 4 means that the proposed act can be reduced to 4‐1, 4‐2, 4‐3 and 4‐4. You could even leave 4‐4 out, and perhaps 4‐1. You could have, as Senator Forshaw says, an act written by a minister, who may not even be in cabinet, and by the territories. Parliament would have absolutely no power over it.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot quite follow. Section 4‐2 talks about an agreement which is `an agreement with a State or Territory under which this Act, or specified provisions of this Act' cease to apply, or that the act itself ceases to apply. So the whole act can be put aside by a particular state or territory. Then the bill says in 4‐3(1):

The Minister may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, make grants to a State or Territory for the purpose of assisting the State or Territory to carry out its obligations under an agreement under section 4‐2.

But the only agreement referred to in 4‐2 is an agreement to set aside the act or part of the act. I cannot see that there would be any monetary obligation in an agreement to set aside an act or to set aside part of the act. If you made an agreement that said, `We are going to run nursing homes in a particular way and there will be certain obligations to do that,' I can understand that. But the agreement that the proposed act refers to in 4‐2 does not seem in any way to involve money. I can understand that you would have an agreement to set aside part of the act and that the Commonwealth would give money to the particular state to carry out the part of its obligations under the act or that part of the act that was left. But I cannot see that it can be interpreted that an agreement referred to in 4‐2 in any way involves the expenditure of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly in answer to Senator Cooney's point, section 4‐2 provides for an application of this act, should it become an act, in a state or territory, for instance, in circumstances specified in the agreement. There may be some expenditure in relation to the application of the act and how it operates in a state.

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions came about as a result of the Council of Australian Governments indicating that aged care was an area that was open to discussion to develop new approaches and explore appropriate responsibilities to achieve the best outcomes in public health. Those responsibilities may well be covered in an agreement in 4‐2, and those responsibilities could well involve some cost, and hence the question in 4‐3 in relation to grants.

The government is opposed to these amendments for the reasons I have mentioned in relation to the Council of Australian Governments. We look at this as being a partnership between the Commonwealth and the states. The states do have a role to play in aged care, and these provisions would facilitate that partnership. But the government realises that, with the Democrats' support, the opposition will succeed in these amendments, and we will not seek to divide on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—The question now is that clauses 4.2 and 4.3 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 44-22, page 177 (after line 18), after paragraph (a), insert:
(aa) the care recipient has been or is likely to be classified as requiring a *high level of residential care;

This amendment proposes to insert a new paragraph in clause 44-22. The effect of the amendment is to insert a new paragraph which sets the amount by which a subsidy can be reduced by a person's income to zero if the person requires a high level of residential care, that is, classification levels 1, 2, 3 or 4.

The reason for this amendment is that currently there are provisions in clause 44-22 whereby the daily income tested reduction in respect of the care recipient is taken to be zero, where one or more of the following applies: that the care recipient was provided with respite care; a determination was in force under subsection (2) in relation to the care recipient; or the care recipient was included in a class of people specified in the residential care subsidy principles. As I have said, this amendment includes provision also to include persons requiring a high level of residential care.

Under the legislation, a new daily fee is being introduced for nursing home residents who have private income above the pension income free area—currently $49 a week and $50 a week from 1 July. For each $1 above the income free area, the resident will be required to pay 25c—that is, 25 per cent of any income or 25c in the dollar for any income over that income free area. They will be paying that on top of paying the standard resident contribution of $26.40 a day towards their care, or on top of the approximately $21 a day if the resident is a pensioner.

The maximum daily fee that can be charged is $60. This new fee that is being introduced will mean that the effective marginal tax rate for part‐pensioners will be close to 100 per cent. Part‐pensioners or self‐funded retirees in nursing homes are going to be hit in the neck by this legislation. Under the proposed legislation, they will have their incomes assessed by the Department of Social Security for the first time. If you do not agree to that assess ment being made, you will be charged the maximum daily fee. What we are going to end up with is nursing homes becoming, effectively, tax collectors for the government. The equivalent of the revenue raised by this new fee will be deducted from the subsidy paid to the nursing home by the government.

Our amendment will prevent the government from charging the new daily fee for aged care residents who require a high level of care—that is, those residents of nursing homes. Aged care providers will therefore not then be able to select residents of the basis of their capacity to pay for care. As is the existing situation, current providers of hostel care will continue to be able to charge the daily fees.

The purpose of the amendment is as I have just outlined. It will include the category of people for whom the daily income tested reduction is taken to be zero. As well it will include that group of persons who are in need of a higher level of residential care. We believe that it is appropriate that they should be treated in this way and that they should not suffer the significant impost that would otherwise be imposed on them by virtue of the new daily fees that will be introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. The government believes that the opposition is trying to maintain a totally separate system between nursing homes and hostels here. It maintains that this would be unworkable in practice. One older person might be income tested and another not whilst both being in the same room. The amendment would mean that the aged care system would be unsustainable into the future as the growth in the aged population becomes significant with more and more people require higher levels of residential care.

SPEECH.PARA: I might point out that residential care charges are not a tax. People in residential care pay for their living expenses, just like people in the community. If you accept the erroneous proposition that nursing home residents' living expenses are a tax, then you arrive at the high effective marginal tax rates that are mentioned. You would get the same result if you added rent or mortgage payments or food bills to calculate the marginal tax rates of people in the community. The fact is that people spend most of their income on living expenses, and their spending generally increases as their income rises.

In conclusion, the government would say that we have ensured that residents who are able to do so have an incentive to invest wisely and increase their income, because the higher the income, the more they will keep after paying charges. It is as simple as that. The government opposes this amendment for the reasons I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the proposition put by the parliamentary secretary that living expenses are expended by everybody, but with the way these particular charges operate, they not only relate to the cost of those living expenses, they are calculated in accordance with income you receive which is above the pension.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary this: does the government have any particular concern about the severity of impact of these charges on those people who are referred to as part‐pensioner recipients? Of course, for those who are pensioners there is a much lower limit. I suppose that, once you get above the part‐pensioner level, your income may be substantially higher. But in that category between total pensioner and those who have income that puts them well outside of the part pension, there is a group of people who seem to be dealt with particularly harshly in that they really can be only earning a very small amount above the pension but still have to pay that $60 charge.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes that it has provided a fair balance for those part pensioners, and it fails to see the concern of the opposition. It believes that this amendment will go nowhere to providing equity and parity in the system, and that is why it opposes it.
—I indicate that the Democrats will not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just respond to a comment that Senator Ellison made. He said that the Labor Party is trying to maintain a distinction between hostels and nursing homes. Yes, Senator Ellison, we agree with that. In fact, that very much is our position; you know that. We believe that is an important distinction that still should be retained.

SPEECH.PARA: This is what we understand and know, because we were involved in the situation for many years while in government of promoting the integrated care arrangements, if you like, that you now see in aged care centres. In my own area in Heathcote, I know of the centre called John Paul Village. It is a first‐class centre which was funded largely by the federal government—Labor government—as well as by the Catholic church and the Catholic community in the area. There you have various types of accommodation that people can purchase or buy into, whether it be hostel or self‐care accommodation, and also nursing home facilities. The distinction between the two with respect to the requirements upon residents is retained, notwithstanding the fact that there is a relationship between the different forms of care.

We certainly say—as again we will be saying when we deal with accommodation bonds—that on this we do not agree with the government. We think your approach of saying, `Well, we set this system up for hostels, therefore we can set it up for nursing homes too,' is wrong, and we will continue to maintain that position. So your comment earlier that we are seeking, through this amendment, in respect of this area, to continue that distinction is one that we do not run away from. We, of course, support the amendment.

That the amendment (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.
