SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Clause 57-1, page 219 (line 7), after "These relate particularly to", insert "who can be charged an *accommodation bond,".
(19) Clause 57-2, page 219 (after line 23), before paragraph (a) insert:

(aa) an *accommodation bond cannot be charged for the *entry of a person to a residential care service as a care recipient if the care recipient has been or is likely to be classified as requiring a *high level of residential care;

These amendments relate to accommodation bonds, which is the new system that the legislation introduces with respect to access to nursing homes. The amendments vary clause 57 by inserting in the box paragraph the words `who can be charged an accommodation bond'.

Amendment 19 would insert a new paragraph into clause 57-2 to state `an accommodation bond cannot be charged for the entry of a person to a residential care service as a care recipient if the care recipient has been or is likely to be classified as requiring a high level of residential care'. I note that the following amendment that we will come to—amendment 20—also relates to the use to which accommodation bonds can be put. In the course of my remarks to amendments 18 and 19, I may refer to some issues that relate to that amendment also.

We need to deal with this whole issue of the introduction of accommodation bonds for persons needing access to nursing homes. In the future, under this legislation an accommodation bond will be required by all future residents of aged care facilities unless they fall into a fairly narrow group. The first is if they are concessional residents. These are essentially people on a low income or with very few assets and who quite clearly cannot find the finances to pay an accommodation bond even of the lowest amount potentially possible under this legislation.

Secondly, you will not be required to pay an accommodation bond if you are a full pensioner and have not owned your own home in the last two years. If you do own your own home but you still have a spouse, dependent child, or carer living in that home—and that person would obviously need to continue to live in the home—then you would not be required to pay an accommodation bond, particularly if the carer, who has cared for you for at least five years, still lives in the home.

BREAK.PARA: The government has said, firstly, that what it is doing is extending the system that operates with hostel care to nursing homes. I have already put on the record what our position is on that: we do not agree that that is an appropriate approach. We believe the distinction should remain because there is a fundamental distinction between persons who choose to go into hostel accommodation and people who are forced by necessity to go into a nursing home. That is a distinction that should continue.

We have also noted in speeches during the second reading debate that whilst Professor Gregory, in his report, recognised the need for substantial capital injection into the nursing home sector, nevertheless he rejected the system of accommodation bonds for nursing home access, particularly because of the significant impact that it would have on the financial position of such persons. I have earlier read Professor Gregory's comments from his report onto the record because that gives the lie to the arguments put by the government that they are relying on Professor Gregory's recommendations in this regard.

What we have now for the first time is a proposal whereby the family home will be included in an assets test if you wish to get into a nursing home. As I said, there are a few exceptions to that situation. I note that, notwithstanding the supposed expertise in this area that the government claims on its side of the chamber, we have not had one speaker from the government, other than the parliamentary secretary at the table, come into this chamber during this debate and seek to support this legislation and defend it.

Senators from the government took an active role in the committee proceedings which led to this excellent report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on funding for aged care institutions. They wrote a dissenting report in which they sought to ridicule the views of the majority. They sought to dismiss the views expressed by many witnesses. They alleged that we were engaged in scaremongering and fear tactics—the usual line that is trotted out. I do not think they ever accused us all of being former trade union officials but I am sure they thought it, which is their usual line. They dismissed out of hand the majority report, but they are not prepared to come into this chamber and speak in this debate.

Notwithstanding all those assurances and those comments by government senators, as I have said before and I will say it again, there is no doubt that people are going to be forced into a position of selling their own home. If they do not fit into the category whereby the family home would be exempted from the assets test, if they cannot get access to a nursing home, say as a concessional resident, then the fact of the matter is they are going to have to come up with the money to pay the bond.

Let us not forget that it is not just the aged person in need of nursing home accommodation who is involved here, it is family members as well. In just about all cases these decisions are hard for people to make. You have people who have been living in their own home for many years, seen their families grow up in their home and move away and have families of their own, and the grandkids come back. Then the time comes around where one of the parents or the sole remaining parent has to go into a nursing home because of their condition. That is a really difficult time for all concerned.

Then imposed over the top of all that is this requirement that they have to work out their asset position or that of a family member if that person happens to be suffering from dementia or some similar illness, and ask: how do I come up with the $80,000 that the nursing home wants in order to get myself or my family member into a nursing home? In many cases there is only one way that they could come up with that money; that is, sell the only remaining asset that they have—their home.

For the government to turn around and say, `You will not be forced to sell your home to get access,' has to be the most pedantic argument that could ever be put. The fact that the legislation does not say, `You will be required to sell your home in order to get the amount of bond that you have been able to negotiate'—it is more likely that you have been told what you have to come up with— does not mean that people will not be forced to do it. It is a bit like saying that nobody is forced to eat. People are not forced to eat. But if you do not eat, then you do not survive. So, in reality, you are forced to eat, and similarly here.

If the only way you can come up with the money to put up the bond is to sell your home, then that is what you are going to have to do. That is going to be a situation facing many people across the community from now—if not from 1 October—as they look at their future situation and at how they can get access to a nursing home.

There are already enough pressures and stresses on individuals without putting this extra stress or pressure on them. Equally, it is no answer to say, `In lieu of selling your home, you can rent it out and earn income and then pay off the bond periodically.' If that means that you are not forced to sell your home, then that is really begging the question as well. It is clear that many people—particularly those who have assets that just get them over the limit or, say, self-funded retirees or part pensioners with a small amount of income that still gets them over that threshold figure—could well find themselves worse off.

I am sure the government has seen the examples that have been calculated of where people rent out their home. By the time you take into account the extra income they receive from that, the impact that that has upon the pension they receive—because it reduces—the fact that they have to pay the additional daily fees of 25c in the dollar and the fact that they have to pay interest because they are paying the bond off periodically rather than as an up-front lump sum, those people end up worse off.

They get caught in a bind: they do not want to sell their home, but, equally, how are they going to get some income through either renting or taking out a loan? Who is going to lend them the money anyway to get a bed in a nursing home?

There are many issues that arise out of this. I have only touched upon one aspect of it so far. I know my colleagues have some further comments to make. I will leave my remarks at this stage at the moment, but I will be coming back to it in due course.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, the government will be opposing these amendments. Again, it is a difference in approach—(Quorum formed) As I was saying, the government opposes these amendments on the basis that I outlined previously. We believe that the hostel and nursing home situations should be brought together so that people can age in peace and that those who can afford to should contribute an accommodation bond for nursing homes, which in turn will improve the lot of the nursing homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The accommodation bond is certainly at the cutting edge of this particular piece of legislation. It is far and away the most contentious and the most concerning item of this particular bill. The concerns that are surfacing in the community about the accommodation bond—or the entry fee; whichever way you wish to describe it—have not really been satisfied to date. In particular, a lot of the concerns about the prudential arrangements for the accommodation bond have not been satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, there is real concern in the community about the principles that have been circulated. I have only recently got a copy—as I understand it, they were finalised only last week. It seems to me that it is rather difficult for the government to proceed with a bill which is so much reliant on these principles in a situation where they are not yet satisfied. In particular, there are some concerns about the accommodation bond that the Parliamentary Secretary could possibly answer. It may well be that they have given due consideration to it, but it certainly does not seem to me that it has been completely dealt with as yet.

The first concern that I have is this requirement that you must pay an accommodation bond if you have owned a home in the last two years. Initially, I can see why that has been brought in. If you do agree that an entry fee should be charged, of course you want to ensure that people do not try to avoid that requirement. You might, in fact, be concerned that people may fraudulently try to avoid it. Circumstances might exist, Parliamentary Secretary, where someone who owned a home in the last two years has lost it through fraud or because a spouse was severely ill and they had very high medical expenses and had to sell their house or because of an accident—it burned down—or some other problem existed and they genuinely had to divest themselves of a home in the last two years. If there is a situation where those people genuinely become very ill and very frail and are required to enter a nursing home, how does this bill deal with that situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —‐ There is a general hardship provision which would allow that to be taken into account. The person concerned would then be accommodated. There is no requirement that says an accommodation bond must be charged; it is up to the provider whether they do. It just says that you cannot charge one if the person has not owned a home in the last two years and fits into that concessional category. I refer you to clause 57‐14 entitled `Accommodation bond not payable in cases of financial hardship'. I think that covers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 57‐14 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary may determine, in accordance with the User Rights Principles, that a person must not be charged an accommodation bond because payment of an accommodation bond would cause the person financial hardship.

What provisions will apply in those circumstances to define financial hardship? In my view, it would be financial hardship if someone whose sole asset was a house had to pay an accommodation bond of, possibly, up to $110,000—as we have heard from some providers of nursing homes. Obviously, if that was the interpretation of hardship then nearly every person would not have to pay an accommodation bond. I am concerned that, because the user rights principles are not settled, we really do not know what financial hardship will mean. Effectively, we are being asked to sign a blank cheque. I would appreciate from the parliamentary secretary some views on the record here in this chamber as to what financial hardship will mean.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has mentioned that in that situation one of the things that could be taken into account is a family farm in the situation where the members of the family are still relying on the farm for income. I want to clarify the point that, when you say that selling a home might cause hardship, you have got to look at the value of the home. If you have a home worth a million dollars, then surely that would be something you would want to take into account. When you say that selling a home would cause hardship, selling a home worth a million dollars would not cause hardship. You have to be careful when you look at that aspect. The minister has already covered that. A draft on the principles that are mentioned there has already been circulated, in any event.

—You may say, Parliamentary Secretary, that the minister has covered it, but I do not believe that he has—and we are actually debating this bill here in this place. I would like you to advise us what sorts of principles will be applied when determining what financial hardship is. I know it could be a family farm; it could virtually be anything, of course. What I would like from you, if you don't mind, Parliamentary Secretary, is some indication of what principles will guide the assessment of financial hardship.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have a look at the exposure draft of the principles I mentioned, clause 43 there deals with an unrealisable asset, which I have mentioned. It states the circumstances in which the secretary may make a determination that a recipient not be charged an accommodation bond.

BREAK.PARA: The criteria listed there are whether it would cause hardship to the care recipient, to the care recipient's partner or to a dependent child of the care recipient. In (b) it says, `If the care recipient has assets other than unrealised assets whose value is less than the minimum permissible assets level.' That is, they have to be left with $22,500 for a single and $45,000 for a couple. So you have that set out there as criteria. The unrealisable asset I have touched on by way of an example in the family farm. It is page 276.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further question arising from that to the parliamentary secretary. The words in 57‐14(1) talk about the determination of the secretary being able to be made where the payment of the accommodation bond would cause the person financial hardship. You talked about other people being caused hardship, so I wonder if you might assist me by telling me what other provision would allow the circumstances of other persons to be taken into account when the question of hardship was raised.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —When one looks at 57‐14(1), the answer itself is in the subclause, because it says that the determination is made in accordance with the user rights principles, which I have referred to. So the phrase `would cause the person hardship' has to be read in conjunction with the user rights principle. When you go to the user rights principles, you look at the recipient, the recipient's partner, et cetera. So rather than repeat all that in the bill, it refers you to the user rights principle, and that is how it gets brought into it.
—They are still draft principles, aren't they?

—Draft principles, yes. But that is what it simply means. Otherwise you would have to say that saying `would cause hardship to the person' does not rule out those other matters. In fact, it includes them, because it explicitly says that the determination has to be made in accordance with the user rights principles.

—Just following that up: that may well be true, but are there any provisions that have been tested and found to meet this sort of test? My concern is that, whilst that may be the intent, the specific words `because payment of an accommodation bond would cause the person financial hardship' on a literal meaning—whatever other provisions exist—would have to mean, I would have thought, that it had to be that person and not somebody else.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, a similar situation is found in country hostels where a similar discretion is exercised and operates in the same matter. I might point out the words `refusals to make determinations are reviewable' in that subsection. So there is a second course of action open to the recipient if there is a determination which is not made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept what you say. You did not let me know whether that provision had been tested—whether there had been any contest about that that may or may not be relevant as to whether there would be any testing of this provision. It has been tested in the courts; is that right?
—It hasn't been tested because it has been operating satisfactorily. Anything that works does not have to be tested.

—I wanted to ask questions relating to the accommodation bond and particularly those people who may not be charged an accommodation bond. There is information in the public arena that those concessional residents who will not be charged an accommodation bond will attract a subsidy, depending upon the proportion of concessional residents in nursing homes. I understand that the separation point between the two levels of subsidy is 40 per cent occupancy of the nursing home—that is, for the 40 per cent of bed spaces occupied by concessional residents, a subsidy of $7 will be attracted and, for any occupancy above that level, a subsidy of $12 will be attracted.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wanted to know was: upon what basis is that divide constructed? Is it merely a financial calculation as to how much this will cost, or is there some other basis for the 40 per cent divide which has been advised as the basis for the higher or lower level of concessional resident subsidy per day that will be paid to the nursing home provider where there is occupancy by concessional residents?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The level of 40 per cent was arrived at through consultation with the providers, particularly the churches, which are the chief providers in this area. The $12 figure that you mentioned would apply to all concessional residents, including those in the first 40 per cent. I think you said it would be $7 for the first 40 per cent and then $12 thereafter. Once you get over 40 per cent, the $12 applies to all concessional residents, and it is based on occupancy.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary secretary, you made a comment a moment ago where you referred to hospitals. I want to ask you two questions.
—Is that hostels or hospitals?
—Hospitals. In answer to an unrelated matter to the one that I am raising, you actually referred to what occurs with respect to hospitals in country areas.
—Hostels in country areas.

—Hostels. I wanted to ask you these questions: would you agree that, because of necessity, people who are seeking access to a nursing home—or a family who is seeking access to a nursing home for another family member—do not get assessed for entry unless it is needed? Would you agree that that is a different situation to hostels and that, consequently, there are many people who become residents of nursing homes who could equally be admitted to hospitals? In fact, from memory I think about 60 per cent of the residents of nursing homes go into nursing homes from acute care.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the government's view? Do you see any problems that will occur in the future where people who previously, or under the current system, would have sought access to a nursing home—because of their state of health, their lack of capacity to look after themselves or the fact that they are no longer able to rely upon home care that is being provided, which are all the usual situations that lead to people being admitted to nursing homes—could equally, in many of those cases, be admitted to hospital? Do you think the potential exists for them to be admitted to hospital? Many nursing homes now provide forms of acute care that previously were provided in hospitals.

One of the concerns that we have is that, if people are faced with the problem of not being able to gain a nursing home bed because of an inability to raise the finance for the bond or because of a desire not to sell their own home, this will place pressure on the public hospital system. In fact, there have been some reports already in the paper today of the potential for the public hospital system to be further stressed because of the introduction of accommodation bonds for nursing homes. So I would like you to comment on that.

If an aged person is assessed as needing nursing home care and accommodation, particularly if they are suffering from some serious complaint, it may well be in those circumstances—whereas previously they may have been able to get access to a nursing home bed and still receive the medical treatment and care—that in the future the option of utilising the public hospital system would come more into play. I think that is something that everyone has acknowledged in the past; that is, in order to relieve the pressure on the public hospital system, it is important to promote the development of nursing homes. So could you comment on that issue, please?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I understand that there is ACAT assessment for both hostels and nursing homes alike—there is not just one for nursing homes. In relation to hostels, I understand that 30 per cent of people coming into a hostel come from a hospital—that is, they have probably had an illness, gone to hospital and realised that they needed to go into a hostel from the hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to nursing homes, I would take issue with the fact that many nursing homes offer acute care, as you mentioned, and that they are really a substitute for hospitals. The government does not see that there will be any problem with public hospitals. In fact, this proposal will see the improvement of nursing homes, which could then provide in a more adequate sense for residents rather than their having to go to a public hospital. With the increase in capital funding here, nursing homes will get better; and this will alleviate the need for people to go to hospital. It is quite the reverse of what you are suggesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question of the concessional resident subsidy that I was talking about earlier and which is the subject of the breakdown that we were discussing earlier, I understand that it is the government's intention to set a minimal level of occupancy reserved for concessional residents in nursing homes generally. Has an average setting been determined?
—Twenty‐seven per cent.
—The parliamentary secretary says 27 per cent.
—On average.

—I note that that is below the 40 per cent rate. Does that assume, therefore, that, on average, concessional residents will be paid at the lower of the two concessional rates? Is that a fair assumption?
—Yes.

—In relation to that, I would be concerned that there is therefore apparently a presumption that the payment that other occupants will make and the income derived from that is intended to subsi dise the concessional residents for the difference between the two levels of payment. That seems to me to be making the assumption that you are going to have a high level of income derived from the bond and the administrative draw downs where this average is achieved—that is, on average, 73 per cent of beds occupied by people who are not eligible to be treated as concessional residents.

SPEECH.PARA: That may be manageable—I will not dwell on the equity of it—for the sector in areas where a high bond can be charged and a higher level of income can be achieved. But I have a concern about areas, for example, where property values are low and there is a difficulty in raising significant amounts of income in terms of the accommodation bond required. In the arrangement between the Democrats and the government, you have provided for a subsidised rate for that—on average, 27 per cent.
I have to make the assumption that the organisations that have agreed believe they will have significantly more than 40 per cent of their beds occupied by concessional residents.

So I suppose the real average for the nursing homes that are not in that sector, the group that you referred to earlier—the religious organisations, et cetera—may have less than 27 per cent, and they will receive the lower rate for that. Nevertheless, those nursing homes will need to effectively make up the shortfall if the targets that the Gregory report established are met—or even the government's targets which I understand are less in the short term than the Gregory report targets—by charging an accommodation bond which is higher than it would otherwise need to be to achieve that level. In other words, if there is a 20 per cent level that is being subsidised and it is about 45 per cent below the full rate—the $12 per day that Professor Gregory recommended—they will have to make that up by increasing the bond, and therefore the earnings on the bond will increase.

There are a lot of issues about the bond. There are issues about the rate of return on money—we can take the draw down as a given—and there are also issues about the level of the bond that need to be addressed. This is the first area in this bill in which it can properly be attended to. I would be interested in a response from the government in relation to that.

I would also be interested in a response from the Democrats, who are party to the position which has been reached. I take that from Senator Woodley's press release headed `Democrats win major concessions on aged care'. Senator Woodley knows that press release well. It says that that agreement resulted from negotiations with the Democrats and the three main church providers.

I would be interested, parliamentary secretary, if you could comment on the question of the effect on the accommodation bond of that subsidy factor—I would also be interested in hearing comments on that matter from Senator Woodley on behalf of the Democrats—and also on the effect that might be had from these arrangements in areas where it will be difficult to raise significant income out of accommodation bonds, due perhaps to lower property values, without exceeding the proportion of concessional residents that the department is estimating.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, the $7 subsidy that we are talking about equates to the draw down of $2,600 a year. That is how that was arrived at. If a facility was in an area of lower economic value then it would be quite likely that the concessional residency would exceed 40 per cent. If it exceeds 40 per cent they go into the $12 category and get the higher subsidy. If you were to set up a facility in an area of that sort I would submit that your land purchasing costs would be less—you mentioned that the land in the area is of a lower value—than for some facilities that might be set up in suburbs which are quite expensive. SPEECH.PARA: To answer your question, the $7 subsidy equals the draw down in any event. If you were in a situation like that one would envis age a higher rate of concessional residency. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify one issue with the parliamentary secretary. You say that once you go over 40 per cent you get the increased subsidy of $12. Do you get it for everybody in the institution who is on a concessional subsidy or only for those who are above it?

—If you are above 40 per cent and people are getting the higher subsidy and some people leave so you drop below 40 per cent, do those people who are on the increased subsidy stay on it or does it drop immediately?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking into consideration the answer that you gave to my previous question, I still have a concern in relation to areas where people own property that is not as valuable as, say, property in Sydney, Melbourne or Brisbane. TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem for the provider is that if they only want to go for concessional to make it worthwhile they need to perhaps have over 40 per cent. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so I understand Senator O'Brien correctly: your concern is that in an area of low property values people would not be able to pay much in accommodation bond and, therefore, the facilities would have to rely on concessional residents. TALK.START.PARA: —The $26,000 is the bond which is paid up front. That is what you mean, isn't it, not the draw down? So the $12 is based on a bond of about $48,000?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner adjournment, we dealt with opposition amendments 18 and 19. I now move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (20) Clause 57-2, page 220 (line 31) to page 221 (line 2), omit paragraph (k), substitute:
(k) the approved provider must use the accommodation bond in either or both of the following ways:
(ka) the approved provider must not use the accommodation bond for a purpose that does not comply with the prudential requirements (see section 57-3);

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes a variation to clause 57-2 of the bill by omitting paragraph (k) and substituting a new paragraph (k).

In the debate on the previous amendments, we raised our concerns about the principle of accommodation bonds in nursing homes. By virtue of the decision to reject our amendments, the Senate has endorsed that system coming into operation. As I have said before, and as the government and the Democrats are well aware, there are major concerns with respect to these accommodation bonds. For instance, people have been rightly concerned that the bonds will simply be used to accrue further profit to the nursing homes because of the interest that they can earn on the capital funds that are raised and intended to be used for capital improvement in the nursing home.

The higher the bond you set, the more money you can raise, if you are able to get residents to agree to pay those bonds. Given the demand and the necessity for aged people to increasingly use nursing home facilities, one can anticipate substantial amounts of money being raised across the industry at large but, more notably, in particular sectors of the industry.

Clearly, as we debated in the previous amendments, the not‐for‐profit sector, which caters, as Senator Neal said, for about 50 per cent of nursing home residents, we believe will not be in the position of attracting substantial bonds in the way that other centres might. Their motivation is not profit making. In many cases those homes are run by charitable or church organisations. Senator Woodley has referred to them in his earlier remarks. They provide, and have provided for many years, tremendous service and commitment to caring for the aged. That is consistent with the similar activities undertaken in the hospital sector by church organisations. There still remains major concern about the use to which the accommodation bonds will be put.

It is clearly the intention of the government that these bonds will be utilised for capital works. As the minister has said, it is intended that the funds to be raised and held in trust to earn interest for the nursing home provider will be used—or that interest component will be used—to improve the stock of nursing homes, to bring them up to appropriate standards where they may not currently exist, to enable them to build extra facilities or expand existing facilities, to create more nursing home beds and to assist with retiring debt. These are all the objectives. Whilst we do not agree with the system of accommoda tion bonds, we wish to ensure that the intention of the legislation is carried out.

If the whole point of the government's reform package is to generate funds for the building, upgrading and refurbishment of nursing homes, it is important to ensure that that intention is reflected in the legislation. If you look at the legislation, there is no requirement in the bill that the funds available from charging accommodation bonds have to be used for this purpose. We are talking about interest, as I have said, and we are talking about $2,600 a year for five years that can be drawn down from the bond.

It is only fair that if the resident is going to be required to put up a bond—it may be $50,000 or $80,000; there is no limit on the amount—to enable them to get access to a nursing home bed and receive the care provided, then they are entitled to be sure, firstly, that their funds are going to be adequately protected through appropriate prudential arrangements; but, secondly, that the earnings off those funds are going to be used for the purposes for which they are intended.

So we have proposed that the bill be amended to spell out in clear terms that it is a requirement that those funds from the bond be used, as we say, to meet capital works costs and to retire debt and, further, to give the added protection that the funds should not be used for a purpose that does not comply with the prudential requirements. I remind the Senate that we are still waiting for those to be finalised and put in place.

This amendment will hold the government to the rhetoric of its legislation and we would ask that the government agree to it. It will put into the legislation what you say this legislation is really all about; that is, providing a means to expand our existing nursing home facilities.

We are concerned also that, if the market works as one would expect, nursing homes that are already up to standard or that may be considered to be at the top end of quality facilities will, of course, have an advantage in the market in being be able to charge higher accommodation bonds. They will, therefore, earn greater interest and build up a bigger fund compared to other homes which may be older and not necessarily of the highest standards, as are some of the more recent homes and facilities that have been built. Those facilities, I might say, were built under the program instituted by the Labor government that put some $1.2 billion over those years into expanding our aged care accommodation.

It is a matter of concern to us that there will be situations where the need to either expand the facilities or upgrade them may not be as pressing in a new home as it is in an older home. Nevertheless, the new homes will be able to charge bonds, earn interest and build up a large pool of money. The question then arises, if there is no legislative prescription to ensure that that money is used for the purpose that is intended, then there is no security ultimately for the residents concerned. And let us remember that their heirs and successors would be entitled to the refund of the money that they have put in, less the draw‐down over the five years.

I might say that, whilst the homes are going to be earning the interest, the poor old residents are not. They are not even going to be keeping pace with inflation, low as it may be these days due to the great economic record of the previous government. When they get paid that refund when they leave the nursing home, they get back the amount less the $13,000 if it is over five years. It is not only less that, of course; it is less in real terms because they have not earned any interest on it. So their funds should be appropriately protected.

We are particularly concerned that these bonds do not end up getting used, for instance, for activities that would not fall within the requirement that is intended. So we move the amendment. It holds the government to its promise, its commitment, and we seek the support of the Senate in doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: What you are doing there is talking about, as Senator O'Brien mentioned, the income from the bond and the retention amount. What that links into is (ka) of your amendment, that is, the prudential requirement. You are not covering the whole of the bond there, as I see it, because what you are talking about there is the income and the retention amount, and saying that both of those must be applied to capital works and retiring debt—yes—but you also link them into (ka), which is the prudential requirement. And you have not got the whole shooting match in there when you talk about only the income from the bond and any retention amount.

I am saying that you have missed part of it in the prudential requirement, because you would have to say basically `the income from the bond, the bond itself and the retention amount'. Also, if you did want to amend it, it might be preferable to have put it in at (n), not (k). So I think that that is a problem—one that perhaps you had not foreseen.

BREAK.PARA: While you have a look at that, I would say that, in relation to the wording here, `aged care' does cover all those areas. Obviously, staff salaries is part of it. Also, retiring debt would be part of it, because it enhances the security of the home. It means that the home is a more viable facility, and the more viable it is, the better it is for its residents. It means that if it is not paying exorbitant interest rates on high debt it can use its moneys for aged care purposes.

So it comes within that ambit, and that is why the government thought that the purpose of providing aged care to care recipients was a catch‐all phrase. I invite the opposition to just look at that as to whether they have protected the whole of the payment in the prudential arrangements by just talking about the retention amount and the income from the bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, we believe that the amendment we have moved is adequate. We took your existing (k), which reads:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (k) the approved provider must not use the accommodation bond for a purpose that is not related to providing aged care to care recipients, or that does not comply with the prudential requirements . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We have removed that and split it into two. The new (k) is as we have indicated in the words I have read. It indicates what the approved provider must use the income for, which we understand is consistent with what the government says is supposed to happen. Then we have reinserted the second half of your existing paragraph (k) as the new (ka). That is what we have done, and we believe that that does not cause any problems along the lines that you have sought to indicate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —While there is some consideration of this matter, it seems that the parliamentary secretary has not addressed the question of whether the accommodation bond can actually be drawn and used rather than invested. I would just like that clarified, because there are a couple of things that flow from that.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that 57-4(2) does not actually say anything other than that a proportion of the accommodation bond balance must be kept in a liquid and secure form. So, arguably, the bond could be used to buy curtains or to finance an extension of the residence. That is really one of the points that I was making before. That may or may not be good policy. I suppose the question is how liquid that is in the event that there is suddenly a rush on the pool of accommodation bonds held by a proprietor.

The requirement to have them refunded in a timely way is really a little vague. What does timely mean? How quickly is timely? I suppose a question that arises is: if timely means six months, does that mean that the proprietor would have to pay some form of interest on the bond held after the proprietor was entitled to hold it? They are questions that seem to me to arise from that general provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we go on to the issues raised by Senator O'Brien, I ask the opposition if they would be prepared to look at the amendment that they have put being amended to cure the problem, as I see it, as to meeting capital works costs and retiring debt—to tie that into aged care.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am getting at is that, as it stands at the moment, it does not relate to aged care. That could be a prospect which could solve this. I do not want to hold up the bill while we go around in circles on this subclause, although it is an important one. Perhaps Senator Woodley might have some ideas on that too. We seem to be at an impasse and, if it is going to progress matters, we would look at an amendment to the opposition amendment, provided it tied into aged care.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would be happy to move on to the next item and see if we can sort out formal words in the meantime on this amendment. We will take up your offer there. Did you wish to respond now to the other issues that Senator O'Brien raised?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —They might fall away if your amendment were to pass. If your amendment is, as you say, such a good amendment, it most probably fixes Senator O'Brien's queries.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Forshaw) proposed:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That further consideration of opposition amendment No. 20 be postponed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would support the postponement. I think that is a good idea. I do not want to add to the confusion, but we ought to try to fix it up. I am minded to support an improved ALP amendment. I think you have raised another problem, though, that I can see. That is, in the initial phase, certainly we would want all of the money to be used for capital, retiring debt, et cetera. But down the road, does there come a point at which a provider has done everything he can possibly do? What does he then do with the income? It seems to me that, once you have done everything that brought your facility up to scratch, there may be the point at which you would want to allow the use of the income for other things. Can you see what I mean?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take that on board. I suggest that we have a look at that on the side while we progress with other matters, because I think we still have some little time to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening carefully to the debate. I was about to indicate that I was prepared to vote for the proposal to postpone opposition amendment No. 20, which was put forward by Senator Forshaw, if only to allow the government time—between now and when the bill goes back to the House of Representatives and probably comes back here—to draft those amendments. But, if you are doing it now in this manner, it is certainly a more civilised way of approaching things.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 20 postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The running sheet indicates that we would now proceed to amendments Nos 3, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 and 17. Originally I was going to seek, by leave, to have those taken together. Revised amendments 10, 12 and 21 have been circulated. Do I need to seek leave to move them?
—No, you may move them in the revised form, Senator Forshaw.

—What I would then be proposing to do, because I envisage the outcome may be different in some respects on some of these, would be to move amendments 3, 13 and 17 together. Therefore, I seek leave to move amendments 3, 13 and 17 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (3) Clause 2-1, page 4 (line 14), omit "a high quality of care", substitute "a high quality of nursing and personal care".
(13) Page 140 (after line 18), after clause 41-2, insert:
41-2A Requirement to use part of residential care subsidy to provide nursing care
The Residential Care Subsidy Principles must specify how much of any *residential care subsidy paid to an approved provider must be used for the provision of nursing care;.
(17) Clause 56-1, page 214 (after line 11), after paragraph (a), insert:

(ab) to use not less than the amount specified in the Residential Care Subsidy Principles as the amount of any *residential care subsidy paid to an approved provider which must be used for the provision of nursing care;

SPEECH.PARA: Following resolution of that motion, we will be seeking to move amendments Nos 9, 10, 11, 12, 14 and 15 together. I will speak essentially to the range of issues covered by this group of amendments which relate to the issue of nursing care. A major issue of concern to many groups involved in the provision of aged care services is the potential diminution of standards, or the requirements to provide appropriate nursing and personal care. I draw your attention to amendment No. 3. That amendment seeks to omit from the bill the words `a high quality of care' and insert, in lieu thereof, the words `a high quality of nursing and personal care'. This is an em phasis that we are seeking to have reiterated in other clauses of the bill.

Evidence was given to the Senate committee, and there have been continuing expressions of concern, by such groups as the Royal College of Nursing, the New South Wales College of Nursing and other groups, that nowhere in the bill does it stipulate, for instance, that nursing care has to be provided by registered or enrolled nurses or by people with adequate training.

Senator West, in her speech during the second reading debate, covered this issue very well and spoke, obviously, from experience. She enunciated the concerns of the professional groups. She referred to the skills that staff are called upon to exercise in providing care in nursing homes and the importance of ensuring that there are adequate numbers of registered or enrolled nurses working in nursing homes.

In the interests of saving time, I do not wish to reiterate all those arguments. The government is well aware of them—as, indeed, are the Democrats. They will recall these issues being raised during the Senate committee proceedings. What I do, however, wish to refer to is the response by the government senators in the committee's report, because it concerns me that this attitude prevails amongst some members of the government. In their minority report, at page 83, in a section relating to an allegation—the allegation being that standards of care will deteriorate under the new system—they state:

PARA.EMPHASIS: This is a completely fallacious argument with no basis in fact and is designed to frighten the aged.

SPEECH.PARA: The line has been run, and is constantly being run by the government, that the issues raised by the opposition are somehow part of a great national scare campaign orchestrated by the opposition to frighten the aged community. Nothing could be further from the truth and it really is a scurrilous allegation. I must indicate that I did not sit through the Senate committee proceedings; I was not a member of the committee at the time. But, having been given this responsibility at about the time the committee was drawing its inquiry to a conclusion, I took the trouble to read the Hansard transcript and the report and I listened to the debate, particularly the contribution from Senator West. I have also had representations from professional organisations.

It should be noted that Senator Woodley said that he and others have given a lot of time and thought to this issue. There are many centres indicating their concerns in this area—that they do not want to see this legislation as the vehicle whereby, because there is no specific recognition of these requirements in the legislation, the nursing standards will fall.

For the government to simply dismiss all of that as some fear or scare campaign being run by the opposition is just, as I said, a scurrilous allegation. And it really is a slur upon the people in the nursing profession, people associated with providing aged care facilities and providing care to the aged. It is a slur on their professional integrity, honesty and commitment to make those sorts of allegations. We did not have to go out and try to scare people. This is not something that is being made up; these are real and genuine concerns felt by groups such as the Royal College of Nursing. They are not going to lightly make these sorts of claims concerning a potential diminution of standards.

These are the people who dedicate their working lives to looking after the frail and the aged in nursing homes and other aged care facilities. They are some of the most dedicated workers in this country. Dare I say it, probably many of them are trade unionists. It appears that because they might wear that tag and are members of an association their views count for very little with this government. This government want to malign them and suggest that this is just some nasty plot by the ALP and the unions.

These expressions of concern and these requests for ensuring that this legislation makes it abundantly clear that professional standards of nursing care and qualified personnel remain are required under the legislation are being put forward by the people who more than anyone know what is required. They are often the only people that nursing home residents have regular contact with. We seek the Senate's support for the amendments that we have moved that relate to requiring aged care services to provide for appropriate access to nursing care services. I do not think I need to go into specific detail in regard to each and every amendment as they pick up that theme and propose the relevant amendments to the sections of the bill that are required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am inclined to not support the ALP amendments, but they nevertheless raise some very real issues. I am genuinely listening to the debate in this regard. The genuine issues that the ALP raise in this area are particularly the concerns that I have arising out of the inquiry. I did not read carefully enough the government's minority report. Thank you for drawing it to my attention because that is a most unfortunate and unfair statement. Of the evidence received, the most substantial evidence was that given by a number of professors from a number of institutions and from the Australian Nursing Federation. I do not think that they were wanting to scare people. I think they were raising real concerns that need to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I am having problems with the ALP amendment is that in trying to cure what I see as a potential problem they are creating some other problems. In amendment No. 3 to change `a high quality of care' to `a high quality of nursing and personal care' seems to me to actually be limiting again. The problem I have with it is that it is restrictive. I guess amendment No. 17 is okay, but again I find that pretty inflexible. I do not know that amendment No. 13 achieves anything. It states:
The Residential Care Subsidy Principles must specify how much of any *residential care subsidy paid to an approved provider must be used for the provision of nursing care.

How on earth could you specify that? I have such problems with the way you have tried to cure what I believe is a potential problem. I do not think you have got it. I ask the parliamentary secretary: how can we get around this problem?

I have had discussions with the government and I think what they were proposing to me was in fact very helpful, but I think it might help the committee if we actually have that on the record. There is the potential for rorting of the system and there is a concern that adequate nursing care be provided. I guarantee that it is not going to happen with the not for profit organisations or the church institutions, but I am not sure about some of the for profit providers. I know that the government probably has more faith in some of the for profit organisations—more faith than I would have in some of them, having seen some of the things that have happened. You can see that we are trying to address a real problem. Could you spell out what the government sees as the answer to this?

Under the previous government, the method that was used to try to guarantee the provision of nursing care was the acquittal method. The problem was that that acquittal method was often three years behind and, in some cases, up to 10 years behind. Really that system was not working. If a staffing problem arose in an institution and you did not find out about it for three years, by that time it had disappeared or got worse. Your system did not work. I am not sure your amendments are getting at the problem, but nevertheless you are describing a real problem. I would like to hear what the government has to say about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are requirements relating to the level and qualifications of staff employed in any approved residential aged care facility. I might firstly turn to 54‐1(1)(b). That requires that an approved provider must `maintain an adequate number of appropriately skilled staff to ensure that the care needs of care recipients are met'. That is a bald statement there. It means that each facility should ensure that the staffing skills mix reflects current resident care needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Across the board you will not need nurses in every facility to the same extent. Some facilities will need more nurses than others. That goes without saying. The basic expectation is that services catering for high care residents will have nursing staff to provide supervision and necessary nursing procedures. Again, that is something the government is willing to put on record.

The prescribed services in 54‐1(1)(a) provide for minimum levels of staffing to ensure resident safety and supervision—that is, all facilities must provide 24‐hour on‐call staff where there are four or more high care residents classified as category four or above out of the eight categories. Then the services must provide qualified nursing care, where shown necessary by the residents assessed care needs, and qualified 24‐hour staff cover is to be provided where there are more than seven high care residents classified at four and above. That is in the quality of care principles. In 54‐1 you have these provisions that go right to the very heart of providing for skilled staff.

You then go back to the question of the objects which opposition amendment No. 3 deals with. I totally agree with Senator Woodley that if you amend 2‐1(1)(b) in the form that the opposition would then you are tying in `high quality of nursing and personal care' as one. What the government is providing is a much broader responsibility and that broader responsibility is to promote a high quality of care and accommodation for recipients of aged services that meets the needs of individuals.

To those who think that the opposition amendment No. 3 on the surface seems to be more targeted, it is. But the trouble is that it casts a more narrow responsibility on the provider. It is the object in the government's legislation that casts a broader obligation—a high quality of care. That relates to everything, not just personal care, not just nursing care—a high quality of care. That would mean that you have sufficient railing on stairs, that your lifts allow for elderly people. My parents, for instance—I declare an interest in this legislation—are going into a hostel themselves. One of the things they look at is the lift and access to the lift. Designing all that is allowing for a high quality of care generally, that you have a building which can facilitate older people and those who are not as mobile as some of us.

The government opposes amendment No. 17. As Senator Woodley said, this is linked to amendment No. 13. It requires not less than the amount specified in the principles to be used for the provision of nursing care. This amendment does not recognise that some residential care services will cater for some people who will not require nursing care at all. We believe that it will maintain red tape, which was detested and is detested by providers in the current system. We would agree with Senator Woodley in his comments. I think that covers the points in relation to the three separate amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Woodley supported my remarks with regard to the comments by the government senators on the committee. I note that Senator Ellison seems to take a more responsive approach on the issue, rather than adopting the rhetoric of trying to belittle the opposition's arguments as some sort of scare campaign. I do appreciate his change of tack, as it were. It is an important issue, and I am sure we all recognise that.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming specifically to the concerns or the reasons put as to why the amendments would not be acceptable, I have often heard arguments about whether the words in clauses are so broad that they include everything but then, because they do not specifically include an important factor, they do not really cover everything. The other argument is put by the government that you have to adopt a narrow interpretation of the words `nursing and personal care' in our amendment and suggest that those words exclude any other sort of care. We do not accept that argument. Equally, we do not accept your argument, Senator Ellison, that the current object, which is the use of the words `high quality of care', specifically ensures that where it is necessary, and where it should apply, appropriate qualified nursing care will be available.

The fact of the matter is that your current wording does not enforce that. It does not ensure that that will occur. You might say that that is the intention and that people will do the right thing, but given the attitude that I have referred to earlier from the government senators on the committee that seem to belittle this whole concern in the first place, we have some real concern—as do the professional organisations—that unless reference to nursing care, to recognised qualifications, is included in the legislation, then facilities will be able to operate without employing even one qualified nurse. That would be possible. We would suggest that that is an outrageous situation to arrive at.

If the government is not prepared to accept our amendments, then ultimately the facts will speak for themselves in the future. But we know that there will be operators out there—there always are; it might be only one or two—that will see this as removing or not requiring certain standards, not ensuring that there is a presence in their facilities of qualified staff. They will look for ways to ensure that they do not have to meet what is said to be an appropriate standard, but which is not required under the legislation.

I make a final point about amendment Nos 13 and 17. Again, it is the same argument, but Senator Woodley said that we had the previous acquittal system, the CAM and SAM arrangements, which people were critical of. Whatever the criticisms may have been, Senator Woodley, the fact is that they were there, specified, and intended to ensure that funds granted were utilised in the manner which was intended. Having thrown that system out, there is nothing here that replaces it in this legislation, that requires a demonstration, if you like, that will ensure that the requirements would be met in the future, as they were required to be under the old system.

I have heard plenty of criticisms about the old system. The first time I came into the Senate three years ago I became a member of this committee, which I am now back on. There was a debate going on at that time about CAM and SAM. If I heard it once, I heard it a thousand times. What we are endeavouring to do is ensure that the aspect of that system which required that providers not siphon off funds intended for care and put them into other areas continue to apply under this legislation—albeit that those acquittal methods have been abandoned. What we do not want to see is the other extreme, where you will have facilities which will utilise the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act and the opportunities that are open there to negotiate outside awards, reach in-house agreements, or demand the acceptance of individual contracts. We do not want to see a breakdown of those standards, ending up in a deterioration in the standards that should be applicable in nursing homes. Those are the reasons why we put them forward.

I do at least appreciate the fact that you are coming towards supporting them, or you support what we are trying to do. That is a start. I wish we could get you to support what we are doing as well, because it is a darn sight better than what is there at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up the time of the debate unnecessarily, but it seems to me that there is an understanding of Senator Woodley's objection to amendment 3, but there is his acceptance of some of the principles that we are seeking to address. Perhaps one of the problems is the meaning given in the definition to the term `residential care', which may need to be quite broad, but it is broad enough to be read as possibly excluding `nursing care'. Residential care is `personal care or nursing care, or both personal care and nursing care'. Then there is a determination of what that care is supposed to provide. Clearly, under that definition, it is permissible to provide residential care which includes only personal care, not nursing care. Nowhere in the definitions are the terms `personal care' or `nursing care' defined, from what I can find.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Residential care has two alternatives, for obvious reasons, because in the hostel you might not need that nursing care. I do not think you need to define nursing care and personal care. The words speak for themselves. What you have got with the amendment is a situation where you are talking about `nursing and personal care,' not `nursing or personal care'. That is why we say there is a problem here. It is a situation where you could be casting an undue onus on a hostel, for instance. I think they should be looked at as two discrete requirements for discrete residents who have different needs.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, in the case of my parents, they certainly do not need the nursing care. They are going to a hostel. They are both elderly but do not require the services of a nurse. So that is why we have that in there, Senator O'Brien. I think it is a more compendious provision by the government than the one offered by the opposition. We also have the accreditation standards. Accreditation is the way that you really apply the acid test. If a facility does not have the staffing I mentioned and the principles, and I detailed them earlier, of course their accreditation is at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sympathetic to what Senator O'Brien and Senator Forshaw are saying because I have the same concerns. The problem, though, is that you do not cure it with a definition. Admittedly, amendments Nos 13 and 17 go towards a mechanism to try and get in place what they are saying, but I am still not convinced that it is any better than what the government, through the accreditation system, is providing. What you will get with the accreditation system is an absolute channelling for anyone who is fair dinkum about providing a proper facility, a channelling into a high quality of nursing care.

SPEECH.PARA: I do agree that the problem is that there are some unscrupulous operators who will get around anything. Simply because you put your mechanism in place is not going to stop them. What I am hoping is that the accreditation system will be as good as the government says it is and that we will pick up those unscrupulous operators. That is what we have got to get it to.

Most of the providers will be wanting to do the right thing. I have been into an awful lot of aged care complexes, and I put on the record my experience. I am inclined to stay with the government, but I have to say to the government: you really have to deliver on this one, because there are some baddies out there, and you had better get them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what Senator Woodley said and what Senator Ellison said. The accredita tion system is absolutely necessary and no doubt will catch a lot providers that should be caught. But the accreditation system does not give the person receiving residential care an ability to enforce the provisions of the act. One thing that the opposition's amendment does is arm and empower a user of residential care more so than leaving it to an accreditation system. Could you comment on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that the opposition's amendments go any further than the government's amendments in relation to empowerment. They merely cast an onus upon the provider, just as ours do. In fact, I think that the requirement of a high quality of care is a wider and broader onus to cast upon the shoulders of the provider than the narrower focus suggested by the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: When we have our complaints committee, one of the things that the resident could do is go to the committee and say, `Look, a high quality of care means providing adequate railings on the stairs.' That is a high quality of care because of the duty that is owed to the person living there. That does not relate to nursing, it does not relate to personal care; it is a general high quality of care.

Our definition would empower that person even more so to go to the complaints committee and say, `Look, they're falling down in the objects of this act because they're not providing a high quality of care.' A high quality of care would be making sure that the floors are not slippery; it would be making sure that the steps are clearly visible; it would be making sure that you have ramps rather than steps to make it easier for elderly people to go up if they have a gofer, for instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —A gofer? They come from America.
—For those of you who do not know what a gofer is—my mother is thinking of buying one—they are little motorised carts that can get you around pretty quickly.
—I think that's what you and I need, Senator Ellison.

—Senator Forshaw, I think you and I will both end up in one one day. If you go to most hostels, you will see a stack of them outside all plugged in getting charged overnight. Providing that sort of care all comes into it. It is not just the personal care of looking after someone in a nursing home. It ranges from that, with a nurse, right through to a hostel which has all these facilities for elderly people.

—I would agree with everything you said if proposed amendment No. 17 was an alternative, but it is an addition. Everything that you have said still remains. What the amendment does is enable a person to say, `Look, I should get nursing care.' There can be no argument about that. It eliminates a step in the argument. You do not have to say, `Look, I'm entitled to good care. I'm going to argue that good care includes nursing care.' You do not have to take that step. You can go straight to the issue and say, `In addition to the gofer, in addition to the ramps, in addition to all those things, you have to give me good nursing care.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the instrument for this particular facility, you need nursing care. I will point again to the principles I mentioned, which dealt with the number of staff that you have to have where you have residents of classification 4 and above. All that is provided for in the principles. There is that bound in there.

SPEECH.PARA: The resident will be able to point to all this and say, `This is why we should have an extra nurse'—because, under the principles, it will say `four nurses', `seven nurses,' or whatever. It is already catered for in the principles. There is enough for a resident to rely on in both the bill and the principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, this is my final comment on this—that is what I hope, anyway. I just cannot let Senator Ellison's spuri ous example go that, by proposing the change that we do, somehow you will have a facility in the future that will not have any railings on the stairs or—
—No, I said `sufficient railings'. There is a big difference.

—Senator Ellison, I am sure you are aware that it is not only the aged care legislation of this parliament that ensures that buildings and facilities have appropriate structural requirements. There is a whole host of planning law, state and local government. There is a myriad of things that deal with those issues. I think it is a bit of a red herring to be using that as an example to suggest that our proposals somehow leave it open slather to not comply with those things—particularly when you, yourself, have said that you will have an accreditation system, and you are setting up an accommodation bond system which is designed to produce income to provide all the facilities and those things about which you have just spoken. But I will leave my comments at that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 8-3, page 18 (after line 25), after paragraph (b), insert:
(ba) any person who is responsible for the nursing services provided, or to be provided, by the *aged care service conducted, or to be conducted, by the applicant.
(10) Clause 8-3, page 18 (after line 32), after subclause (3), insert:
(3A) A person referred to in paragraph (3)(ba) must hold a recognised qualification in nursing.
(11) Clause 9-1, page 22 (after line 19), after paragraph (2)(b), insert:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 252 (after line 25), after clause 63‐1, insert:

TAB.EMPHASIS: 63‐2 Annual report on the operation of the Act

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister must, as soon as practicable after 30 June but before 30 September in each year, cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a report on the operation of this Act during the year ending on 30 June of that year.
(2) A report under subsection (1) must include information about the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (a) the extent of unmet demand for places; and
(b) the adequacy of the Commonwealth subsidies provided to meet the care needs of residents; and
(c) the extent to which providers are complying with their responsibilities under the Act; and
(d) the amounts of accommodation bonds charged; and
(e) the duration of waiting periods for entry to residential care; and
(f) the extent of building, upgrading and refurbishment of aged care facilities; and
(g) the imposition of any sanctions for non‐compliance under Part 4.4, including details of the nature of the non‐compliance and the sanctions imposed;

SPEECH.PARA: but is not limited to information about those matters.

The original proposal for an annual report on the operation of the act was set out and it took up almost two pages. We have reconsidered that proposed amendment and set out in the revised amendment something which is a lot shorter in terms of the requirements for information to be included in an annual report to be laid before each house of parliament each year, but they still go to very important issues.

We believe that it is essential that there be a reporting process to the parliament by the minister. The Democrats have announced that there would be an annual report to the parliament, but there is nothing in the legislation at this point that would ensure that. There is nothing in the other proposed reviews that are part of the agreement between the government and the Democrats that provides an opportunity for the parliament to make an assessment. The Democrats and the government did not accept our proposed amendment to require in legislation that independent review. But, hopefully, they will support us in this proposal which is to require the minister to provide, as soon as practicable after 30 June each year but before 30 September, a report on the operation of the act.

That report must include information about the matters set out in the amendment. They go to such things as the extent of the unmet demand for places; the adequacy of the Commonwealth subsidies provided to meet the care needs of residents; the extent to which providers are complying with their responsibilities under the act; the amounts of accommodation bonds charged; the duration of waiting periods for entry to residential care; the extent of building, upgrading and refurbishment of aged care facilities; and the imposition of any sanctions for non‐compliance under part 4. We believe that that will certainly give the parliament an opportunity to assess the operation of this act and consider such report. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the letters from the Uniting Church, Anglicare Australia and the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, and a letter from myself to the minister which deal with this issue, and also the minister's reply to each of those letters. I said earlier in the debate that I would do this at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated to the ALP that I would not support subsection (2) as it was originally circulated. I do think that what is now listed under (2) is the appropriate information that we would want to see. I believe that while it will not limit the minister, because it does say, `but is not limited to information about those matters', it will provide some guidance for the development of the guidelines which have already been promised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. I point out that, in fact, the minister has committed herself to a review of this legislation and the government is already required to report to parliament the outcomes for aged care through the annual parliamentary reporting process. It may be that the last sentence in the amendment, `but is not limited to information about those matters' could be used as an authority for wider reporting. But there is always a danger, when you are too specific in the requirement, that you tend to limit the report to those matters anyway. We would submit that this is a narrower requirement of the minister than is currently the case, but I will not take it any further. The government will oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
