SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have in relation to opposition amendment No. 20, which dealt with clause 57-2, a new proposed subclause (n). As I understand it from reading the note I have—and we will confirm this with the opposition—the new proposed subclause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (n) the approved provider must use the income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount in the following ways:
(i) to meet capital works costs relating to residential care;
(ii) to retire debt relating to residential care; or
(iii) to improve the quality and range of aged care services.
Subclause 57-2(k) will not be used to circumvent the intention of subclause (n). I remind the Senate that subclause 57-2(k) states:

(k) the approved provider must not use the accommodation bond for a purpose that is not related to providing aged care to care recipients, or that does not comply with the prudential requirements (see section 57-3);
I understand that opposition amendment has the agreement of the Democrats. What is the position of the opposition? Perhaps Senator Forshaw could help us.

It is the government's position that providers would not be able to charge an accommodation bond and invest that without there being certification or accreditation. That means that there is an ongoing certification and accreditation in relation to those provid ers. They would have to invest the bond in aged care capital and maintain the standards that would be required by that accreditation and certification.
I have said that for the record because I understand that is a concern of the Democrats and Senator Woodley. I hope that goes some way to meeting that concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little hard to properly investigate what is being proposed. But from what was read out, the third category of expenditure seems to me to be well in excess of what might normally be seen as capital expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The improvement of services, I would have thought, could have included things like providing more occupational therapy, providing more nursing and a lot of things that most people would not really consider to be in the capital realm. I would appreciate the parliamentary secretary advising his views on that issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that related to Senator Woodley's previous inquiry when he said, `Look, say you use your accommodation bond to plough back into the capital works and you have done everything that is possible, then you should be able to use any excess in relation to therapy and care of that nature.' Additional services, of course, come under the high quality of care that I mentioned earlier in our objectives. So I would say that that would come within it and that you should be able to do that after having met those other requirements.

—If that is the case, there is nothing that is contained in your amendment that requires all capital requirements to have been satisfied before (iii). The way it is framed with (i), (ii), an `or' and then (iii), you could just bypass (i) and (ii) and go on to (iii). But essentially you might be using it for recurrent funding when you have potential capital expenditure still not gone to.

—Can I seek clarification a little bit further? I understood from the way we worded (i), (ii) and (iii) that that interpretation could be put on it. But the guarantee is, of course, that you will never meet accreditational certification unless you do them in that order. You really cannot go to (iii) until you have done (i) and (ii) because the whole system would not work. Is it your understanding, Parliamentary Secretary, that with the accreditation certification system it is impossible to do (iii) until (i) and (ii) are completed satisfactorily?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is entirely correct. That is the point I was going to make.

—Rather than just a bald statement to that effect, you might like to explain exactly how the mechanism works. On the face of it, there is nothing contained in your proposed amendment that seems to rely on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is the accreditation and certification that requires it. It does not have to be contained in the amendment because the accreditation and certification processes require that anyway.

—Are you aware, Parliamentary Secretary, that you must comply with the accreditation before you can request or require an accommodation bond anyway? So, once you have overcome the requirement of accreditation, options (i), (ii) and (iii) are all available to you immediately. Of course, you would not have any funds payable until you had actually been accredited anyway.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The accreditation and certification is on ongoing process.
—Could you please point out, then, the portion of the accreditation requirements that you say have the effect that you have stated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you turn to 209, you will see 54‐2, accreditation standards. Subsection (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Quality of Care Principles may set out Accreditation Standards. Accreditation Standards are standards for quality of care and quality of life for the provision of residential care on and after the accreditation day.

Subsection (2) goes on to deal with what accreditation standards may deal with. That outlines the area of accreditation. As for the certification, that is dealt with in part 2.6, division 37 of the bill, clauses 37‐1 and on from that. Clause 37‐2 states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Certification Principles

SPEECH.PARA: The certification of residential care services is also dealt with in the Certification Principles.
They will be the principles dealing with the process I mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, thank you for pointing out the sections of the bill that deal with accreditation and certification. But you still have not shown me or explained what section of the certification or accreditation requires them to satisfy items (i) and (ii) of your amendment before moving on to (iii). I will explain to you what my concern is. I think Senator Woodley himself might be concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: What might well happen—again, particularly in the commercial nursing home operations—is that they could get in funds under the accommodation bond ostensibly for capital purposes. They could then use the funds for what might be described as improvements to aged care services—say, for provision of nursing care. They could then transfer the funds that they would ordinarily have used for the provision of nursing care to their bottom line to be distributed as profit. It seems to me that would completely subvert the original purpose of this bill, which is to ensure that the accommodation bond is used for the purposes of capital improvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having the principles in relation to the certification aspect looked at. I would also draw Senator Neal's attention to 38‐3, suitability of residential care service for certification. That outlines various aspects that the secretary must have regard to in relation to certification dealing with the standard of the buildings, the standard of residential care and whether the applicant has been a provider of aged care and its conduct as such a provider. It is set out there, so I will not go on. It does say `any other matters specified in the Certification Principles'.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the principles, I would refer you to the exposure draft dealing with the Aged Care Bill principles and, in particular, clause 14‐1 which deals with the nature of assessment. It says that the secretary must not approve a method of assessment unless the assessment deals with aspects of the residential care service. It goes on to list those aspects. That clause goes into more detail about whether the buildings and equipment being used to provide the service and care meet the requirements of any state law. It goes on with details about the service providing a secure and safe environment, adequate personal privacy, availability of and access to public transport and, similarly, medical care.
Those are the sorts of things that are being assessed in relation to the certification. That relates directly to the provisions we have mentioned in this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have a situation where you have come back with a revised proposed amendment about which Senator Woodley has raised a question which I would put to you as well. I would like you to put an answer to this on the record. Is it the government's intention and understanding here that the ability to utilise the income in respect of placitum (iii) would occur only after the req uirements of (i) and/or (ii) have been met? In other words, is that the position of the government?
—Yes.

—If it were to come to pass that that was not what occurred but in fact you had a situation where the funds were being used on recurrent expenses—in other words, under (iii) where there was still a failure to comply with (i) and (ii)—what would be the government's position then with respect to further reviewing the operation of this section? I think that goes to the question that Senator Woodley raised as well, if I am correct. How do you propose to ensure that that would be avoided? That is the nub of the issue: we are looking for a way to ensure that the proposed words give effect to a sequential application, if you like—that you cannot utilise the income for (iii) if you have not met (i) and (ii).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The three‐month review and the 12‐month review, which are not that far away, would certainly be looking at how this would operate.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing is that the thorough assessment which is made in relation to certification would pick this up. It is listed in that order of (i), (ii) and (iii), because capital works are important and that is primarily what we are looking at. So you acquit that first, then you move on to retiring debt and then you move on to the quality and range of aged care services. That is the order it is taken in. I cannot say what a review of this part of the operation would reveal. It is certainly going to be looked at and looked at very soon, because we have a review three months after proclamation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary and Senator Woodley, could we put forward these additional words in (iii) that, hopefully, would more clearly spell that out—that assurance that you have just given. In (iii), in front of the words `to improve the quality and range of aged care services'—that is your word ing—we would insert the words `and where no capital expenditure is required or likely to be required under subparagraph (i) or (ii)'. Then it would follow on with the words you have already put forward. So (iii) would read in full:

SPEECH.PARA: where no capital expenditure is required or likely to be required under subparagraphs (i) or (ii), to improve the quality and range of aged care services;
We believe that that more adequately spells out that it is a sequential process before you get to (iii).

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My only query is how you determine where no capital expenditure is required. I suppose that is more explicit than `or likely to be required'. It is less definite than the first part of your amendment. But perhaps Senator Woodley could guide us here with his experience.

—The problem is that it has just dropped on me out of the blue. It is very hard to know all the implications of language when you do not have the time to consider it. It seems to me to be picking up the intent of what the parliamentary secretary has said, but there may be problems with it.
—The review process would show that up.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I suggest that the government would be inclined to stick with the amendment it is proposing and to see how this provision operates. At the three‐month review stage we would have a look at that. If there is a further amendment needed in the terms suggested by the opposition, then so be it. But it is something which we have placed on the record that we will look at as to how it operates. I do not think much harm is going to befall anyone in the space of three months. I think it is fairly clear what the government's intention is as to how this should work. I think that the providers can see that; it is on the record; and there is no reason why it should not work. But if there is some problem with it, we could revisit it in a minor amendment.

—What is more likely to be required would deal with the question of depreciation. I just want you to get your mind around that—that in fact that is an improvement of the provision for future expenditure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing with future depreciation is an inexact art. In fact, I would put to you that it is very difficult to assess how a building will depreciate in the future. That is the problem I have with that term. I think that the government cannot accept that amendment and will press its amendment as I have proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison, what you said, both in response to our earlier proposals and then in support of your own proposal, is that there will be mechanisms established in the review process which will look at all these things anyway and see how they will work out. If problems do arise, as we have suggested they may well do, or if other issues come through that have been unexpected, then you can have a further look at it. We would say that that is precisely a process that should be able to be adopted in regard to what we are now saying these words should state.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are suggesting is that the additional words `where no capital expenditure is required or likely to be required under subparagraphs (i) and (ii)' pick up precisely, we believe, the intent that you have put on the record. Rather than run with proposals which clearly cause concern—and I understand Senator Woodley has raised them and we have raised them—what we would put to you would be to accept the wording we have put forward, which makes it that much clearer what the intent is. It will be in the legislation. They do not have to come back and read the Hansard of what we said here at 10.20 p.m. on the second last day of this session. It is there.

If the problems come to pass—and they will not show up in three months; it will be a bit further down the track than that, given the impact of all these changes—we can have a look at it again. If there are no problems, the amendments work fine. I cannot really see why you cannot accept the wording, given that it reflects the intention that you have stated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can take it much further. The words, as I have said, are uncertain, and I do not think they improve the government's amendment. The government opposes them.

—I would indicate that there is a further process in this, which is that obviously the amendments will go to the House of Representatives. They then may come back, and that will give us time for further consideration. At this stage I would stay with the ALP words which have been added, but I do not think that is the end of the matter. I would be prepared to work through this some more when the message comes back from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

—Senator Forshaw, that is the amendment before the chair at the moment.

—That is correct. Senator Ellison has been referring to the government's amendment, but he came back and read the revised words that people had talked about. The ALP amendment, as has been read out, proposes that there be a new paragraph (n). The amendment reads:

—No. What I have just read out is a revised version of amendment 20.

—I seek leave to withdraw the original amendment 20 and move the revised amendment.

TITLE.XREF: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see that the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1997 is finally being debated. I think it has been on and off the agenda for the last three or four weeks. I will be very relieved to see it dealt with and I am sure the government will be as well. Essentially, the opposition does not oppose this bill as it improves the method of payment of veterans' benefits and also establishes a vocational rehabilitation scheme for veterans that was initiated by the previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of the veterans' rehabilitation scheme was initiated by a program put forward by Senator Faulkner in 1994. The adoption by this government of this particular scheme must be an endorsement of his original concept and to some extent a back‐handed congratulation for his initiative—probably one of the few that will be received by him from this government.

Effectively, it provides a scheme whereby veterans can be retrained to return to the work force. It also sets up a protection of their benefits that ensures that those veterans who may be reticent to return to the work force because they are fearful that once they lose their benefits they may never regain them if something untoward happens with their job, will be able to return to those benefits.

Senators are probably aware of many veterans in their electorates—and I certainly am—who have been scared either physically or psychologically by their experience in warfare and have not been in a fit state to return to employment for many years. The trouble with these sorts of difficulties is that they were not easily overcome. Sometimes when a psychological problem or psychiatric problem is overcome the pressure of returning to employment, the stress of exposure to the general community and the stress of having to comply with guidelines and the normal pressures of employment can be additional stress on veterans that they cannot cope with.They may return to the state they were in before and be unable to retain their employment.

The second part of the rehabilitation scheme—that is, the protection of their benefits—is a very important part of the program and ensures that veterans approach their rehabilitation with a great deal of enthusiasm and certainty that there is security of that underlying benefit if their attempt to return to employment were to fail.

The second major part of the bill, which is supported by the opposition, is the rationalisation of payments between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security. They are in two parts. Veterans or their spouses who are receiving disability pensions can have them paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs where previously they might have been paid by the Department of Social Security. Carers paid by Veterans' Affairs will be transferred to the Department of Social Security. Essentially, it means that whatever sorts of payments people are receiving they will only have to deal with one department rather than a multiple of departments as is the case in many circumstances at the present time. There is an essential benefit for all those receiving payments. It is a simpler and more straightforward system of payment.

The only concern we might have—and I suppose it will require time to see whether this concern is borne out—is that the transfer of payments away from the Department of Veterans' Affairs may eventually mean that the purpose of Veterans' Affairs is lost. I am hoping it is not the intention of this government to eventually abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs in a continuation of their slash and burn approach to restructuring and rationalisation.

There is a section of this bill that we do not support and that is the section that reduces the benefits that are payable to veterans. This is done in a number of ways. This government describes it as better targeting of income support benefits. This is done in three ways. The first is the cutting of rental benefits for single persons who are sharing accommodation. You might recall that this issue was debated at some length in relation to the social security budget measures and it is in identical terms.

It assumes that where two single people are sharing a home and receiving rental assistance somehow their costs will be reduced and accordingly they should see receive less rental assistance. We have had this debate at some length before—and I suppose we will have it again in the committee stage of this bill, so I do not wish to dwell on it excessively. But it is firmly the view of the opposition that because people share a home and may share the cost of food, groceries and those sorts of expenses, they do not share the costs of accommodation because each of them is required to have their own bedroom, and that is normally the determinant of the sort of rent that is payable.

I suppose one of the most callous things about this measure is the fact that the government is prepared to remove it for the people in this category when in fact there are only 340 people who are affected. That means that the savings that are achieved with this particular bill are almost microscopic—in fact, $21,000. That really is not a very large amount of money to inflict the sort of concern and upset on people who I would have thought the government would have had more regard to, particularly a conservative government that like to fly the flag of patriotism and support for our veterans. Certainly those sentiments did not stop them imposing this particular cut.

The second change that is also really a twin to the changes made under the social security budget legislation is to deem income for those people between the ages of 55 and 60 who have superannuation in place. I must confess that we see this as a betrayal of all the principles that were put in place by the creation of superannuation in Australia. Superannuation was put in place to ensure that people once they retired, not before—and I would like to emphasise that point—were guaranteed a secure source of income. We really do consider it a complete betrayal of that principle to require people before retirement to access their superannuation. Certainly it is not only a betrayal of those principles but also, I think, essentially short-sighted.

There is one difficulty: by deeming income from their superannuation and requiring those people at aged 55, in effect, to access their superannuation because they will not have the other source of income from their periodic benefits, they will run out of their superannuation before they might have. Eventually, having used all their superannuation and still surviving the same length of time, they will have to call on the state to provide them with a pension or in some circumstances a larger pension than they would otherwise have had. It is a proposition that we see as being wrong in principle and short-sighted in effect.

The third matter where there is a reduction in veterans' benefits is the discontinuation of the saved eligibility for fringe benefits for some service pensioners. Obviously, it is a fairly small matter but we see any erosion of benefits to our veterans as something that we are opposed to and, being part of this package which erases their benefits, we are in opposition to that proposition.

As I said at the outset, the large part of the bill, the positive aspects—the introduction of the vocational rehabilitation scheme for veterans and the simplification of the payment of their benefits—we support, but we do not support the reduction in benefits payable to them. We will be putting forward amendments to those two areas seeking to remove them from the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill we are considering today gives effect to a number of the veterans' affairs related measures which were announced in last year's budget. Most of the measures contained in this bill are non‐controversial and the Democrats have no problem in supporting them. There are two parts of the bill, however, that we will not be able to support. The first of these, schedule 5, amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to remove the means test for superannuation assets in certain cases. I will be talking further about this part of the bill once we move into the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of this bill which we will not be able to support is part 3 of schedule 1. This is the section of the bill which reduces the amount of rent assistance payable to single veterans sharing accommodation. Part 3 of schedule 1 mirrors changes to the social security legislation we dealt with towards the end of last year, and the position we are taking today is consistent with the line we took then. While the Democrats acknowledge that this change affects only a small number of veterans, we do not believe that this justifies the implementation of a measure which not only is unfair but also is based on assumptions which are fundamentally flawed.

The government justify cutting the amount of rent assistance payable to single people who share accommodation because they believe that they can achieve cheaper housing costs than single people who live alone. I would like to point out the main reason we disagree with this assumption. Firstly, people who share accommodation often do so because they are on a low income and they can only afford to spend a limited amount on accommodation each week. The biggest economy of scale these people reap is cheaper rent. Because they pay less rent they receive less rent assistance. Thus the current system already takes account of these economies of scale.

Secondly, while people may achieve economies of scale other than rental costs by sharing accommodation, reducing rent assistance to account for these savings is not appropriate as, in the department's own words, rent assistance is not intended to meet non‐housing costs. Finally, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the coalition's pre-election social security document specifically stated:
The coalition recognises the vital role of rent assistance in reducing after housing poverty. A coalition government is committed to maintaining the real value of rent assistance.

Once again, the Democrats will not support this government's attempts to break its own election promise. Finally, the Democrats would like to commend the government for establishing the veterans' vocational rehabilitation scheme, contained in schedule 6. This is a measure that the various veterans groups have been lobbying for for a long time, and we are very pleased to see it finally coming to fruition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to briefly address the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill again tonight, specifically looking at rent assistance. I am really sorry that this bill is coming in so late. The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill, which this bill mirrors, came in late and was a hurried debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly draw attention to the second reading speech, which talks about the transfer to the Department of Social Security of the payments for carers who were receiving payments under the Veterans' Affairs Act. The second reading speech says:
A small number of carers, who could be disadvantaged or temporarily inconvenienced by the transfer, will continue to be paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

When I look at what the explanatory memorandum says on rent assistance, I find no mention that people who are continuing under the DVA to receive the carers payments will be exempted from the impact of the cuts to the rent assistance for single people sharing. Yet under the Social Security Act that particular group of people has been granted exemption. I suspect that an anomaly has occurred here. I hope that, in the minister's summing up on the second reading or in the committee stage, he is able to clarify whether in fact there is an anomaly that affects these people who remain carers and disadvantages them even further. I think it highlights the hastiness with which a number of the changes were made to this rent assistance. It does not do anything in any way to reduce my criticism of this measure.

I am sure that the minister is going to come up with her usual comments as to why it should be done. However, if the minister were to go and visit a number of the accommoda tion places in Sydney that I know still exist that offer people rental accommodation—which will be classified as shared accommodation because these people have to share a kitchen and a bathroom—she would see some of the grottiest, most revolting, degraded rooming houses in inner Sydney. I might add that these places are charging quite large rents. Such people are affected by this legislation, and I think it is an appalling thing that they are. This issue certainly needs to be debated further. Also when I read the explanatory memorandum, I find that I get a bit confused. The outline on the top of page ii talks about rent assistance, stating:

It will not be applicable to people who have dependant children, pay for their board and lodging, are in a nursing home or receive service pension or income support supplement on the ground of permanent incapacity for work.

When I turn to pages 8 and 9 in the explanatory memorandum, where there is a more detailed explanation, I see nothing there to give me any indication about the people who are in receipt of service pension or income support supplement on the ground of permanent incapacity for work. I wonder whether there is a mistake in the explanatory memorandum. The exemption is mentioned in one part and not in part 3 on page 8.
I also have concerns when I read the explanatory memorandum because on page 8 under the heading `Explanation of the changes' the second sentence in the second paragraph states:

If a person lives with at least one of their children and that child receives specified government assistance such as AUSTUDY or a social security payment, the person may still be determined to be a single person sharing accommodation, provided the other criteria are satisfied.

I am still looking for them. We now know that Austudy is about to be changed to the youth allowance and that there is going to be rent assistance in that. What is going to be the impact upon the rent assistance component in this youth allowance payment when the people are in this situation? Is the rent assistance component of the youth allowance going to be modified and played around with because they are living in this type of accommodation, or are they going to get the full rent assistance out of the youth allowance and their parent, who they might be living with, will in fact suffer a cut in their rent assistance? Those are just a couple of the anomalies that I think need to be looked at. I also think that we need to look at the second sentence in the second paragraph on page 9, which says:

For instance, a person who pays most of the bills of a group house, and therefore incurs living expenses that are more than if the person was living alone, might still be determined to be a single person sharing accommodation if the person pays them in exchange for having equal use of a car owned or maintained by another sharer.

This looks like they are creating a problem for a number of people who have disabilities who may share accommodation with people and pay more of the rent or more of the accommodation costs, because in return for that they get assistance to be able to live in a normal situation, so-called, rather than having to live in an institution. These matters highlight a number of questions that need to be asked about this attack on rent assistance and this attack on poor people who live in cities such as Sydney, where the rent and accommodation costs are equal to or as high as anything in the world. Therefore, even people living in very grotty, run-down, low quality accommodation are charged very large amounts of rent. This takes no cognisance of the fact that there are many people in Sydney in that situation who are on low incomes and are paying out significantly large amounts of their income on just the basic rental accommodation. I think that this is something that the minister and the government certainly need to be looking at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to be brief. I just wanted to make a comment with respect to the deeming of superannuation. Unfortunately, this is a re‐run of the debate that occurred last year on this measure which is contained in the legislation that is before us. We do have an opportunity to reconsider through this legislation the issue of the deeming of superannuation in its entirety. We made it very clear last year that we thought that this proposal to deem superannuation earnings when a person turned 55 was one of the most vicious measures contained in the budget of August last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Since Labor proposed last year a cut‐off of $250,000 of superannuation assets that you could have before this vicious measure took effect, I would have to say that the community concern on this matter has not died down at all. In fact, as the effective operative date draws closer and closer, the community concern has grown and grown. I am not going to read the entire correspondence into the record, but I just want to give a couple of examples. My friend and colleague Mr Peter Morris in the other place passed on to me a letter from a Mrs J. Neuman. She outlined her and her husband's circumstances. They voluntarily took redundancy packages in May 1993. A major factor in their decision was receiving social security payments up until the age of 65.

TALK.START.PARA: —How disgraceful; terrible; shocking. It is shocking what you did. You opened a gateway and they drove trucks through it.

—It is shocking, Senator Newman, that you are proposing to deal with this issue in the way you are. It is a pity you do not listen to the sorts of concerns that are outlined in this letter. They have received advice that, from September this year, they will lose $60 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a letter from a disabled former police officer. He outlines his particular circumstances. There are three people from the north‐west coast of Tasmania in a similar situation. I will mention them by name but I will not go through the details of the cases. Mr Doug Krushka, Mr Peter Cooney and Mr Brian Youd have either voluntarily retired or have been retrenched. That is an all too common event in Tasmania. They have also been informed that they will loose various social security payments.

It seems to me there is a basic contradiction in the government's approach. On the one hand, we had the announcement in the last budget that persons should not be allowed to access their superannuation over the prescribed timetable that was announced before the age of 60. On the other hand, we have a measure here that we dealt with last year that forces people to take their superannuation between the age of 55 and 60—not in total, but in part.

Senator Newman interjected earlier that we had allowed a gateway. We had allowed a gateway, Senator Newman, for a very good reason: for the vast majority of people coming up to 55 or who are already 55, the harsh reality is that finding alternative employment is not easy. Certainly, the considerable majority of cases we have had presented to us at the present time are men who find that the harsh reality of finding alternative employment is extraordinarily difficult.

They are, by and large, people who made a decision many years ago to voluntarily put money into superannuation and who sacrificed their recurrent expenditure to boost their superannuation saving on the understanding that, under the rules at that time and the rules up until December last year, when we passed the deeming of the superannuation provision, if they could not find alternative employment or they were on a disability pension—as is the case with this former police officer—they could place their superannuation into some form of vehicle. If they were unable to find employment or if they were on a disability pension and qualified, then they would have access, on the criteria established for unemployment benefits, disability pensions, et cetera, to that social security.

These people are absolutely outraged by the changing of the goalposts, as they put it to me continually, in respect of the deeming of superannuation. The reality for them is that, in many cases, they will have to draw down on their superannuation to make up for a loss of income as a consequence of the effect of deeming.

The second issue that we have encountered—that all of them have been encountering as they have gone off to their financial advisers, because this measure takes effect from September this year—is that in many cases they are going to have to unravel their commitments. They entered into a commitment in respect of superannuation. They may have locked away their money until they were 60, 62, 63, or whatever the age. Firstly, they have to pay for advice to find out how to unravel their superannuation arrangements. Secondly, in many cases, there are penalty provisions for unravelling their investments early.

The two problems I have mentioned are very substantial indeed. It is hitting these people in the community at one of the most difficult times in their life—turning 55, on a disability pension, or unemployed—often as a consequence of redundancy. What are we going to tell the BHP workers who are all going to lose their jobs? How can you explain this to the people I have mentioned here in the debate? Senator Newman can talk about gateways all she likes, but the fact is that the set of rules that existed was the set of rules that people made investment decisions under for a very long time frame.

TALK.START.PARA: —For three years; just for three years. Get your facts right. You opened it in 1993.

—It is not three years, Senator Newman. I am talking about people making a conscious decision to invest in superannuation many years ago, voluntarily. This is before the advent of compulsory superannuation. Senator Newman, you are quite right. Changes affecting this area were made in 1993, for quite deliberate reasons.
—A mistake, based on the wrong assumptions.

—You can say it is a mistake, Senator Newman. But a Labor government took a decision accepting the reality of the time for people who were in this situation. I do not want to take the time of the Senate any longer. We know we have an opportunity to reconsider this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say to you, Senator Newman, is that the outrage from people in the community is gathering. Every year more and more people are going to be affected by this measure, because of the ageing population and because of the growth in superannuation accounts. We will sheet home the blame where it should lie. This is, as I say, one of the most vicious, unfair measures left over from August last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. Absolute rubbish.

—You can say rubbish, Senator Newman. I will accept the interjection. My colleagues in the other place and in the Senate have been inundated with letters. I had a meeting with a number of retiree organisations, over‐55 organisations, over the last few months, and this is one issue above all others about which they complain in the strongest terms.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, Senator Newman, come September, as more and more people discover they are going to be hit by this provision, I do not think you will know what you have unleashed. It is certainly a very, very draconian measure to treat people who often, for reasons they cannot help, have been made unemployed or redundant—and there are plenty of them in Tasmania, as we know, Senator Newman, as over the year in that state the unemployment rate has continued to climb. I conclude by saying that we hope the Senate takes this opportunity to reverse and put an end to this vicious measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to enter this debate. I do so, believing that it is a fine opportunity for the whole of the Senate—in fact, for the whole of the parliament—to revisit what occurred in December last year. I do not want to deal with all of the measures in this legislation. For many, almost all, of them, the government is to be commended. But I do wish to refer to the matter that other senators have referred to, including the latest two being Senator Woodley and Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to have the opportunity of revisiting this particular matter, because I believe that there has been a degree of misunderstanding. I will be pointing to particular aspects of answers that I was given previously which, whilst going through with a fine‐tooth comb might have been technically correct, nevertheless, gave an impression that may have misled some readers.

In the debate on this issue last year, I did ask a question—and I think it was of Senator Sherry at that time—about why a person with a house, plus $180,000, plus $250,000 in superannuation, should be regarded as eligible for welfare. I have had time to reflect on that matter. The first thing I would like to say is that, in reality, there would be very few persons or couples, as the mythical one in my question, who would find themselves in that very fortunate position of having $430,000 in monetary assets.

The fact is that a home‐owning married person who is 65 years of age and who elects to retire with $$250,000 in superannuation is not eligible for benefits. However, there are many thousands of other people between 55 and 64 years of age who are much worse off and will be affected seriously by the decision to include superannuation assets in the means test for allowances.

Many of these people, as has been said, are unemployed; some of them are no longer in the work force—out of choice, as indicated by Senator Sherry. Those are people who made their decision years ago, voluntarily having entered into schemes which took money out week by week—money that could well have been spent on other things. Those persons made prudential sacrifices for the benefit of their family—and they are now going to be hit. I might just say that, in my view, we should be encouraging people—

TALK.START.PARA: —To save.
—Yes, to save, Minister. But we should also be encouraging those people who desire to retire early to do so, if we are going to have a look at question of employment.
—On the taxpayer—when they have the means?
—On the taxpayer? You have so many people on full unemployment benefits, and younger people who could take those jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to the point—and I do not think it was to the minister; I do not think it was in her portfolio that I put the questions down—that I have asked certain questions about the effect of the government's decision in respect of a bonus to those who work until the age of 70. In my view the it ought to be the other way around: that is the bonus for people who want to retire but cannot because they cannot afford to. That is one of the reasons that I am inclined to vote for the motion that has been put forward by the Australian Democrats and by the opposition.

Under the circumstances, as I have said, many of the people are unemployed and are looking for work, and many of them have family commitments. That is the other thing about this: it does not take into account the number of dependents that people have. A home owning married person aged between 55 and 64 who loses a job and who has $250,000 in superannuation is not eligible for welfare unless their total assets, excluding a house, are less than $176,000. There is an issue of fairness involved in these two situations, that is, the person aged between 55 and 64 and the person aged 65 and over.

As an example of the unfairness, I submit to the chamber the following examples. A home owner aged 65 years‐plus with $30,000 in possessions and $250,000 in superannuation savings has a fortnightly income of $772. A home owning couple aged between 55 and 64 years of age who have both lost their jobs would be $192 per fortnight worse off. This highlights the unfairness of the way in which allowees between 55 and 64 years are being treated compared with people over 64 years of age. A couple on a mature aged allowance—that is, between the ages of 60 and 65—will get no income support if they have $176,000 in assets, whereas a couple aged 65‐years plus with $160,000 in assets is eligible for part pension.

I think there should be fairness. We should compare the treatment that is now going to be meted out to persons who are between 55 and 64 with what the government is doing to those who are going to stick it out at work until the age of 70. They will get a bonus. Yet those who have planned for many years to retire, who have scrimped and saved for that purpose, who have built up a bank of superannuation, will get absolutely nothing from the government. They are expected to eat into their superannuation savings, when those savings should be used to meet their commitments after they reach the retiring age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions tonight to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1997. The bill is further evidence of this government's continuing commitment to veterans, as several senators have had the grace to acknowledge, through significant support for the rehabilitation of Vietnam and younger veterans and the option for disabled veterans to draw their aged pensions from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The centralised management of care of payments demonstrates this government's commitment to greater administrative efficiencies, and the changes to the treatment of superannuation assets reflects the government's recognition of the need to provide individuals with incentives to enhance their financial and personal independence.

I have some correspondence from the veterans' organisations about this legislation. I urge senators to consider it very closely. I will read some extracts, but I do have the letters with me. The RSL has said:

These two initiatives are of great importance to the veteran community. I would be most grateful if you could press for the passage of these through the parliament. There is an expectation throughout the veteran community for early implementation of these initiatives.
AVADSC said:
This bill has real benefits for the veteran community. I hope that your colleagues will put their support towards securing early passage of the bill.
The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia said:

This delay puzzled me a little as the normally bipartisan attitude towards veterans issues generally guarantees a speedy passage for such legislation. This legislation is important to the veterans and ex-service community, particularly that in relation to the vocational rehabilitation scheme.

I am particularly concerned about the amendments being proposed by both the opposition and the Democrats relating to the over-55s superannuation. Those amendments are unacceptable and will be utterly rejected by the government. The issue of exemptions for inaccessible superannuation is an issue that senators might wish to discuss in the committee stage.

BREAK.PARA: Tonight I wish to have incorporated in Hansard a document which sets out the circumstances under which superannuation will be treated. I would like it to be available to senators so that they can see it in time for the committee stage. I think it makes it quite clear that the treatment of inaccessible superannuation by the government will be treated in a very fair manner. I hope honourable senators have the opportunity to study that closely before they make up their minds about this superannuation issue. I seek leave to incorporate the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't seen it yet.
—I am going to give it to you for your benefit. You could have it after the debate if you want it.
—What I am saying is before we incorporate it.
—I beg your pardon. Would you like to have a look?
—Show it now and incorporate it later.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Can I canvass some of the matters which honourable senators have raised so far in the second reading debate. I really feel sad, Senator Woodley, that you refer to election commitments but you have no hesitation as a party in forcing us to break our election commitments when it comes to special benefit for migrants or the holding of a constitutional convention. I urge you to think very closely about that, and the consistency of your party's treatment of our election commitments as well. I think it is fair to raise that issue now.

BREAK.PARA: Can I remind the Senate that until 1993 superannuation assets were included in the social security test. They always were until 1993. In the budget last year we proposed to close the door when the horse was starting to bolt. The rorts had been developed by financial planners who were advising people to artificially change their investment arrangements so that they were skewed to superannuation. It meant that different types of savings were being treated quite differently by the social security assets test. Surely it is fair to treat all savings the same. I ask the Senate to consider: does the form in which people take their savings really matter? Surely the encouragement of savings, of itself, is of importance.

Why should we sit here and prejudice the savings that people in small business, for example, have had tied up in their businesses until they lose their business, until they close down because of illness or for whatever reason, and have been unable to have superannuation and provide the capital and running funding for their business. Just think about that. There are a lot of people in those circumstances. Perhaps over the years there will be more people who have superannuation—there will be—but at the current time there are a lot of people who do not have much superannuation at all. Their savings are in other forms.

By trying to change back to the other arrangements the Senate is, in fact, prejudicing the savings of people who have not had the tax advantage which is given to those who have superannuation. Senator Woodley and Senator Neal, your amendments will be giving to people who already have tax assistance from the taxpayer for their superannuation, further assistance from the taxpayer by way of special treatment in the social security means test. Surely that is what is not fair.

I also want to point out to Senator Harradine that allowees have always been treated differently under income and assets tests in the social security system from pensioners. We did not change that. That is exactly as it has always been. You are surely not suggesting that we should be paying people pensions at the age of 55? If you are, when you consider the ageing of our population, when you take into account the direction that OECD countries are going in, which is the opposite direction—recognising the heavy cost to taxpayers of supporting large numbers of older people on income support—surely it is better to encourage them, where they can, to remain self‐sufficient. By having income from work, whether it is from small business or even part‐time work, they surely are better able to afford the goods and services which can be provided by younger people. They are not taking younger people's jobs; they are providing jobs for younger people. I think perhaps you were not looking at that as well as you might have.

Senator Sherry raised the question of the so‐called inundation of the Labor Party by people who are concerned about the over‐55s measure. I am advised by my department that the correspondence to the department on this measure has dropped right away since the legislation was passed last December. They keep meticulous records of the correspondence both by way of campaign cards and also by way of letters. In addition, both my departmental officers and I have spent a great deal of time over the last few months—
Senator Neal interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listen. We have spent a great deal of time meeting with organisations that represent older Australians. It is not a major issue for them, I can assure you, because really you are talking about the people who are more affluent in our society. I find it amazing that the Labor Party, the party that one would expect to be really more concerned about the people who have little or nothing, is here being advocates of people who have substantial assets, and you want the taxpayer to support them more than they are supporting themselves. I find that incredible and it surely is against all the equitable principles that you supposedly have stood for. I wonder where the Labor Party is going.

BREAK.PARA: Let me make it absolutely clear that the amendments to the over‐55s super are not acceptable to the government. The result will be that the Senate will have to account to the veterans community for the failure of this bill to pass. This is a bill, as I have already said, that the veterans are urging should be dealt with speedily. These amendments are simply devices hung on the peg of the veterans bill. I believe they are quite disgraceful and will be condemned utterly around the country by veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman sought leave for the incorporation of a document earlier. Is leave granted?

BREAK.PARA: The document read as follows—
SUPERANNUATION ASSETS OF OVER 55 CUSTOMERS—EXEMPTIONS

When this measure was announced on 20 August 1996, the Minister publicly recognised that there would be a need to exempt superannuation assets in certain situations. As the issues involved were complex, the Minister had them comprehensively investigated before determining the details. The Minister can now clarify when exemptions will be provided.
Background—How Exemptions Can Be Provided

Under the income test, the Minister can provide exemptions through making determinations to exempt specified superannuation assets. Under the assets test, exemptions can be provided through the existing asset test hardship rules.
Situations in Which Exemptions Will Be Provided

The Minister will provide exemptions for inaccessible superannuation assets. It would be unfair to assess these superannuation assets, because that could lead to a situation where the customer's income support was reduced because of the measure, but where the customer would not be able to compensate for this by drawing on his or her superannuation asset.
Exemptions will be provided where the asset is inaccessible because of a contract entered into prior to the Budget announcement, or because of the rules of the superannuation fund:
. an example is where the customer purchased a "fixed term rollover" prior to the budget announcement where the contract does not permit access until expiry of the term of the contract.

Exemptions will be provided only until the expiry of the contact period as stated at the date of announcement of the measure. Exemptions will not be provided where these contracts were entered into after the announcement of the measure.
Exemptions will also be provided where the asset is inaccessible because of a legislative bar.

. an example is where the customer is unable to access the asset because he or she does not satisfy any of the "conditions of release" specified in the superannuation regulations for instance because they are working part time.

However, the Government has taken steps to greatly reduce the number of situations in which superannuation is inaccessible, through the streamlining of the conditions of release announced in the 1997-98 Budget. The new rules mean that unemployed customers who are not retired, but who are affected by the assessment of their superannuation, will be able to access their superannuation on grounds of financial hardship (subject to the rules of superannuation fund).

The Minister will also provide exemptions for traditional endowment or life superannuation contracts purchased before the announcement of the measure. These are usually long term capital guaranteed contracts with a substantial insurance component and maturity bonus' payable at maturity of the contract. It would be unreasonable for customers to be forced to terminate these contracts before they mature to make up for a reduction in their income support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
