TALK.START.PARA: — I rise tonight to speak in recognition of the upcoming 40th anniversary of the signing of the Australia-Japan Commerce Agreement. This was commemorated by the 20th Australia-Japan Relations Symposium recently held here in Parliament House, where the future directions of cooperation between our two countries were explored. We also welcomed a delegation of young Japanese political leaders to Canberra at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The commerce agreement, signed on 6 July 1957, was the first major trade agreement signed by Japan with a foreign nation following World War II. This came about largely because of the work of former National Party leader, Sir John McEwen. It is doubtful that this agreement, followed by four decades of a stable Japan‐Australia relationship, would have come about were it not for his persistence and determination.

Before a deal could be made with Japan, Australia needed to come to an agreement with Great Britain over wheat imports and a number of other bilateral and Commonwealth undertakings that were important at that time. In Peter Golding's biography Black Jack McEwen—Political Gladiator, he describes just how difficult it was for McEwen and his department head, John Crawford, to make this trade. Golding later says that a deal was signed after several weeks of hard bargaining.

The subsequent Australia-Japan Commerce Agreement was especially significant for the National Party. Prior to the signing, Sir Robert Menzies gave sole responsibility for trade to two then Country Party ministers. This was a very great step forward for my party at that time.

In 1997, the National Party is still at the forefront of Australia's trade negotiations. National Party leader, Mr Tim Fischer, is both trade minister and Deputy Prime Minister, and at present of course he is Acting Prime Minister. He is held in high regard right across the Asia‐Pacific region, a region in which he has worked so hard to gain credibility during his whole public life.

At a time when our trade is increasingly regulated through the GATT and World Trade Organisation commitments, there are few ways to gain leverage, but exporters are already reaping the benefits of the rapport that the present trade minister has developed over time with our Asian trading partners.
Australia is now getting fresh milk into Hong Kong every day. Our cheese is exported to Korea for the first time. Riverina rice has now gained entry to Japanese markets—and there is more to come.

The Japanese have been our largest trading partners now for nearly 30 years. Last year, our exports to Japan were worth $15.5 billion, one fifth of our total exports. Australia had a trade surplus with Japan of $5.4 billion in the full year of 1995-96.

We supply over half of Japan's coal needs, and prospects for increased energy sales to Japan are increasingly sound. Japan is our principal market for a whole range of raw materials, food and processed goods, including beef, iron ore, seafood and crude petroleum. Japan is among our main markets for wool, sugar and wheat—our great primary production exports.

BREAK.PARA: In 1995‐96, manufactures accounted for 14 per cent of our exports to Japan, and services exports such as tourism and education are growing steadily. In 1996, over 800,000 Japanese visitors came to Australia, generating $3 billion worth of export dollars. Very interestingly, 300,000 Australian jobs depend on our bilateral trade links, and there is a steady two‐way flow of investment and expertise between our two countries. There are now far more Australians learning Japanese than in any other country in the world, except of course Japan.

It is clear that Japan will remain our most important economic partner for the foreseeable future. A new report from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's East Asia Analytical Unit A New Japan? Change in Asia's Megamarket provides an important reminder of Japan's global economic significance.

In 1996, Japan's GDP grew by 3.6 per cent, and its potential growth rate is steady at around 2.5 per cent. This means that Japan is still able to add the equivalent of two-thirds of the Indonesian economy or one-fifth of the Chinese economy to the world's economy every year.

The report emphasises the breadth of opportunities opening up in Japan for Australian firms. But to exploit these opportunities we need a stable foundation. The strength and quality of the relationship between Japan and Australia is that foundation built over a period of 40 years.

It was nowhere more evident than during Prime Minister Hashimoto's May visit. But a comment made at the symposium by Tokyo University Associate Professor Tanaka also struck a chord with me when he described our relationship as `a natural partnership'. I believe that the natural partnership he spoke of is in part because we both value our democratic status, and we share a similar outlook on the world, our place in it, our relationship to the rest of Asia and our vision for the future.

Together we built a relationship ahead of time, because both countries needed a trade relationship earlier than our less developed neighbours. Now, in economic terms, the rest of our region has substantially caught up with us and, in some instances, has surpassed us both. But the importance of our relationship is very strong.

Which brings me to my final point—the security of the region. As the two leading industrialised democracies in the region, we share many security policy objectives, not only in the region but globally. Our approach to China, our relations with the United States and our participation in APEC are all important to both countries. Most recently, our willingness to assist with the maintenance of peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula has also stood us in good stead with our Japanese friends.

Prime Minister Hashimoto's announcement that he would assist our entry to the Asia side of the Asia-Europe Meeting—ASEM—is proof positive of Japan's continued willingness to nurture the relationship that was established on a formal basis in 1957. I hope that the foresight and spirit of cooperation that marked our earlier relations with Japan continue to feature strongly in our modern dealings—40 years on this year from those very important beginnings back in July of 1957.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record a few remarks about the very uncertain future a small group of workers is being faced with, and I also want to mention two other individual workers and their uncertain future.

SPEECH.PARA: At the estimates committee meeting of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee some two or three weeks ago—Wednesday, 11 June—I addressed some questions to the officers of the Attorney-General's Department regarding the future of Auscript and, more importantly, the future of the people who currently work for Auscript. I asked whether a review had been conducted as to whether or not it was in the public interest that Auscript be sold. Of course, we have not been given—like so many things with this current government—the information on that. The response from the officer was that it may be confidential but that he would look into it.
I asked about the content of the report and was told by the secretary of the department, Mr Skehill:

There was a report which identified a range of options—one of which was retention in public ownership, one of which was privatisation and there were some subvariants on that. It costed each of those options. It concluded that the cheapest option in terms of net present value was retention, but it also noted that that was a strategy with some risk. It would only be the cheapest option if a whole range of initiatives could be successfully taken and sustained and if the client base was retained as well.
I asked why the option was not accepted by the government from a person who was then asked to do the review. I was told by Mr Skehill:

You may be aware that the government has consistently, with the National Commission of Audit and a number of other initiatives, established what is known as a series of privatisation decision principles or a decision tree. This provides a structured basis on which consideration is given to whether commercial undertakings of the government are retained in public ownership. The government's view was that there was no overriding or compelling reason in the public interest why Auscript should remain in public ownership. In accordance with the established government policy, it decided to offer Auscript for sale.

One wonders why they conducted a review in the first place. As I said, we have asked for a copy of the final report—there may be commercial-in-confidence matters pertaining to it—but we have not received it.

The people who work at Auscript were described to include many dedicated and talented people. We are talking about 300 people in all. Some 90 of them are permanent full-time employees, and some 200 or 210 are casual employees. For the 90 permanent full-time employees, an amount of $4,273,000 has been allocated in the budget for possible redundancy payments. For the 200 or 210 casual employees, there is no allocation. There is no entitlement to any form of redundancy payments whatsoever. I asked a few questions about the nature of the people who work with Auscript and was told by Mr Reaburn, the deputy secretary of the department, that a number of those casual workers at Auscript had worked there for over 20 years. They walk away with nothing.

The matter was of concern to me during the estimates committee hearing, but it was brought home to me with a real shudder today when I received a letter from a constituent, incidentally, in Perth. I do not have the permission of the individual to use their name, and it probably would not be appropriate that I do, but it is appropriate that I read into the record some extracts from this letter. I quote part of it:

The majority of court recording officers are female. The position, although specialised, does not allow for career opportunities, further training or promotion. Scope for re-employment is limited, especially with the recent massive reductions in court hearings in all judicial areas, because of increased costs, beginning on January 1 this year, and increasing again on July 1.

Clearly, most of us work out of financial necessity. Our circumstances of employment have a much valued flexibility of choices of days which enables us to organise our private responsibilities, especially regarding family matters, and still maintain a degree of much needed income.

It is the classification of "casual" for which we are being punished. The flexibility comes at a high cost to us as employees; we are not truly casual, in the commercial sense of the word. Our employer, the Federal Attorney-General's Department expects us to:
(a) be available for a minimum of 3 days per week, for 7 hours each of those days notified one week in advance;
(b) be available to continue working in a court hearing, without notice, if the court decides to continue the hearing beyond normal working hours, often until late at night;

(c) not expect a guarantee of work on the minimum 3 days we must set aside, so that when we phone in, as we must, the day prior to working we can be told: Sorry, no work tomorrow; or we can be told to come to work, but sent home after 3 hours, if there is not enough work;
(d) maintain the 3 days availability at all times, even during the downturn in demand;
(e) give a month's notice of holidays, and after being off the roster for 1 month, Auscript reserves the right to re‐consider our "suitability" for placement back on the roster;
(f) wait for 10 days before payment for each fortnight's work, even though we are dismissed at the end of each day's employment.

These conditions preclude the possibility of effectively taking on another part time or casual position, so we have a choice of "liking it or lumping it". The limited availability of flexibility in the workforce for women, especially in Perth means that we have maintained our employment with Auscript at times to our detriment, especially over the last 12 months where we have had only one day, if we are lucky, per week employment.

Now that Auscript is being sold, `casual' staff, who represent the major part of the workforce in Auscript, especially in the production area, will not be entitled to any redundancy package or benefits, apart from long service leave for those who have worked 10 years or more.

If we had not remained with the Government but sought employment in the private sphere, such conditions would not apply. Long service leave is available after 7 years, and redundancy packages are available to true casual staff, such as was the case for Coles Fossey recently in Perth.

I am given to understand that the union that represents a large number of the workers with Auscript are seeking negotiations with the Attorney‐General's Department to try to get some justice for this relatively large group of workers. Certainly, they are, in the words of Mr Reaburn, `dedicated and talented people'—people who have been relied on to provide a valuable service in the past. I wish those negotiations well. I wish there was something more positive that I could do to assist their cause. I hope that, in the end, they will get justice.

The other two individuals whom I want to refer to tonight—and they have not been told that I am going to refer to them, so they will probably be embarrassed if they are watching—are two individuals who provide an invaluable service to every senator in this place. I refer to the officers who are currently employed in the Senate Transport Office.

I do not know what their future is and I am not sure that they, in turn, know what their future is. I know the government have made mention that they have made some decisions about the future of the Transport Office. But again, as I said earlier, as with so many of the decisions of this government, they have not been notified. We, as senators, have not been notified in a formal sense of what is going to happen. The minister appeared on a television program one Sunday some weeks ago and laid out what is going to happen, but I have seen no paperwork to show what is going to happen.

We have two very dedicated individuals, one of whom has been with the Senate for 13 years, Kearen Finn, who has a very uncertain future. I do not believe that is good enough. In mentioning Kearen first, that is not to in any way denigrate the value and the use of Bruce Greentree, who is also employed in that office.

I think it is very callous of the government to treat Mr Greentree and Ms Finn in this way. I hope that their situation can be resolved at an early time. I understand from the minister's decision that the Senate Transport Office is going to close, that we will not, when we return here in August, be seeing the smiling, happy faces of Bruce and Kearen. I take the opportunity in a personal sense to wish them all the very best for the future. I am sure I am doing that on behalf of not only all my Labor colleagues but every senator in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight not long after the elections in Indonesia are over. I am speaking about the human rights situation in East Timor, and the Indonesian military crackdown in Baucau. The Australian government should urgently protest to the Indonesian government and report the following alleged human rights violations to United Nations fora: firstly, the capture of Falantil leader David Alex and three other Falantil members on Wednesday, 25 June at 9 a.m. at Otabubu Kaibada Uaimua Baucau and the alleged killing of David Alex on 26 June 1997; secondly, the alleged capture and rape of two young Timorese girls inside an Indonesian military post at Baucau in the evening of Wednesday, 25 June 1997; and, thirdly, the alleged capture of 60 young Timorese in Baucau in the evening of Wednesday, 25 June 1997 and the subsequent murder of two youths by the Indonesian army.

SPEECH.PARA: These are just the latest in a range of abuses that encompasses the deteriorating human rights situation in East Timor since Indonesia's national elections and since the award of the Nobel Peace Prize.

The news today that David Alex has been killed has come from varying reports. Our own government intelligence, which seems to coincide with the Indonesian government line, is that he was wounded in an armed skirmish and that he died in capture. However, there have been other reports of death by extrajudicial killing.
If the government is relying on such sources, they should not rely solely on information from the Indonesian government.

We must re‐send Ambassador John McCarthy to East Timor—where his visit may have coincided, ironically, with this violence—to monitor the human rights situation and find out how David Alex was killed and the reasons for his death. We need to know whether he suffered torture before his death and whether he died in a helicopter, in custody or during questioning, as conflicting reports have indicated.

David Alex was the hub of the resistance and the primary strategist behind the East Timorese armed resistance. It is a blow to the East Timorese movement that the Indonesian government have stepped up their military tactics. The violence of the Indonesian military, which is all‐pervasive in East Timor, is not just confined to the armed resistance, but to civilians as well. There are unconfirmed reports of further rape and capture of East Timorese youths in Bacau, where the military are taking revenge for the killing of Indonesian soldiers some weeks ago.

There should be an inquiry into the death of David Alex and the recent Indonesian crackdown and human rights violations in Bacau. This inquiry should be full and independent. There is no point calling for a report into David Alex's death that relies only on the Indonesian government's story and is a narrower examination of the rapidly deteriorating human rights situation in East Timor at present.
I would like to quote some parts of a press release we received this evening from the East Timor International Support Centre. It reads:

BREAK.PARA: We are deeply concerned over the safety of five East Timorese arrested together with the Baucau commander of the East Timor armed Resistance, David Alex. Indonesian authorities refuse to disclose their whereabouts and our sources indicate they might be detained in the Rumah Merah Indonesian military torture installation in Baucau. At the present moment, there is a very heavy presence of troops in Baucau, 130 km from the capital Dili.
There is a very strong likelihood that the five are currently being tortured. The use of torture is a common practice of Abri—
that is the Indonesian armed forces—
. . . the pictures posted on the InterNet—
I have the address if people are interested—
are clear evidence of the brutalities committed against the East Timorese people by Abri. We are also deeply disturbed that there are 46 East Timorese currently being detained by police.
My final quote from the press release states:
Nobel Peace laureate also urged Western nations to stop selling arms to the Indonesian forces, to end the war in East Timor.
It continues:

"Since 1975 Indonesia has been fighting a dirty war against the East Timorese military Resistance, and has simultaneously been exercising its troops in the use of arms against East Timorese civilians", said Ramos‐Horta.
Indonesia buys weapons from the West with East Timor in mind, and the arms suppliers know very well that they would also be used against East Timorese as well as in Indonesia.

"Once again", said Ramos‐Horta, "the increased level of conflict in East Timor proves that no amount of force used will ever suffice to crush the spirit of the East Timor people." "Once again, after 22 years of the senseless and brutal war against the East Timorese, the Indonesians should realise that only through dialogue under the UN auspices can there be a resolution of this conflict," added Nobel Peace laureate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to stress the need for the government to put into place a system to protect unit trust investors. When unit trusts fail, immediately there is a fight to escape responsibility and all parties rush for their lawyers and the courts. In the end, it is these latter group that reap in the money from the unit trust failures. These problems in the superannuation industry were solved with your assistance and your participation, Madam Deputy President, many years ago and we now have a sound system of prudential regulation under the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: With the release of the report of the Wallis financial system inquiry, the FSI, into the financial system, there has been a new found interest in the checks and balances that are needed to deliver optimum levels of investor protection. During the next few months the government will be examining its position with a view to arriving at a policy which hopefully will deliver appropriate prudential controls. The regulation of the funds management industry is a key component of our national savings, which needs the attention of government if it is to create a safe and certain environment to grow our stocks of national savings. Regrettably in the past there have been some significant losses in the collective investment area—notably with the Australia‐wide Group. In fixing our savings problem we need to do so on a broad front.

Compulsory superannuation and the recently announced budget measures that will provide a universal rebate of up to $450 per year are but two measures to boost savings. Cutbacks in public expenditure to ensure a move towards balanced budgets in two year's time and budgets in surplus are also part of the national savings agenda. Investor confidence and efficiency in our fund raising industry are two measures which are integral to turning around our savings industry. In Australia we now find that one in three Australians own shares. The Australian Stock Exchange is number 10 in the world in market size and its efficiency rates are second only to that of the United States.

Investor confidence is to a large extent driven by the scope and extent of government regulation in the capital markets. In any move to tighten regulations to protect investors, it is important that investors not be given the impression that, regardless of the degree of prudence and honesty exercised by those with whom they have entrusted their money, they will not face the prospect of losing part or all of their capital fund. This was the matter that Wallis looked at in examining whether or not there was an implied guarantee attached to bank products—and the jury is still out on that one.

Wallis concluded that disclosure should be the starting point for all deposits and investment products. If a product has a high degree of prudential protection, then the level of disclosure should be commensurately low. On the other hand, if the product has a low level of protection and regulation then the disclosure level should be high. While this is fine in theory, it does need some qualification and Wallis and his team were prepared to do this. Wallis concluded that compulsory superannuation contributions should have the protection of the type provided by the ISC and that this function should come under the aegis of the new prudential regulator who would also have control of bank deposits. It also recommended that there be an anti-fraud recovery device and went so far as to give a formula for its particular operation.

In the non‐super domain Wallis concluded that a collective investment review should be implemented, thereby bringing superannuation and non‐superannuation savings under similar systems of prudential control and supervision. However, in the non‐superannuation area certain points of distinction should actually be drawn. Here the deposits of voluntary disclosure levels are high and in accordance with the Corporations Law investors are actually advised that their capital sum may be at risk.

With the advent of the savings rebate and with the benefit of hindsight of fund failures, such as the Excelsior superannuation plan, Estate Mortgage and the recently settled Australia‐wide debacle, all of which are know to you, Madam Deputy President, it is time for the government to deliver an enhanced regulatory arrangement to better protect the non‐super investment products. But if we were to survey the many retirees who lost their savings in the Burns Philip‐Estate Mortgage disaster or if one were to speak to the 23,000 or so mums and dads who lost a total of $145 million following the mismanagement of the Australia‐wide fund, and then spend five years chasing the manager and the trustee company only to made $100 million, I am sure that these people would say that politicians do have a responsibility to do something to protect their interests.

Similarly, if one were to speak to those Victorian state and federal politicians who had to prepare a government response to the late 1980s financial meltdown in that state, they would no doubt say that prevention would have been far better than cure. I add here that it was only because of the intervention of the ASC that the Australia‐wide investors actually made any headway at all. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard an article from the Australian Financial Review dated 3 June 1997.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The article read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TRUSTS OUTCOME COLD COMFORT

The $100 million settlement last week of the Aust‐Wide Trusts court case was a victory, of sorts, for the thousands of unfortunate mum and dad investors who sank $145 million into trusts managed by Ron Kerr and Henry Townsing's Aust‐Wide Group.
And a victory for ASC chairman Alan Cameron, who has been keen to assert his credentials as a defender of the small investor's rights.

But the settlement is still cold comfort for investors as a group because it highlights the abject and utter failure of successive Australian governments to put in place a simple and effective mechanism to protect the interests of unit trust investors.

After a never‐ending series of studies, reports and inquiries into possible reform of the unit trust industry, the regulatory and legal framework that allowed the Aust‐Wide debacle to take place still remains largely intact today.

Way back in 1992, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee's Collective Investment Review panel, headed by investment banker Mark Burrows, came up with a set of recommendations on how to make unit trust and other "collective investment" type schemes safer and more transparent for small investors.

The CIR report was enthusiastically supported by the then Labor Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch. However, the recommendations of the CIR report never made it into legislation, largely thanks to a long campaign by the trustee company industry against its implementation.

The CIR report identified that one of the main structural problems with the regulation and supervision of the unit trust industry was the problem of dual responsibility—with the task of investing the funds and safeguarding the investments split between a manager and a trustee.

The CIR identified that when unit trust investments went bad, investors in the trusts had difficulty recovering their losses because of the fuzzy issue of who they had to sue—the fund manager or the trustee.
Invariably in such cases the management company had little capital or had gone broke, so there was little sense in investors suing a bankrupt company.

However, when they tried to recover their losses from the trustee, the self‐professed guardian of investors savings, the trustee invariably argued that the losses had been caused entirely by the fund manager.
In other words, investors went round and round in circles chasing the passing buck.

The CIR group's answer to the agony of small investors was to create the concept of a "single responsible entity"(SRE), in other words a place where the buck stopped when investors had lost their dough.

The SRE could either be the fund manager or the trustee, but it could not be both. As a further protection for investors, the CIR group recommended that fund managers have minimum levels of shareholder capital (suggested minimum of $10 million), back‐up insurance, and be subject to rigorous licensing and scrutiny by the Australian Securities Commission.

As a further level of protection, the directors of any SME would be jointly and severally liable to make up any losses suffered by investors. In short, if unit trust investors lost money and the fund manager was at fault, the directors of the fund manager all lost their houses.

Five years later the recommendations of the CIR report are gathering dust in a cupboard somewhere in Canberra. The Wallis committee dusted off the report for a quick read and recommended the adoption of the "single responsible entity" approach to unit trust management and investor protection.

So now the problem of how to protect investors in unit trusts rests with the Treasurer, Peter Costello, whose department is looking at introducing a new regulatory framework on collective investments in the near future.
But don't bet on it. The Trustee Company industry earns around $100 million a year in fees as the "investor watchdog" on unit trusts, an annual stipend the industry is loath to give up.
The trustee companies know too well that, if the SME concept is adopted, most of the major fund managers in Australia will stop using trustees for public unit trusts.
In essence trustees would be left monitoring all of the unit trusts managed by small, high‐risk fund managers, without any of the big juicy trusts where there is absolutely no risk at all.
The Trustee Company Association, which represents the industry's 17 major players, has defeated all previous attempts to change the regulatory regime for unit trusts.

The TCA is a dab hand at twisting arms in Canberra and no doubt before long Peter Costello will be besieged with phone calls from backbenchers, worried that he's about to throw the mum and dad investors of Australia to the wolves.
How Costello handles the issue of unit trust regulation will clearly provide a signpost on how effective he is in handling well‐organised interest groups.

Unsurprisingly, in a circuitous piece of logic, the Trustee Company Association managed to turn the potential embarrassment of the Aust‐Wide settlement into an argument against the adoption of the SME concept.

In the Aust‐Wide case, the Australian Securities Commission took court action against Permanent Trustees, the trustee of Aust‐Wide trusts, on behalf of the 26,000 investors who had lost all or most of their capital.

The ASC argued that Permanent Trustee had failed to discharge its duty under the trust deed, and in common law, to protect the investors in the trusts. Without making an admission, Permanent contributed $26.6 million to the $100 million pool of funds that will be used to repay the Aust‐Wide investors.

After the settlement, the TCA issued a statement arguing that the settlement showed the benefits of the dual responsibility system. TCA national director Don Blyth said: "When funds fail, it is the trustee that remains solvent while the fund manager is insolvent and not worth suing."

Perhaps. But what Blyth might also have pointed out was that if Permanent Trustee had been doing what the trustee company industry claims to be doing for investors, the Aust‐Wide investors would not have lost $145 million in the first place.
And while $100 million for the Aust‐Wide investors is a good result in the circumstances, the 26,000 mums and dads are still massive losers overall.
There were two trusts involved in last Friday's settlement, the Aust‐Wide Trust and the Flexi Property Fund, funds from which had been channelled into other Aust‐Wide Trusts.

Of the $59 million invested by Aust‐Wide, investors will get back roughly $33 million. Of the $86 million invested by Flexi, some $64 million will come back. In round numbers they've recovered 57 per cent and 74 per cent respectively of their starting point investment.

In other words, the investors in Aust‐Wide and Flexi lost 43 per cent and 26 per cent of their original capital (and more if inflation is taken into account) and received no income for approximately eight years.

As most of the Aust‐Wide investors were retired, or approaching retirement, the ultimate bill for the Aust‐Wide mess will end up with the Government, which will end up paying higher pensions than otherwise would have been the case.
Perhaps Costello can send the bill to Permanent Trustees.
Ivor Ries

The Senate superannuation committee, during its inquiry leading up to the passage of the SIS bills, devoted a considerable part of its time to developing the right regulatory regime to protect investors in superannuation. The final committee report supported the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission report commissioned in the wake of the Estate Mortgage crash. Essentially, SIS followed a single responsibility path—that is, combined the roles of the trustee and the fund manager and set out in legislation their fiduciary obligations to members: to ensure that there are proper compliance plans and procedures; that opportunities for fraudulent behaviour are minimised; that the investment strategy is in accordance with the trustee; and that any promises made by the beneficiaries to the fund are in fact honoured.

On top of this, one must have a strong prudential regulator who can swoop on a fund as soon as there is a hint of non-compliance with the capacity to use the full weight of the law to punish dishonesty and negligence. Managing other people's money is a serious business with serious consequences if the job is done less than honestly or less than prudently.

We on the superannuation committee took an `at source' or ex ante approach to the regulation of a unit trust. It can only be that the responsibility of ensuring that a member's funds are protected should rest with a single party, not with two or three which can lead to confusion and commercial uncertainty and also the buck passing that I referred to earlier. This was the reasoning behind the ALRC report and became the basis for the SIS recommendations.

How would it be, to use an analogy, if the shareholders in BHP had their moneys con trolled by two boards of management? Who would they blame when something went wrong? Which board would have responsibility for what functions and how could their collective performance be gauged? This is the type of uncertainty that reigns in our non‐superannuation managed investments currently. It is time that action be taken to rectify this obvious problem.

Currently, 1.5 million Australians have about $100 billion investments in this segment of the financial sector—a huge sum, about two‐thirds of the total market. Funds under management are growing strongly at about 14 per cent annually. This is clearly an area which needs both the government's policy-making skills and the finance industry's cooperation. I am confident that a regime can be found which will bolster investor security in this critical area of national savings. The sooner this can be done the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Australian Democrats spokesperson for regional development, I rise to speak on the matter of the Northern Territory Planning Authority and the apparent problems with land sale and development in the Northern Territory. I have been approached by a number of Territory residents who are frustrated with this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The current Northern Territory parliamentary system has been in place since 1974. It is questionable whether this is a fully accountable parliamentary system when the one party has reigned supreme for so long under a single member electoral system without an upper house system of review.

The government, the only party to have been in power for the 23‐year life of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, openly flaunts the fact that Territory Labor does not have a chance of winning at the polls and, what is just as telling, Labor openly concedes this point. Ineffective opposition is fatal to effective accountability. This situation has apparently led to a few arrogant and tired government members running to their own agenda and riding roughshod over people in the Territory.

The government, in particular the Department of Lands, Planning and Environment, has been criticised for making its own rules and not being accountable to anyone. I am told that people appearing before the Northern Territory Planning Authority Commission can be told the committee is the wrong forum to raise their grievances or concerns, yet no other forum is available. It appears the only other avenue is directly to the Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment. Here, I am told, their letters may be acknowledged but not actioned, their appeals may be disregarded and their cries for a more equitable system fall on deaf ears.

I am told of considerable disquiet by the people of the Northern Territory and an increasing distrust of the Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment. Some Northern Territory residents find it difficult to work effectively with the current regime. The Darwin Lord Mayor, Mr George Brown, this month announced he would resign over the Northern Territory's contempt for residents' wishes. It was reported he told the Parap Resident's Association meeting that he had had enough of government interference in planning matters.

I am advised that the determination of the Northern Territory Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment on public land sales is neither public nor open and is carried out at the expense of the environment and the concerns of residents. Open government means making the process of planning and approval transparent and open to scrutiny, but the Northern Territory scenario is apparently neither of these. I am advised that the minister meets directly with developers and holds private consultations with key development groups prior to the direct sale of crown land. I will explain further problems being experienced with the direct sale of land a little later.

I am told the government recently bought back a property and house which was built on a known flood plain. We must ask: why did the government approve building on land which has a 50 per cent chance of flooding every year and was never supposed to be developed? Why has taxpayers' money been used to buy back this property when the developer walks away with his money? Will the government recover this money from the developer? Will the government now go ahead and buy back other properties built on zone 2 flood land? The precedent has, after all, been set.

It is reported that the Northern Territory government has offered unacceptably low compensation to landowners in its drive to resume land for the Alice Springs to Darwin rail corridor. Even given the natural desire to maximise self‐interest in these matters, such claims do need care. Fairness always has to prevail when compulsory acquisition is being actioned. Are the government's valuations for land based on current market values and a fair return? Why then have some offers been so low in the first instance and substantially increased at a later date?

In rezoning matters, the Northern Territory government apparently repeatedly goes against its own Darwin town plan guidelines. Why does the government support and approve changes to formally agreed land zonings? Will it place on public record its reasons for approving rezoning applications?

As I mentioned earlier, another area of contention between the people of the Northern Territory and its monopolistic government is the disposal of crown land by direct sale method. I am told that the Northern Territory Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment works on a `closed door' basis with no transparent scrutiny resulting over the direct sale of crown land. The public are often unaware of such sales and left in the dark when the public notice fails to mention that crown land has been part of a consolidation application. Often the annual report for the Northern Territory Department of Lands, Planning and Environment is the first report to mention the actual number of direct land sales.

The 1995-96 report indicates that 33 direct sales were completed in the year, but as the direct sale of crown land is not a publicly visible process in the Northern Territory it begs to be questioned. Was this the total number of sales and why was the land not able to be sold by auction or by public tender? There have been allegations that the government has, through direct sales process, made exchange deals directly with developers.

It is alleged that there has even been land subdivision and consolidation applications which combine private land with vacant crown land, signed by a government employee. Is it correct and appropriate for government employees to sign and submit such applications? Does this not possibly represent a serious conflict of interest between the department representing the crown estate on the one hand and the eventual beneficiary of the vacant crown land on the other?

It would appear that a culture is developing in the Northern Territory where development submissions are frequently seeking variations to the zoning and building guidelines. Developers set about selling their ideas and plans before gaining zoning and building approval. Variations are now apparently seen as the rule rather than the exception. Examples of this include the historic walkway to the Port of Darwin. Despite public opposition, a walkway from the Darwin plateau down the escarpment is being destroyed by development currently under construction. It is legal opinion that this walkway is a public highway at common law and should never have been interfered with by such a development. I am told that residents' objections have never been acknowledged by the Northern Territory Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment, and the work has simply proceeded unimpeded.

Other contentious decisions include the development of the foreshore escarpment area overlooking Stokes Hill Wharf and Precinct. This picturesque gateway to Darwin City is under threat of development into private dwellings. I understand the most suitable use would be public open space accessible for all. Any development along the escarpment other than parklands is not in keeping with the vision for this area as expressed by the former Northern Territory government in the Future direction for Darwin document of 1990.

The vision, which sets out an appropriate environment for the growth of Darwin, pro posed to establish a metropolitan parkland system with direct orientation to the sea. It clearly states that `the challenge is to ensure that the city's character, natural beauty and environment are not destroyed by haphazard or unthinking development.' In August 1990, the Chief Minister, Marshall Perron, said:

Both Darwin and the tourist industry are set to continue their phenomenal growth, and we must ensure that we do it right. That means making our city even more attractive to tourists and residents, planning ahead to maintain our lifestyle and Darwin's uncrowded appeal, and capitalising on our unique physical, historical and cultural assets.

From reports, it appears that the Northern Territory ministry for lands, planning and development has lost or is losing its way. It must not become entrapped by developers intent on developing at any cost, regardless of the concerns of residents or those who have the long-term interests of Darwin and the Northern Territory at heart.
I was heartened to learn this week that one residents' group had been successful in their call for a halt to a controversial multi‐storey development in Darwin.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 22 July 1996.

QUESTION.PARA: In reference to the letter written to the Minister on 7 June 1996 by the Member for Lowe in which the member expresses grave concern at the effects of cuts to skillshare in his electorate:

(1) Does the Minister concur with the statement made by the Member for Lowe that Skillshare is a `highly positive cost‐effective service . . . a highly successful program' and the clear evidence he presents in his letter that Skillshare `rather than being a government expense is a government saving'.
(2) Will the Minister agree to the request made by the Member for Lowe, and other members and senators, to restore Skillshare's funding.
(3) Will a guarantee be given of the long‐term security of the Skillshare program in a viable form.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I acknowledge that many Skillshare projects provide an effective service to job seekers in terms of skills training, job search training and employment placement assistance. But no labour market program saves the Government money.

The Access Economics report entitled Net Budget Impact of SkillShare, released by the National Skillshare Association in July 1996, concluded that SkillShare created a net average gain to the Commonwealth Budget of around $500 per participant.

However, I believe that a number of the assumptions used by Access Economics were not correct. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has released a paper which revised Access Economics calculations, correcting for assumptions where my Department's information is more accurate. These revised estimates show that SkillShare does not provide a net saving to the Budget but rather costs about $840 per participant. My Department's analysis also shows that all programs have a net cost to the Budget.
If the Senator wishes, my Department would be glad to provide him with a copy of its assessment of the Access Economics report.

(2) Funding for the SkillShare program has been reduced by one‐third in 1996‐97. This is part of the overall savings to labour market programs in 1996‐97. I appointed an independent body, the SkillShare Services Review Committee to review the national SkillShare network and consider submissions from existing SkillShare sponsors for funding from 1 October 1996 to 30 June 1997. As a result, over 380 SkillShares projects continue to provide training and assistance for jobseekers across Australia in 1996‐97.

(3) In the 1996‐97 Budget, the Government announced major changes to the way in which employment services are delivered to job seekers. The new arrangements were expected to come into effect in December 1997. Subject to the passage of legislation, it is now anticipated that the new employment services market will come into effect in March 1998. My Department will no longer contract LMP providers such as SkillShares to provide training courses and work experience for unemployed people. Instead organisations will be contracted to provide individually tailored packages of intensive employment assistance for eligible job seekers, along with labour exchange services and job search assistance. Effective Skillshare projects are ideally placed to be contracted as employment placement enterprises under these new arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What advice can the Minister provide on the plagiarism policies of the University of Queensland.
(2) Is it a requirement of higher education institutions that students work independently on work submitted (other than duly acknowledged joint work).
(3) What penalties are imposed on a student who fails to correctly acknowledge sources used in the preparation of work submitted for the conferral of a degree.
(4) What penalties are imposed on a student who submits the work of others purporting that the work is his or her own.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The University of Queensland does not have a formal University‐wide policy on plagiarism. However the University Statute No.13 concerning student misconduct includes cheating and intentional plagiarism as examples of misconduct. Handbooks issued by the University's academic departments for the guidance of students doing courses offered by each department contain information on and definitions of plagiarism. The University expects and encourages students to act with integrity, ethically, and with mutual respect for fellow members of the University community.

(2), (3) & (4) It is difficult to generalise but it is a conventional practice that students of higher education institutions work independently on work submitted other than duly acknowledged joint work. Cases of collusion are treated in the same way as plagiarism irrespective of the circumstances and/or motivation involved, and all parties are penalised. The range of penalties imposed on a student who fails to correctly acknowledge sources used in the preparation of work submitted for the conferral of a degree, or who submits the work of others purporting that the work is his or her own, includes loss of credit, suspension of attendance, and expulsion from the institution.

ANSWER.PARA: Funding provided by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is not allocated or reported on the basis of electoral boundaries. The information provided below has therefore been compiled on the basis of data available at the postcode or regional level.

However, for the six major programmes listed under `Labour Market Programmes' (LMP's), data has been compiled by attributing LMP activity to specific postcodes relating to each electorate. Postcodes of the job seeker or provider which is attached to each payment are used to determine the location of the LMP activity. An LMP provider may have a business address postcode within, for example, Kalgoorlie, but may in fact be running projects outside the electorate. Conversely there may be providers conducting LMP projects within Kalgoorlie who have postcodes outside Kalgoorlie.

Information on LMP activity has been grouped to reflect the changes in the programme structure which were introduced on 7 October 1996 in line with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Employment Service Advisory Committee (CESAC). The changes were designed to streamline programme administration, make programmes more flexible, provide a greater client focus and simplify the programme structure.

There are also some types of LMP payments which simply cannot be categorised by postcode and therefore cannot be included in an LMP activity summary for the required electorates. These are Formal Training Allowance payments, Apprenticeship Incentive payments and New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) Allowance payments. With regard to 1996‐97, the information relates to expenditure for the year to 6 June 1997, with three weeks remaining in the financial year, for further payments to be made.

For all other programmes listed, data have been obtained from the Department's Area Offices and National Programme Managers on expenditure in regions covering and crossing the electorates requested. For some programmes, the actual expenditure is recorded against the physical location of the Area Office although clients are assisted across a broad spectrum of regions. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 April 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, as stated on page 91 of the Report Summary on the Long‐Term Operating Plan for Sydney Airport and Associated Airspace, that `All proposals for change in terminal area and air route arrangements in Australia are subject to environmental assessment in accordance with Airservices Australia's statutory obligations. These relate principally to two pieces of legislation, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the Act) and the Air Services Act 1995'.

(2) Does the so‐called `environmental evaluation' discussed in the report at page 91 satisfy the Act requirements that all primary and secondary impacts, long‐term and short‐term, must be examined and taken into account.

(3) Is it a fact that this so‐called `environmental evaluation'; (a) does little more than provide a comparison of the numbers of people who, at 1995 air traffic levels, would experience noise greater than 70 dB(A) under different operating modes; (b) falls far short of an assessment of the long‐term noise impacts; and (c) does not even pretend to address other environmental impacts such as air pollution and crash risk.

(4) (a) Is the Minister aware of the arguments for exempting earlier share‐the‐noise initiatives (reopening the east‐west runway, allowing northerly take‐offs from the third runway and abolishing the flight corridors) from the environmental assessment requirements of the Act, briefly: that there was an urgent need to share the aircraft noise because the Labor Government's concentration of overflights was causing some communities in Sydney to suffer grievous hardship and the need for immediate relief for those communities outweighed the public interest in having an environmental impact statement (EIS); (b) do these arguments apply in the case of the long‐term operating plan; and (c) are such arguments not valid for the long‐term operating plan because a redistribution of the noise has now partially taken place, for example the urgency has diminished.
(5) (a) Will an EIS be undertaken into the long‐term operating plan; if not, why not; and (b) what alternatives will be employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2), (3), (4) and (5) The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has designated the Department of Transport and Regional Development as the proponent under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the Act) in relation to the implementation of the Long‐Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and Associated Airspace.

The Department of Transport and Regional Development has provided the Department of Environment with a report detailing the proposals as required under the Act. It is a matter for the Minister for the Environment to determine the level of environmental assessment that is required in relation to the proposals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How many Environmental Defenders Offices (EDOs) are there in Australia;? and (b) where are they located.

(2) (a) What is the level of funding for each office provided by the Commonwealth; (b) what, if any, are the other funding sources of EDOs; and (c) will the Government commit itself to maintaining current funding levels to EDOs; if not. how much funding will be provided to deliver the advice, education and policy services that EDOs provide to the Government and the community.
(3) Does the Government consider itself bound by Commonwealth environment laws; if so, is the Government prepared to have its decisions reviewed.

(4) (a) Which bodies, if any, are responsible for conducting the same or similar work as the EDOs; (b) how are they funded; and (c) does the Commonwealth intend to maintain specialist environmental advocacy services; if so, how and what funding will be allocated to those services outside of that currently allocated to EDOs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Nine.
(b) EDOs are located in:
. Melbourne;
. Sydney;
. Brisbane;
. Hobart;
. Darwin;
. Cairns;
. Perth;
. Canberra; and
. Adelaide.
(2) (a) Funding for Environmental Lawyers 1996-97

(b) EDOs may receive one-off or recurrent funding from a range of other sources, including state governments, private bodies and environmental organisations. A detailed breakdown of these alternative funding arrangements is not provided to the Commonwealth.
(c) Current funding levels have been maintained in the 1997/98 Budget.
(3) Yes. There is a variety of administrative and judicial monitoring and review mechanisms in place relating to Commonwealth decisions on environmental matters.

(4) (a) A wide range of private and public bodies and organisations are involved in monitoring, campaigning and advising on environmental legal issues in a manner comparable to the functions undertaken by EDOs. Various environmental groups are active at the local, regional and national level.
(b) Funding depends on the nature of the organisation, whether public or private, its history, constituents and public support.

(c) Yes. The Government will purchase $0.6m of environmental legal services in the 1997/98 financial year focussing on the areas of community legal education, the provision of information about legal rights and responsibilities relating to the environment, and legal advisory services for people dealing with environmental matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to allegations of an incident at Canungra Land Warfare Centre in which Australian soldiers recently refused to train Indonesian soldiers, but changed their minds when threatened with disciplinary action:

BREAK.PARA: (1) (a) Did this incident take place; (b) was a directive issued to threaten Australian soldiers with disciplinary action if they did not train Indonesian soldiers; and (c) what was the extent of that disciplinary action.

(2) Can information be provided as to whether any other forms of conscientious objection have taken place to the training of either Indonesian or Papua New Guinean soldiers in any defence or training establishment in Australia; if so, please detail the incidents.

(3) (a) What is the Government's position on personnel who have a conscientious objection to training Indonesian or Papua New Guinean personnel; and (b) does the Government accept conscientious objection to particular activities while remaining a member of the forces; if so, please explain the alternative activities that are given to the conscientious objector in that instance; if not, how is that conscientious objector dealt with.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) No.
(c) Not applicable.
(2) No incidents of this nature involving Indonesian or Papua New Guinean soldiers have taken place.

(3) (a) and (b) Provisions pertaining to "conscientious objection" within the Defence Act 1903 (Cth) are not applicable to volunteers currently serving with the Australian Defence Force. If a member of the Australian Defence Force is given a lawful order, and refuses to obey that lawful order, then the member may be liable to prosecution under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 (Cth) for disobedience of a command.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government propose to sell Auscript, the court reporting and transcription service.
(2) Did the review of the service recommend corporatisation and not privatisation.
(3) Has the Government conducted a cost benefit analysis of this privatisation: if so, will the Government make it available.
(4) What is the sale price of Auscript and will details of the contract for reporting services be made available for public scrutiny.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The sale of Auscript was announced in the 1997 Budget.
(2) Corporatisation was one of the options considered by the review, but was not the recommended option.

(3) The review of the service considered the likely outcomes from a number of options. The decision to sell Auscript is based simply on the fact that Auscript provides services which the Government believes can and should be provided to clients by the private sector.

(4) As is standard sales practice, the estimated proceeds of the sale of Auscript have not been published as this would undermine the sales process. Details of the contract for reporting services will not be made public for reasons of commercial confidentiality.
